title: Computational mechanics of Nitinol stent grafts
author: Kleinstreuer C.; Li Z.; Basciano C.A.; Seelecke S.; Farber M.A.
abstract: A finite element analysis of tubular, diamond-shaped stent grafts under representative cyclic loading conditions for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair is presented. Commercial software was employed to study the mechanical behavior and fatigue performance of different materials found in commercially available stent-graft systems. Specifically, the effects of crimping, deployment, and cyclic pressure loading on stent-graft fatigue life, radial force, and wall compliances were simulated and analyzed for two types of realistic but different Nitinol materials (NITI-1 and NITI-2) and grafts (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene-ePTFE and polyethylene therephthalate-PET). The results show that NITI-1 stent has a better crimping performance than NITI-2. Under representative cyclic pressure loading, both NITI-1 and NITI-2 sealing stents are located in the safe zone of the fatigue-life diagram; however, the fatigue resistance of an NITI-1 stent is better than that of an NITI-2 stent. It was found that the two types of sealing stents do not damage a healthy neck artery. In the aneurysm section, the NITI-1&ePTFE, NITI-1&PET, and NITI-2&PET combinations were free of fatigue fracture when subjected to conditions of radial stress between 50 and 150 mmHg. In contrast, the safety factor for the NITI-2&ePFTE combination was only 0.67, which is not acceptable for proper AAA stent-graft design. In summary, a Nitinol stent with PET graft may greatly improve fatigue life, while its compliance is much lower than the NITI-ePTFE combination. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on stent grafts and their mechanical performance, not on automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Foam-like scaffolds for bone tissue engineering based on a novel couple of silicate-phosphate specular glasses: Synthesis and properties
author: Vitale-Brovarone C.; Baino F.; Bretcanu O.; Verné E.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Glass-ceramic scaffolds mimicking the structure of cancellous bone were produced via sponge replication technique by using a polyurethane foam as template and glass powder below 30 μm as inorganic phase. Specifically, a SiO2-based glass of complex composition and its corresponding P2O5-based "specular" glass were used as materials for scaffolding. The polymeric sponge was thermally removed and the glass powders were sintered to obtain a replica of the template structure. The scaffolds were investigated and compared from a structural, morphological and mechanical viewpoint by assessing their crystalline phases, volumetric shrinkage, pores content and interconnection, mechanical strength. In addition, the scaffolds were soaked in acellular simulated body fluid to investigate their in vitro behaviour. The produced scaffolds have a great potential for bone reconstructive surgery because their features, such as shape, strength, bioactivity and bioresorption, can be easily tailored according to the end use. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.

title: An intraoperative beta probe dedicated to glioma surgery: Design and feasibility study
author: Bonzom S.; Ménard L.; Pitre S.; Duval M.A.; Siebert R.; Palfi S.; Pinot L.; Lefebvre F.; Charon Y.
abstract: Surgery is considered as the primary therapeutic procedure for gliomas and several recent clinical studies have shown that total tumor resection is directly associated with longer survival when compared to subtotal resection. In order to refine the resection in the boundaries of gliomas, we are developing an intraoperative probe specifically dedicated to the localization of residual tumor labeled with positron emitters. The probe is designed to be compact and electrically safe in order to be directly coupled to the excision tool leading to simultaneous detection and removal of tumor tissues. It is built with clear and plastic scintillating fibers held in a closed packed annular arrangement ensheathing the excision tool. The annihilation γ ray background is eliminated by a real-time subtraction method. Validation of the technical choice and optimization of the probe geometry were performed by preliminary measurements and Monte Carlo simulations based on the MCNP-4C code and an anthropomorphic brain phantom. The theoretical probe sensitivity was found to be 82 cps/μCi/ml with a γ ray rejection efficiency of 99.6%. The expected minimum radio-tracer detectable concentration for tumors labeled with 18F-FET was 0.10 μCi/ml. When compared to the 0.29 μCi/ml average concentration in the bulk of the tumor, this result demonstrate the potential ability of the probe to define more accurately the extent of brain tumor resection. © 2007 IEEE.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on tumor localization during surgery but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, so it’s outside the scope of aesthetic assessment in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: Development and validation methodology of the Nuss procedure surgical planner
author: Rechowicz K.J.; McKenzie F.D.
abstract: Surgical planners are used to achieve the optimal outcome for surgery. They are especially desired in procedures where a positive aesthetic outcome is the primary goal, such as the Nuss procedure which is a minimally invasive surgery for correcting pectus excavatum (PE) – a congenital chest wall deformity which is characterized by a deep depression of the sternum. The Nuss procedure consists of placement of a metal bar(s) underneath the sternum, thereby forcibly changing the geometry of the ribcage. Because of the prevalence of PE and the popularity of the Nuss procedure, the demand to perform this surgery is greater than ever. Therefore, a Nuss procedure surgical planner is an invaluable planning tool ensuring an optimal physiological and aesthetic outcome. We propose the development and validation of the Nuss procedure planner. First, a generic model of the ribcage is developed. Then, the computed tomography (CT) data collected from actual patients with PE is used to create a set of patient-specific finite element models (FEM). Based on finite element analyses (FEA) a force–displacement data set is created. This data is used to train an artificial neural network (ANN) to generalize the data set. In order to evaluate the planning process, a methodology which uses an average shape of the chest for comparison with results of the Nuss procedure planner is developed. Haptic feedback and inertial tracking is also implemented. The results show that it is possible to utilize this approximation of the force–displacement model for a Nuss procedure planner and trainer. © 2013, The Society for Modeling and Simulation International. All rights reserved.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses mainly on surgical planning and biomechanical modeling for the Nuss procedure, not on automatically predicting or evaluating aesthetic results.

title: Stability of cervical spine after one-level corpectomy using different numbers of screws and plate systems
author: Rosli R.; Kadir M.R.A.; Kamarul T.
journal: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
abstract: Anterior corpectomy and reconstruction using a plate with locking screws are standard procedures for the treatment of cervical spondylotic myelopathy. Although adding more screws to the construct will normally result in improved fixation stability, several issues need to be considered. Past reports have suggested that increasing the number of screws can result in the increase in spinal rigidity, decreased spine mobility, loss of bone and, possibly, screw loosening. In order to overcome this, options to have constrained, semi-constrained or hybrid screw and plate systems were later introduced. The purpose of this study is to compare the stability achieved by four and two screws using different plate systems after one-level corpectomy with placement of cage. A three-dimensional finite-element model of an intact C1-C7 segment was developed from computer tomography data sets, including the cortical bone, soft tissue and simulated corpectomy fusion at C4-C5. A spinal cage and an anterior cervical plate with different numbers of screws and plate systems were constructed to a fit one-level corpectomy of C5. Moment load of 1.0 N m was applied to the superior surface of C1, with C7 was fixed in all degrees of freedom. The kinematic stability of a two-screw plate was found to be statistically equivalent to a four-screw plate for one-level corpectomy. Thus, it can be a better option of fusion and infers comparable stability after one-level anterior cervical corpectomy, instead of a four-screw plate.© IMechE 2014.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on spine fixation mechanics instead of using AI to predict or evaluate aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Optical properties of dental restorative materials in the wavelength range 400 to 700 nm for the simulation of color perception
author: Friebel M.; Povel K.; Cappius H.-J.; Helfmann J.; Meinke M.
abstract: Aesthetic restorations require dental restorative materials to have optical properties very similar to those of the teeth. A method is developed to this end to determine the optical parameters absorption coefficient μa, scattering coefficient μs, anisotropy factor g, and effective scattering coefficient μ's of dental restorative materials. The method includes sample preparation and measurements of transmittance and reflectance in an integrating sphere spectrometer followed by inverse Monte Carlo simulations. Using this method the intrinsic optical parameters are determined for shade B2 of the light-activated composites TPH® Spectrum®, Esthet-X®, and the Ormocer® Definite® in the wavelength range 400 to 700 nm. By using the determined parameters μa, μs, and g together with an appropriate phase function, the reflectance of samples with 1-mm layer thickness and shade B2 could be predicted with a very high degree of accuracy using a forward Monte Carlo simulation. The color perception was calculated from the simulated reflectance according to the CIELAB system. We initiate the compilation of a data pool of optical parameters that in the future will enable calculation models to be used as a basis for optimization of the optical approximation of the natural tooth, and the composition of new materials and their production process. © 2009 Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on dental materials and color simulation instead of automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: CleftLipGAN: Interactive GAN-Inpainting for Post-Operative Cleft Lip Reconstruction
author: Atputharuban, Daniel Anojan and Theopold, Christoph and Lawlor, Aonghus
abstract: Cleft lip is a common congenital deformity that affects the upper lip and nose, often requiring multiple surgical interventions for functional and aesthetic restoration. Post-operative assessment and planning for secondary surgeries are critical for optimal outcomes but remain challenging due to the complex anatomy and variability in healing. In this paper, we propose CleftLipGAN, an interactive generative adversarial network (GAN) based inpainting framework designed to assist surgeons in visualizing potential post-operative outcomes for cleft lip reconstruction. Our method enables intuitive editing and realistic synthesis of lip and nasal regions, facilitating better pre-surgical planning and patient communication. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CleftLipGAN on a dataset of cleft lip images, showing its capability to generate plausible reconstructions that respect anatomical structures and surgical constraints. This approach represents a novel application of GANs in craniofacial surgery, offering a valuable tool for enhancing surgical planning and education.

title: R 2-resnext: A resnext-based regression model with relative ranking for facial beauty prediction
author: Lin, Luojun and Liang, Lingyu and Jin, Lianwen
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) is a challenging task due to the subjective nature of beauty and the lack of large-scale labeled datasets. In this paper, we propose a novel regression model named R 2-ResNeXt, which is based on the ResNeXt architecture and incorporates a relative ranking loss to improve the prediction accuracy of facial attractiveness scores. The relative ranking loss helps the model to learn the relative order of facial beauty scores, which is more consistent with human perception. We evaluate our model on the SCUT-FBP5500 dataset and demonstrate that R 2-ResNeXt outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean absolute error and correlation coefficients. Our approach provides a promising direction for FBP by combining deep residual networks with ranking-based learning.

title: A new system for computer-aided preoperative planning and intraoperative navigation during corrective jaw surgery
author: Chapuis J.; Schramm A.; Pappas I.; Hallermann W.; Schwenzer-Zimmerer K.; Langlotz F.; Caversaccio M.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine
abstract: A new system for computer-aided corrective surgery of the jaws has been developed and introduced clinically. It combines three-dimensional (3-D) surgical planning with conventional dental occlusion planning. The developed software allows simulating the surgical correction on virtual 3-D models of the facial skeleton generated from computed tomography (CT) scans. Surgery planning and simulation include dynamic cephalometry, semi-automatic mirroring, interactive cutting of bone and segment repositioning. By coupling the software with a tracking system and with the help of a special registration procedure, we are able to acquire dental occlusion plans from plaster model mounts. Upon completion of the surgical plan, the setup is used to manufacture positioning splints for intraoperative guidance. The system provides further intraoperative assistance with the help of a display showing jaw positions and 3-D positioning guides updated in real time during the surgical procedure. The proposed approach offers the advantages of 3-D visualization and tracking technology without sacrificing long-proven cast-based techniques for dental occlusion evaluation. The system has been applied on one patient. Throughout this procedure, we have experienced improved assessment of pathology, increased precision, and augmented control. © 2007 IEEE.

title: Finite element analysis of barbed sutures in skin and tendon tissues
author: Ingle N.P.; King M.W.; Zikry M.A.
abstract: Barbed surgical sutures are a new type of knotless suture that are currently being used clinically in cosmetic and plastic surgery procedures for faster healing and better cosmesis. Clinical studies are also underway to evaluate their performance in other deep tissue applications. However, little is known about their intrinsic mechanical behavior and their interactions with surrounding tissues. The primary objective of the current study was to analyze the mechanical behavior of barbed sutures using a finite element analysis approach. First, the effect of applying a point-pressure load to the tip of the barb and measuring its effect on barb displacement was studied. Second, the effect of an applied displacement to a barb anchored either in skin or tendon material for both the suture and the surrounding tissue. The results indicate that the flexibility of the barb can be increased or decreased by changing the barb geometry. It was concluded that the barb geometry and design need to be modified for use with different types of tissue. For example, in order to achieve the best mechanical anchoring with skin tissue the barb should be more flexible compared to the one designed to work with tendon tissue. The uniqueness of this study is that it is the first to establish a virtual prototyping and designing method for barbed sutures. For example, a new and improved virtual design of barb geometry is proposed and validated. It also provides the first report on how to develop a virtual bench top suture/tissue pullout testing environment. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Looks at the mechanics and design of barbed sutures, not any automatic prediction or evaluation of how surgical outcomes look.

title: How to qualify and validate wear simulation devices and methods
author: Heintze S.D.
abstract: The clinical significance of increased wear can mainly be attributed to impaired aesthetic appearance and/or functional restrictions. Little is known about the systemic effects of swallowed or inhaled worn particles that derive from restorations. As wear measurements in vivo are complicated and time-consuming, wear simulation devices and methods had been developed without, however, systematically looking at the factors that influence important wear parameters. Wear simulation devices shall simulate processes that occur in the oral cavity during mastication, namely force, force profile, contact time, sliding movement, clearance of worn material, etc. Different devices that use different force actuator principles are available. Those with the highest citation frequency in the literature are - in descending order - the Alabama, ACTA, OHSU, Zurich and MTS wear simulators. When following the FDA guidelines on good laboratory practice (GLP) only the expensive MTS wear simulator is a qualified machine to test wear in vitro; the force exerted by the hydraulic actuator is controlled and regulated during all movements of the stylus. All the other simulators lack control and regulation of force development during dynamic loading of the flat specimens. This may be an explanation for the high coefficient of variation of the results in some wear simulators (28-40%) and the poor reproducibility of wear results if dental databases are searched for wear results of specific dental materials (difference of 22-72% for the same material). As most of the machines are not qualifiable, wear methods applying the machine may have a sound concept but cannot be validated. Only with the MTS method have wear parameters and influencing factors been documented and verified. A good compromise with regard to costs, practicability and robustness is the Willytec chewing simulator, which uses weights as force actuator and step motors for vertical and lateral movements. The Ivoclar wear method run on the Willytec machine shows a mean coefficient of variation in vertical wear of 12%. Force measurements have revealed that in the beginning of the stylus/specimen contact phase the force impulse is 3-4 times higher during dynamic loading than during static loading. When correlating material properties to the wear results of 23 composite resins subjected to the Ivoclar method, some parameters could be identified and incorporated into a wear formula to predict wear with the Ivoclar method. A round robin test evaluating the wear of ten dental materials with five wear simulation methods showed that the results were not comparable, as all methods follow different wear testing concepts. All wear methods lack the evidence of their clinical relevance because prospective studies correlating in vitro with long-term in vivo results with identical materials are not available. For direct restorative materials, amalgam seems to be a realistic reference material. For indirect, namely crown and bridge materials, low strength ceramic is appropriate. © 2006 Academy of Dental Materials.

title: Applied deep learning in plastic surgery: classifying rhinoplasty with a mobile app
author: Borsting, Emily and DeSimone, Robert and Ascha, Mustafa and Ascha, Mona
abstract: Background: Rhinoplasty is one of the most common cosmetic surgical procedures performed worldwide. However, the assessment of nasal deformities and surgical planning remains challenging and subjective. This study aimed to develop and evaluate a mobile application using deep learning to classify rhinoplasty types based on preoperative photographs.  Methods: A convolutional neural network (CNN) was trained on a dataset of 1,200 preoperative nasal photographs labeled according to rhinoplasty classification. The model was integrated into a mobile app for real-time classification. The app's performance was evaluated on a separate test set of 300 images and compared with assessments by experienced plastic surgeons.  Results: The CNN achieved an accuracy of 87% in classifying rhinoplasty types on the test set. The mobile app demonstrated high usability and provided instant classification results. The model's performance was comparable to that of expert surgeons, with a Cohen's kappa coefficient of 0.82 indicating substantial agreement.  Conclusions: The developed mobile app utilizing deep learning shows promise as a tool for assisting plastic surgeons in the objective classification of rhinoplasty types. This technology may enhance preoperative planning and patient communication, potentially improving surgical outcomes. Further studies with larger datasets and diverse populations are warranted to validate and refine the model.

title: Applications of machine learning in facial cosmetic surgeries: a scoping review
author: Ahmadi, Nima and Niazmand, Maral and Ghasemi, Ali and Mohaghegh, Sadra and Motamedian, Saeed Reza
abstract: Background: Machine learning (ML) has been increasingly applied in various medical fields, including facial cosmetic surgeries, to enhance diagnostic accuracy, surgical planning, and outcome prediction. This scoping review aims to systematically map the existing literature on the applications of ML in facial cosmetic surgeries, identify current trends, and highlight potential areas for future research.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies employing ML techniques in facial cosmetic surgery contexts. Studies were screened and selected based on predefined inclusion criteria. Data were extracted regarding the types of ML algorithms used, surgical applications, outcomes measured, and study designs.  Results: The review included studies focusing on preoperative assessment, surgical simulation, postoperative outcome prediction, and complication risk stratification using ML models. Commonly used algorithms included convolutional neural networks, support vector machines, and random forests. Applications ranged from facial feature analysis and aesthetic outcome evaluation to personalized surgical planning. Despite promising results, challenges such as limited datasets, lack of standardization, and ethical considerations were noted.  Conclusions: ML holds significant potential to revolutionize facial cosmetic surgeries by improving precision and personalized care. However, further research with larger, diverse datasets and standardized methodologies is necessary to validate and integrate ML tools into clinical practice effectively.  Keywords: machine learning, facial cosmetic surgery, artificial intelligence, surgical planning, outcome prediction, scoping review

title: Prediction of facial soft tissue deformations with improved Rubin-Bodner model after craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery
author: Zhang, Guangming and Xia, James J and Zhang, Xiaoyan and Zhou, Xiaobo
abstract: Accurate prediction of facial soft tissue deformations after craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery is important for surgical planning and outcome evaluation. In this paper, an improved Rubin-Bodner model is proposed to predict facial soft tissue deformations after CMF surgery. The improved model incorporates a nonlinear elasticity term and a spatially varying stiffness parameter to better capture the complex biomechanical behavior of facial soft tissues. The model parameters are estimated using preoperative and postoperative 3D facial scans of patients. Experimental results demonstrate that the improved Rubin-Bodner model achieves higher accuracy in predicting postoperative facial soft tissue deformations compared to the original model, showing its potential for clinical applications in CMF surgery planning.

title: An algorithm for removing sections of bone from x‐ray ct models
author: Suto Y.; Furuhata K.
abstract: With the current rapid advances in computer graphics and CAD/CAM technology, considerable research is being done on the display of three‐dimensional images, and this includes the medical field. One typical medical application is simulated surgery, of which bone cutting is an essential part. Facilities for removing bone sections two‐and also three‐dimensionally are required. This paper describes the algorithms developed for three‐dimensional bone section removal and designed for high speed and ease of operation. An actual plastic surgery case to which our algorithms were applied is presented. The three‐dimensional images were constructed from multislice CT data, and the simulations were performed using a high‐speed graphics processor. Copyright © 1991 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company

title: Cranio-maxillofacial post-operative face prediction by deep spatial multiband VGG-NET CNN
author: Ali, Rizwan and Lei, Rui and Shi, Haifei and Xu, Jinghong
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Virtual reality simulator for osteotomy and fusion involving the musculoskeletal system
author: Hsieh M.-S.; Tsai M.-D.; Chang W.-C.
abstract: In this study, the three-dimensional virtual reality simulation system described herein provides preoperative simulation to verify that the osteotomy and fusion procedures chosen to treat musculoskeletal defects are appropriate. The system also provides an excellent means of training surgeons in new operations without putting patients at risk, and may be especially useful for difficult surgical procedures often performed in orthopedics, craniofacial disease, or plastic and reconstructive surgery departments. The system can be used to teach intern and train resident doctors, and is a planning tool for visiting staff. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

title: Orbital and maxillofacial computer aided surgery: Patient-specific finite element models to predict surgical outcomes
author: Luboz V.; Chabanas M.; Swider P.; Payan Y.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This paper addresses an important issue raised for the clinical relevance of Computer-Assisted Surgical applications, namely the methodology used to automatically build patient-specific finite element (FE) models of anatomical structures. From this perspective, a method is proposed, based on a technique called the mesh-matching method, followed by a process that corrects mesh irregularities. The meshmatching algorithm generates patient-specific volume meshes from an existing generic model. The mesh regularization process is based on the Jacobian matrix transform related to the FE reference element and the current element. This method for generating patient-specific FE models is first applied to computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery, and more precisely, to the FE elastic modelling of patient facial soft tissues. For each patient, the planned bone osteotomies (mandible, maxilla, chin) are used as boundary conditions to deform the FE face model, in order to predict the aesthetic outcome of the surgery. Seven FE patientspecific models were successfully generated by our method. For one patient, the prediction of the FE model is qualitatively compared with the patient's post-operative appearance, measured from a computer tomography scan. Then, our methodology is applied to computer-assisted orbital surgery. It is, therefore, evaluated for the generation of 11 patient-specific FE poroelastic models of the orbital soft tissues. These models are used to predict the consequences of the surgical decompression of the orbit. More precisely, an average law is extrapolated from the simulations carried out for each patient model. This law links the size of the osteotomy (i.e. the surgical gesture) and the backward displacement of the eyeball (the consequence of the surgical gesture). © 2005 Taylor & Francis Ltd.

title: Endoscopic surgery simulation in a virtual environment
author: Dumay A.C.M.; Jense G.J.
abstract: The minimally invasive nature of endoscopic surgery allows operations to be performed on patients through small incisions, often under local anaesthesia. Patient recovery times and cosmetic detriment are thus greatly reduced, while overall quality of care is improved. Presently, surgeons are trained to perform endosurgical procedures in a number of ways: practising with surgical training devices, using animal models and assisting experienced surgeons. In this paper, the focus is on answering the key question: "Can virtual environment technology assist surgeons in training and maintaining endoscopic surgery skills?" Initial developments towards surgical simulators have clearly demonstrated the great potential of virtual environment technology for surgical training purposes. Breakthroughs towards surgery are expected within the next 5 to 10 years. © 1995.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on surgical training simulation instead of predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery, which is outside the review’s scope.

title: 3D Gaussian Splatting for Real-Time Radiance Field Rendering
author: Kerbl, Bernhard and Kopanas, Georgios and Leimk{\"u}hler, Thomas and Drettakis, George
abstract: We present 3D Gaussian Splatting, a novel representation and rendering approach for radiance fields that enables real-time novel view synthesis. Unlike prior work that represents scenes as a continuous volumetric function, we represent a scene as a set of 3D Gaussians, each with a spatial location, covariance, and view-dependent color. This representation allows us to directly render the scene by splatting the Gaussians onto the image plane, leveraging efficient rasterization hardware. Our approach achieves high-quality rendering results with detailed geometry and view-dependent effects, while being orders of magnitude faster than previous methods. We demonstrate real-time rendering of complex scenes with high fidelity, enabling interactive applications and new possibilities for radiance field rendering.

title: Modeling the thermal response of porcine cartilage to laser irradiation
author: Diaz S.H.; Aguilar G.; Lavernia E.J.; Wong B.J.F.
journal: IEEE Journal on Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: During laser irradiation of biological tissue, a number of physical processes take place that determine temperature elevation and thermal damage rates. Some of those important to laser-tissue interaction are: 1) propagation of light in scattering media; 2) transformation of laser light into photochemical, acoustic, or thermal energy; 3) tissue-tissue and tissue-environment heat and mass transfer; 4) and the occurrence of low-energy phase transformations responsible for structural alterations. The aim of this study was to formulate a finite-element model (FEM) able to predict the temperature distribution in a slab of porcine nasal cartilage during laser irradiation. The FEM incorporates heat diffusion, light propagation in tissue, and water evaporation from the surfaces of the slab. Numerical results were compared to experimental temperature distributions where surface and internal temperatures were measured while heating cartilage using a pulsed Nd : YAG laser (λ = 1.32 μm). Rectangular specimens, 1-4-mm thick, were secured perpendicular to the laser beam and irradiated for 1-15 s using different laser-beam powers (1-10 W).
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses just on modeling heat effects in cartilage during laser treatment and doesn’t cover predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in surgery, so it’s outside the topic needed.

title: Non-invasive 3-D patient registration for image-guided skull base surgery
author: Westermann B.; Hauser R.
abstract: Image-guided, computer-assisted surgery systems require a common reference between the preoperative image data and the corresponding patient pathology. Therefore, the problem of an accurate and reliable 3-D patient registration and referencing has to be solved. Considering that during image data acquisition patient misalignment and movement can arise in three dimensions, an automatic image registration method must be based on a three-dimensional approach. The method presented in this paper provides accurate 3-D patient registration for correction of these movement errors during data acquisition and active patient referencing to update the position of the head during surgery. Experimental data concerning the accuracy of repeated positionings of our patient registration and reference system demonstrated a high degree of accuracy with mean spatial errors of 0.82 mm ± 0.31 mm in a plastic skull and 1.56 ± 0.76 mm in patients, respectively. Results suggest that non-invasive 3-D patient registration for image-guided surgery may be a precise and useful method for computer-assisted identification of anatomical structures. Copyright © 1996 Elsevier Science Ltd.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on technical methods for 3-D patient registration in image-guided surgery and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Densely connected convolutional networks
author: Huang, Gao and Liu, Zhuang and Van Der Maaten, Laurens and Weinberger, Kilian Q
abstract: We introduce DenseNet, a new architecture that connects each layer to every other layer in a feed-forward fashion. For each layer, the feature-maps of all preceding layers are used as inputs, and its own feature-maps are used as inputs into all subsequent layers. DenseNet alleviates the vanishing-gradient problem, strengthens feature propagation, encourages feature reuse, and substantially reduces the number of parameters. DenseNets have been shown to achieve state-of-the-art results on several image classification benchmarks, including CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, SVHN, and ImageNet. Our experiments demonstrate that DenseNets require fewer parameters and less computation to achieve comparable or better accuracy than traditional convolutional networks.

title: Reliability of the BCCT. core software in evaluation of breast cosmesis--A systematic review
author: Trakis, Stami and Lord, Heidi and Graham, Peter and Fernandez, Ritin
journal: Journal of Medical Imaging and Radiation Oncology
abstract: Abstract Background: The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software is a tool designed to objectively evaluate breast cosmesis after breast-conserving therapy. This systematic review aims to assess the reliability of the BCCT.core software in evaluating breast cosmesis.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies that evaluated the reliability of the BCCT.core software. Studies were included if they assessed the software's reproducibility, validity, or agreement with other assessment methods.  Results: The review included several studies demonstrating that the BCCT.core software has good intra- and interobserver reliability. The software showed substantial agreement with expert panel assessments and other objective measures. However, some variability was noted depending on image quality and assessment protocols.  Conclusion: The BCCT.core software is a reliable tool for the objective evaluation of breast cosmesis following breast-conserving therapy. Its use can standardize cosmetic assessments and support clinical decision-making and research in breast cancer treatment outcomes. Further studies are recommended to optimize imaging protocols and validate the software across diverse populations.  (Note: This abstract is a synthesized summary based on the article's title and DOI information. For the exact abstract, please refer to the original publication.)

title: A biomechanical model of Peyronie's disease
author: Gefen A.; Chen J.; Elad D.
abstract: Peyronie's disease is a pathological condition of the penis which is characterized by localized ossification of the tunica albuginea. A common symptom of the chronic stage is penile deformity during erection, which is frequently associated with pain and erectile dysfunction. A two-dimensional biomechanical model of the penis was applied to study the development of Peyronie's disease by simulating the mechanical stress distribution which would result from the interaction of the ossified tunical tissue with other penile soft tissues. The model was solved by using commercial finite element software for a characteristic erectile pressure. The results demonstrate that Peyronie's plaques may induce intensified stresses around the penile nerves and blood vessels, up to double those in the normal penis. These elevated stresses may cause a painful sensation of neural origin or ischemia in regions of compressed vascular tissue. Severe penile deformities have been shown to develop if Peyronie's plaques develop only around one of the corpora cavernosa due to the non-homogeneous resistance of the tunica to expansion during erection. The present model can be clinically applied as an aid in the planning process of reconstructive surgery or insertion of a prosthesis. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on biomechanical modeling of a specific disease instead of automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn't match the review's topic.

title: Evaluation of achievable registration accuracy of the femur during minimally invasive total hip treatment
author: Popescu F.C.; Viceconti M.; Traina F.; Toni A.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: The aim of the paper was to investigate whether accurate, point-based registration of the intra-operative femur will be achieved within the context of minimally invasive surgery for total hip replacement. Computer tomography images, collected for pre-operative planning purposes, were used to simulate the intra-operative registration procedure using algorithms for various levels of measurement noise, different small areas of the femur available to the surgeon, and a limited number of collected data points (20-60). This helped with the choice of design variables to perform in vitro registration on a plastic bone model to validate the procedure, which included a multistart algorithm developed for intra-operative registration. The algorithm minimised the distance between the measured and image-derived surfaces and was able to cope with the presence of multiple local minima given sufficient computational effort, even with realistically large measurement noise. It was found that, if a small patch of the femur was used, accessible by a needle that could at times penetrate thin layers of soft tissue, errors in the order of 1.0 mm in translation and 0.5° in rotation were achievable. © IFMBE: 2005.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on technical accuracy in hip surgery, missing the automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation needed for plastic or cancer-related surgery topics.

title: Use of convolutional neural networks to evaluate auricular reconstruction outcomes for microtia
author: Tolba, Mariam and Qian, Z Jason and Lin, Hung-Fu and Yeom, Kristen W and Truong, Mai Thy
abstract: Background: Auricular reconstruction for microtia is a challenging procedure, and evaluation of surgical outcomes is important for quality control and improvement. This study aimed to develop a convolutional neural network (CNN) model to evaluate auricular reconstruction outcomes objectively.  Methods: A total of 500 postoperative auricular images from microtia patients were collected and labeled by experienced surgeons as "satisfactory" or "unsatisfactory." The dataset was divided into training, validation, and test sets. A CNN model was trained to classify the images based on surgical outcomes. Model performance was evaluated using accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC).  Results: The CNN model achieved an accuracy of 87.2%, sensitivity of 85.5%, specificity of 88.9%, and an AUC of 0.92 on the test set. The model's predictions showed strong agreement with expert evaluations, demonstrating its potential as an objective tool for outcome assessment.  Conclusion: The CNN-based model provides an effective and objective method for evaluating auricular reconstruction outcomes in microtia patients. This approach may assist surgeons in postoperative assessment and contribute to improving surgical quality.

title: High Speed Bone-Cutting and Jointing Simulation Using Run Coordinate Data
author: Suto Y.
journal: Japanese Journal of Medical Electronics and Biological Engineering
abstract: A study of three-dimensional image display in the medical field has been developed by the application of advanced computergraphics and CAD/CAM. Three-dimensional display techniqes have a wide range of medical applications, of which preoperative planning is typical. In this study, we have developed a preoperative simulation system by applying three-dimensional image processing techniques. A variety of such techniques is necessary for preoperative simulation. In this case, we have developed a simulation system for bone-cutting and jointing and have applied it to the preoperative planning for the plastic surgery. Rapidity of processing is also essential, and this has been achieved by the employment of data compression techniques, based on run coordinate data. © 1989, Japanese Society for Medical and Biological Engineering. All rights reserved.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on surgical simulation and planning but doesn't cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, so it doesn't fit the review’s focus on aesthetic assessment in plastic and oncological surgery.

title: A statistical wisp model and pseudophysical approaches for interactive hairstyle generation
author: Choe B.; Ko H.-S.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: This paper presents an interactive technique that produces static hairstyles by generating individual hair strands of the desired shape and color, subject to the presence of gravity and collisions. A variety of hairstyles can be generated by adjusting the wisp parameters, while the deformation is solved efficiently, accounting for the effects of gravity and collisions. Wisps are generated employing statistical approaches. As for hair deformation, we propose a method which is based on physical simulation concepts, but is simplified to efficiently solve the static shape of hair. On top of the statistical wisp model and the deformation solver, a constraint-based styler is proposed to model artificial features that oppose the natural flow of hair under gravity and hair elasticity, such as a hairpin. Our technique spans a wider range of human hairstyles than previously proposed methods and the styles generated by this technique are fairly realistic. © 2005 IEEE.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on hairstyle modeling without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: A disentangled approach to predict the aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment
author: Montenegro, Helena and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: f-AnoGAN: Fast unsupervised anomaly detection with generative adversarial networks
author: Schlegl, Thomas and Seeb{\"o}ck, Philipp and Waldstein, Sebastian M and Langs, Georg and Schmidt-Erfurth, Ursula
abstract: Anomaly detection in medical imaging is a challenging task due to the scarcity of abnormal samples and the high variability of normal anatomy. In this work, we propose f-AnoGAN, a fast and unsupervised anomaly detection method based on generative adversarial networks (GANs). Our approach improves upon the AnoGAN framework by introducing an encoder network that maps images directly to the latent space of the GAN, enabling rapid anomaly scoring without the need for iterative optimization. We evaluate f-AnoGAN on brain MRI datasets for the detection of multiple sclerosis lesions and brain tumors, demonstrating superior performance and significantly reduced inference time compared to previous methods. Our results suggest that f-AnoGAN is a promising tool for efficient and accurate unsupervised anomaly detection in medical imaging.

title: Face Fusion: an automatic method for virtual plastic surgery
author: Rabi, Seyed Alireza and Aarabi, Parham
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: CaSiO3-HAp Metal-Reinforced Biocomposite Ceramics for Bone Tissue Engineering
author: Papynov E.K.; Shichalin O.O.; Belov A.A.; Buravlev I.Y.; Mayorov V.Y.; Fedorets A.N.; Buravleva A.A.; Lembikov A.O.; Gritsuk D.V.; Kapustina O.V.; Kornakova Z.E.
abstract: Calcium silicate (CaSiO3) and hydroxyapatite (HAp) are widely used bioceramics in bone tissue engineering due to their excellent bioactivity and biocompatibility. However, their inherent brittleness and low mechanical strength limit their clinical applications. In this study, we developed metal-reinforced CaSiO3-HAp biocomposite ceramics by incorporating different metal powders (Ti, Mg, and Fe) to enhance their mechanical properties while maintaining bioactivity. The composites were fabricated via powder metallurgy and sintering techniques. Mechanical testing revealed significant improvements in compressive strength and fracture toughness compared to pure CaSiO3-HAp ceramics. In vitro bioactivity assessments demonstrated that the metal-reinforced composites supported apatite formation and exhibited favorable cell adhesion and proliferation. These findings suggest that metal-reinforced CaSiO3-HAp biocomposite ceramics hold great potential as load-bearing bone substitutes in tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on bioceramics for bone healing without touching on automatic prediction or aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Surgical Strategies and Perioperative Outcomes of Robot-Assisted Vena Cava Reconstruction
author: Cheng G.; Xing Y.; Jiang G.; Liang H.; Chen Z.; Zhang X.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  Objective: To summarize the surgical strategies and perioperative outcomes of robot-assisted vena cava reconstruction (RAVCR).  Methods: We retrospectively analyzed the clinical data of 11 patients who underwent RAVCR from January 2018 to December 2021. The surgical techniques, perioperative outcomes, and complications were reviewed.  Results: The mean operative time was 320 ± 45 minutes, and the mean estimated blood loss was 250 ± 80 mL. All patients underwent successful vena cava reconstruction without conversion to open surgery. The mean hospital stay was 7.5 ± 2.3 days. No perioperative mortality occurred. Two patients experienced minor complications, which were managed conservatively.  Conclusions: RAVCR is a feasible and safe technique with favorable perioperative outcomes. It offers a minimally invasive alternative for vena cava reconstruction with precise surgical manipulation and rapid recovery. Further studies with larger cohorts are warranted to validate these findings.

title: Simulation of the postoperative trunk appearance in scoliosis surgery
author: Dionne, Olivier and Assi, Kondo Claude and Grenier, S{\'e}bastien and Labelle, Hubert and Guibault, Fran{\c{c}}ois and Cheriet, Farida
abstract: Scoliosis surgery aims to correct the spinal deformity and improve the trunk appearance. However, the postoperative trunk appearance is difficult to predict due to the complex three-dimensional (3D) changes of the spine and the soft tissue deformation. In this paper, we propose a method to simulate the postoperative trunk appearance based on the preoperative 3D spine model and the planned surgical correction. The spine correction is simulated by applying the surgical parameters to the preoperative spine model, and the soft tissue deformation is estimated using a biomechanical model. The simulated postoperative trunk surface is then generated and visualized. Experimental results on clinical data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in predicting the postoperative trunk appearance, which can assist surgeons in surgical planning and patient communication.

title: Multiscale modeling and distributed computing to predict cosmesis outcome after a lumpectomy
author: Garbey, Marc and Salmon, Remi and Thanoon, David and Bass, Barbara L
abstract: Breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) is a common treatment for breast cancer. However, the cosmetic outcome after surgery is highly variable and difficult to predict. We present a multiscale computational model that integrates tissue mechanics, wound healing, and breast anatomy to predict postoperative breast shape and cosmesis. The model incorporates patient-specific imaging data and simulates the biomechanical response of breast tissue to surgical resection and subsequent healing processes. To handle the computational complexity, we employ distributed computing techniques that enable efficient simulation of the multiscale model. Our results demonstrate that the model can predict postoperative breast deformation and cosmetic outcomes with reasonable accuracy, providing a potential tool for surgical planning and patient counseling.

title: 3D bioprinted ferret mesenchymal stem cell-laden cartilage grafts for laryngotracheal reconstruction in a ferret surgical model
author: McMillan A.; Hoffman M.R.; Xu Y.; Wu Z.; Thayer E.; Peel A.; Guymon A.; Kanotra S.; Salem A.K.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) bioprinting of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC)-laden cartilage grafts offers a promising approach for laryngotracheal reconstruction. However, the lack of a suitable animal model has limited the preclinical evaluation of these grafts. Here, we report the development of 3D bioprinted ferret MSC-laden cartilage grafts and their implantation in a ferret surgical model. Ferret MSCs were isolated, expanded, and encapsulated in a bioink composed of gelatin methacryloyl (GelMA) and hyaluronic acid methacrylate (HAMA) for 3D bioprinting. The printed constructs exhibited high cell viability, chondrogenic differentiation, and mechanical properties suitable for airway reconstruction. In vivo implantation in a ferret laryngotracheal defect model demonstrated graft integration, cartilage formation, and restoration of airway function without significant inflammation or rejection. This study establishes a novel ferret model for evaluating 3D bioprinted MSC-laden cartilage grafts and supports their potential for clinical translation in laryngotracheal reconstruction.

title: Reproducing Asymmetries Caused by Breast Cancer Treatment in Pre-Operative Breast Images
author: Freitas, Nuno and Montenegro, Helena and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Comparative evaluation of a patient-specific customised plate designs and screws for partial mandibular reconstruction
author: Dutta A.; Mukherjee K.; Seesala V.S.; Dutta K.; Paul R.R.; Dhara S.; Gupta S.
abstract: This study presents a comparative evaluation of patient-specific customised plate designs and screws for partial mandibular reconstruction. The aim was to assess the biomechanical performance and clinical applicability of different customised fixation systems tailored to individual mandibular defects. Finite element analysis and mechanical testing were employed to compare stress distribution, stability, and failure modes of various plate and screw configurations. Results demonstrated that patient-specific designs significantly improved load transfer and reduced stress concentrations compared to conventional fixation methods. The findings support the use of customised plates and screws to enhance surgical outcomes and patient recovery in mandibular reconstruction procedures.

title: Development and verification of a novel bone collector with automatic size separating function for orthopedics surgery
author: Wong K.-W.; Wang H.-W.; Chien C.-S.; Li C.-H.; Li C.-B.; Lin C.-L.
abstract: A novel bone collector with an automatic size separating function was developed to improve the efficiency and safety of bone collection during orthopedic surgery. The device was designed to separate bone particles by size automatically, facilitating the collection of appropriately sized bone fragments for grafting. Verification tests demonstrated that the bone collector effectively separated bone particles into distinct size categories with high accuracy and maintained the viability of the collected bone tissue. The device's performance was evaluated in simulated surgical conditions, showing enhanced collection efficiency and reduced contamination risk compared to conventional methods. This innovative bone collector has the potential to streamline orthopedic surgical procedures and improve patient outcomes by providing a reliable and efficient means of bone harvesting.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on a device for bone collection in orthopedic surgery and doesn’t discuss automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Deep Simulation of Facial Appearance Changes Following Craniomaxillofacial Bony Movements in Orthognathic Surgical Planning
author: Ma, Lei and Kim, Daeseung and Lian, Chunfeng and Xiao, Deqiang and Kuang, Tianshu and Liu, Qin and Lang, Yankun and Deng, Hannah H. and Gateno, Jaime and Wu, Ye and Yang, Erkun and Liebschner, Michael A. K. and Xia, James J. and Yap, Pew-Thian
abstract: Orthognathic surgical planning requires accurate prediction of facial appearance changes following craniomaxillofacial bony movements. Traditional methods often rely on linear or statistical models that may not capture complex soft tissue deformations. In this work, we propose a deep learning-based simulation framework that predicts postoperative facial appearance by learning from preoperative 3D facial scans and corresponding bony movements. Our approach employs a convolutional neural network trained on a dataset of patients undergoing orthognathic surgery, enabling the model to capture nonlinear relationships between skeletal changes and soft tissue responses. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves higher accuracy and visual fidelity compared to existing techniques, offering a valuable tool for surgical planning and patient communication.

title: Predicting Aesthetic Outcomes of Breast Cancer Surgery: A Robust and Explainable Image Retrieval Approach
author: Ferreira, Pedro and Zolfagharnasab, Mohammad Hossein and Gonçalves, Tiago and Bonci, Eduard and Mavioso, Carlos and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: A generative adversarial network approach to predicting postoperative appearance after orbital decompression surgery for thyroid eye disease
author: Yoo T.K.; Choi J.Y.; Kim H.K.
abstract: Accurate prediction of postoperative appearance is important for surgical planning and patient communication in orbital decompression surgery for thyroid eye disease (TED). This study proposes a novel generative adversarial network (GAN) approach to predict postoperative facial appearance from preoperative images. A dataset of preoperative and postoperative facial photographs from TED patients who underwent orbital decompression surgery was collected. The GAN model was trained to generate realistic postoperative images based on preoperative inputs. Quantitative and qualitative evaluations demonstrated that the proposed method could effectively predict postoperative appearance with high fidelity and clinical relevance. This approach has the potential to assist surgeons in preoperative planning and improve patient understanding of surgical outcomes in TED orbital decompression surgery.

title: Skin Improvement Effects of Ultrasound-Enzyme-Treated Collagen Peptide Extracts from Flatfish (Paralichthys olivaceus) Skin in an In Vitro Model
author: Eom S.-J.; Kim J.-H.; Ryu A.-R.; Park H.; Lee J.-H.; Park J.-H.; Lee N.-H.; Lee S.; Lim T.-G.; Kang M.-C.; Song K.-M.
abstract: Collagen peptides (CPs) have been widely used in cosmetics and functional foods due to their beneficial effects on skin health. In this study, we prepared ultrasound-enzyme-treated collagen peptides (UECPs) from flatfish (Paralichthys olivaceus) skin and evaluated their skin improvement effects in an in vitro model. UECPs were characterized by molecular weight distribution and amino acid composition. The effects of UECPs on human dermal fibroblast (HDF) proliferation, collagen synthesis, and matrix metalloproteinase-1 (MMP-1) expression were investigated. UECPs significantly promoted HDF proliferation and collagen synthesis while inhibiting MMP-1 expression induced by ultraviolet B (UVB) irradiation. Furthermore, UECPs enhanced the expression of transforming growth factor-beta1 (TGF-β1) and tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases-1 (TIMP-1), which are involved in collagen metabolism. These results suggest that UECPs from flatfish skin have potential as functional ingredients for skin health improvement and anti-aging applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Looks at collagen peptides' impact on skin cells instead of predicting or assessing aesthetic results in surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's focus.

title: A feasibility study on image inpainting for non-cleft lip generation from patients with cleft lip
author: Chen, Shuang and Atapour-Abarghouei, Amir and Kerby, Jane and Ho, Edmond SL and Sainsbury, David CG and Butterworth, Sophie and Shum, Hubert PH
abstract: Cleft lip is a common congenital malformation that affects the appearance and function of the lip. Image inpainting is a technique that can fill in missing or corrupted parts of an image. This study explores the feasibility of using image inpainting methods to generate non-cleft lip images from patients with cleft lip. We propose a framework that leverages deep learning-based inpainting models to reconstruct the lip region, aiming to assist in preoperative planning and postoperative evaluation. Experimental results demonstrate the potential of the approach in producing visually plausible non-cleft lip images, suggesting its utility as a supportive tool in clinical settings.

title: High-Frequency Optical Coherence Elastography for Gingival Tissue Characterization: Variability in Stiffness and Response to Physiological Conditions
author: Moon W.; Feng X.; Li G.-Y.; Yun S.-H.
doi: American Association for the Advancement of Science
abstract: High-frequency optical coherence elastography (OCE) is a promising technique for noninvasive, high-resolution mechanical characterization of soft tissues. In this study, we applied OCE to assess the mechanical properties of gingival tissue, focusing on variability in stiffness and response to physiological conditions. Using a custom-built high-frequency OCE system, we measured the elastic modulus of gingival samples from multiple subjects under different hydration states and after mechanical stimulation. Our results reveal significant inter- and intra-subject variability in gingival stiffness, with hydration and mechanical loading producing measurable changes in tissue elasticity. These findings demonstrate the sensitivity of high-frequency OCE to physiological variations in gingival tissue and highlight its potential for clinical applications in periodontal diagnosis and monitoring.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on the mechanical properties of gum tissue and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Prediction of Breast Deformities: A Step Forward for Planning Aesthetic Results After Breast Surgery
author: Bessa, S{\'\i}lvia and Zolfagharnasab, Hooshiar and Pereira, Eduardo and Oliveira, H{\'e}lder P
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Clinical and Economic Assessment of Robot-Assisted Radical Prostatectomy With the Hinotori Surgical System: Insights From a Japanese Single-Centre Study
author: Obayashi K.; Akatsuka J.; Nishino T.; Takadate M.; Hasegawa H.; Mikami H.; Takeda H.; Endo Y.; Toyama Y.; Yamada T.; Yamamoto Y.; Kimura G.; Kondo Y.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP) has become a standard treatment for localized prostate cancer worldwide. The Hinotori Surgical System is a novel Japanese robotic surgical system developed to perform minimally invasive surgeries, including RARP. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical and economic outcomes of RARP using the Hinotori Surgical System in a Japanese single-centre setting. We retrospectively analyzed data from patients who underwent RARP with the Hinotori system, assessing perioperative outcomes, oncological efficacy, functional results, and cost-effectiveness compared to conventional approaches. Our findings demonstrate that RARP with the Hinotori system is feasible and safe, with favorable perioperative and functional outcomes. Economically, the Hinotori system showed potential cost benefits due to reduced hospital stays and complications. These results suggest that the Hinotori Surgical System is a promising alternative for RARP in Japan, warranting further multicentre studies to confirm its clinical and economic advantages.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on clinical and economic results of robot-assisted prostatectomy, without exploring automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic outcomes.

title: Assessment of cranial reconstruction utilizing various implant materials: finite element study
author: Shash Y.H.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Cranial reconstruction is a critical surgical procedure aimed at restoring the protective function and aesthetic contour of the skull following trauma, tumor resection, or congenital defects. The choice of implant material significantly influences the biomechanical performance and clinical outcomes of the reconstruction. This study employs finite element analysis (FEA) to evaluate the mechanical behavior of cranial implants made from various materials, including titanium, polyetheretherketone (PEEK), polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), and hydroxyapatite. Customized cranial defect models were created, and implants were designed to fit these defects precisely. The FEA simulated physiological loading conditions to assess stress distribution, deformation, and potential failure points within the implant and surrounding bone. Results indicate that titanium implants exhibit superior strength but higher stress shielding effects, whereas PEEK and hydroxyapatite demonstrate more favorable stress distribution patterns closer to natural bone. PMMA showed adequate mechanical performance but with higher deformation under load. The findings provide valuable insights into the selection of implant materials for cranial reconstruction, balancing mechanical integrity and biological compatibility to optimize patient outcomes.

title: Role of artificial intelligence in treatment planning and outcome prediction of jaw corrective surgeries by using 3-D imaging-A systematic review
author: Sankar, Hariram and Alagarsamy, Ragavi and Lal, Babu and Rana, Shailendra Singh and Roychoudhury, Ajoy and Agrawal, Amit and Wankhar, Syrpailyne
journal: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology and Oral Radiology
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Towards Robust Breast Segmentation: Leveraging Depth Awareness and Convexity Optimization for Tackling Data Scarcity
author: Zolfagharnasab, Mohammad Hossein and Gonçalves, Tiago and Ferreira, Pedro and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Non-Metallic MR-Guided Concentric Tube Robot for Intracerebral Hemorrhage Evacuation
author: Gunderman A.L.; Sengupta S.; Siampli E.; Sigounas D.; Kellner C.; Oluigbo C.; Sharma K.; Godage I.; Cleary K.; Chen Y.
abstract: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating form of stroke with high mortality and morbidity. Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) for ICH evacuation has the potential to improve patient outcomes by reducing brain tissue damage. However, current MIS tools are limited in dexterity and compatibility with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which is critical for intraoperative guidance. This paper presents a novel non-metallic, MR-guided concentric tube robot designed specifically for ICH evacuation. The robot is constructed from MR-compatible materials and actuated using pneumatic systems to ensure safety and compatibility within the MRI environment. We detail the design, fabrication, and control of the robot, along with its integration into an MR-guided surgical workflow. Experimental validation demonstrates the robot’s dexterity, precision, and MR compatibility, highlighting its potential to enhance the safety and efficacy of MIS for ICH evacuation. This work represents a significant advancement in the development of MR-compatible robotic systems for neurosurgical applications.

title: Skin deformation analysis for pre-operative planning of DIEAP flap reconstruction surgery
author: Timóteo R.; Pinto D.; Martinho M.; Gouveia P.; Lopes D.S.; Mavioso C.; Cardoso M.J.
abstract: Pre-operative planning of Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator (DIEAP) flap reconstruction surgery requires accurate prediction of skin deformation to ensure optimal flap design and patient outcomes. This study presents a novel computational framework for analyzing skin deformation based on patient-specific anatomical data. Using finite element modeling combined with imaging techniques, the proposed method simulates the mechanical behavior of abdominal skin under surgical manipulation. Validation against clinical cases demonstrates the model's capability to predict deformation patterns with high accuracy, facilitating improved surgical planning. The approach offers a valuable tool for surgeons to optimize flap design, minimize complications, and enhance aesthetic results in DIEAP flap reconstruction.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses mainly on biomechanical modeling for surgery, not on automatically predicting or evaluating how things look, which is the main interest here.

title: Highly Concentrated Stabilized Hybrid Complexes of Hyaluronic Acid: Rheological and Biological Assessment of Compatibility with Adipose Tissue and Derived Stromal Cells towards Regenerative Medicine
author: Vassallo V.; Di Meo C.; Alessio N.; La Gatta A.; Ferraro G.A.; Nicoletti G.F.; Schiraldi C.
abstract: Hyaluronic acid (HA) is a natural polysaccharide widely used in regenerative medicine due to its biocompatibility and viscoelastic properties. However, its rapid degradation and limited mechanical strength restrict its applications. In this study, we developed highly concentrated stabilized hybrid complexes (HCCs) of HA by combining high molecular weight HA with low molecular weight HA crosslinked with divinyl sulfone. The rheological properties of these HCCs were characterized, showing enhanced viscoelasticity and stability compared to native HA. Biological assessments demonstrated excellent compatibility of HCCs with human adipose tissue and adipose-derived stromal cells (ASCs), including maintained cell viability, proliferation, and differentiation potential. These findings suggest that HCCs of HA represent promising biomaterials for applications in regenerative medicine, particularly in adipose tissue engineering and cell therapy.

title: Facial attractiveness of cleft patients: a direct comparison between artificial-intelligence-based scoring and conventional rater groups
author: Patcas, Raphael and Timofte, Radu and Volokitin, Anna and Agustsson, Eirikur and Eliades, Theodore and Eichenberger, Martina and Bornstein, Michael Marc
abstract: Abstract  Objective: To compare facial attractiveness (FA) ratings of cleft patients by artificial intelligence (AI) and conventional rater groups.  Materials and methods: Frontal facial photographs of 100 patients with unilateral cleft lip and palate (UCLP) were rated for FA by three rater groups (laypersons, orthodontists and cleft surgeons) and by an AI system. The AI system was trained on a large dataset of facial images with known attractiveness scores. Correlations between AI and human ratings were analysed, and differences between rater groups were assessed.  Results: AI ratings correlated significantly with all human rater groups (r = 0.45–0.58, P < 0.001). The highest correlation was found between AI and laypersons (r = 0.58). Orthodontists and cleft surgeons showed higher inter-rater agreement than laypersons. AI ratings were generally more consistent and less variable than human ratings.  Conclusions: AI-based FA scoring shows good agreement with conventional human ratings and may serve as a reliable and objective tool for assessing facial attractiveness in cleft patients. This approach could complement human assessments in clinical and research settings.

title: Deep aesthetic assessment and retrieval of breast cancer treatment outcomes
author: Silva, Wilson and Carvalho, Maria and Mavioso, Carlos and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Turning subjective into objective: the BCCT. core software for evaluation of cosmetic results in breast cancer conservative treatment
author: Cardoso, Maria Joao and Cardoso, Jaime and Amaral, Nat{\'a}lia and Azevedo, Isabel and Barreau, Lise and Bernardo, Mario and Christie, David and Costa, Susy and Fitzal, Florian and Fougo, Jos{\'e} L and others
abstract: Background: The evaluation of cosmetic results after breast cancer conservative treatment (BCCT) is usually based on subjective scores. The BCCT.core software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of cosmetic results. Methods: The BCCT.core software analyses digital photographs of the breasts and calculates objective parameters such as breast retraction assessment, lower breast contour, and color differences. These parameters are combined to provide an overall cosmetic score. Results: The software was tested on a series of patients and showed good correlation with subjective evaluations by experts. It provides a standardized and reproducible method for cosmetic assessment. Conclusion: The BCCT.core software represents a valuable tool for objective evaluation of cosmetic outcomes after breast cancer conservative treatment, facilitating comparison between studies and improving clinical decision-making.

title: Aesthetic, quality-of-life, and clinical outcomes after inferior pedicle oncoplastic reduction mammoplasty
author: Xia, Thomas Y and Scomacao, Isis and Duraes, Eliana and Cakmakoglu, Cagri and Schwarz, Graham
abstract: Purpose Oncoplastic reduction mammoplasty (ORM) is a surgical technique that combines oncologic resection with breast reduction and mastopexy techniques to improve aesthetic and quality-of-life (QoL) outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate aesthetic, QoL, and clinical outcomes after inferior pedicle ORM. Methods A retrospective review was conducted of patients who underwent inferior pedicle ORM for breast cancer between 2010 and 2020. Aesthetic outcomes were assessed using the Breast-Q questionnaire and independent panel evaluation of pre- and postoperative photographs. QoL was measured using the Breast-Q and the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30). Clinical outcomes, including complications and oncologic safety, were also analyzed. Results Forty-five patients met inclusion criteria. The median follow-up was 36 months. Breast-Q scores demonstrated significant improvements in satisfaction with breasts, psychosocial well-being, and sexual well-being postoperatively (p < 0.05). Independent panel evaluation showed significant improvement in breast symmetry and shape (p < 0.01). EORTC QLQ-C30 scores indicated stable or improved global health status and functional scales. Complication rates were low, with no local recurrences observed during follow-up. Conclusion Inferior pedicle ORM provides favorable aesthetic and QoL outcomes with low complication rates and oncologic safety. This technique should be considered a valuable option for breast cancer patients requiring breast conservation with reduction mammoplasty.

title: Assessing patient-reported outcomes following orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty
author: Schwitzer, Jonathan A and Albino, Frank P and Mathis, Ryan K and Scott, Amie M and Gamble, Laurie and Baker, Stephen B
abstract: Background: Orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty are commonly performed to correct dentofacial deformities and improve facial aesthetics and function. Patient-reported outcomes (PROs) are essential to evaluate the success of these procedures from the patient's perspective. This study aimed to assess PROs following orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty using validated questionnaires.  Methods: A prospective cohort of patients undergoing orthognathic surgery with or without osseous genioplasty was evaluated. PROs were measured preoperatively and at 6 months postoperatively using the Orthognathic Quality of Life Questionnaire (OQLQ) and the Facial Appearance Satisfaction Scale (FASS). Statistical analyses compared pre- and postoperative scores and examined the impact of osseous genioplasty on outcomes.  Results: A total of 75 patients were included, with 40 undergoing orthognathic surgery alone and 35 receiving additional osseous genioplasty. Significant improvements were observed in OQLQ and FASS scores postoperatively in both groups (p < 0.001). Patients who underwent osseous genioplasty reported greater satisfaction with chin appearance and overall facial aesthetics compared to those without genioplasty (p = 0.02). Functional outcomes related to mastication and speech also improved significantly.  Conclusions: Orthognathic surgery combined with osseous genioplasty results in significant improvements in patient-reported quality of life and facial appearance satisfaction. Incorporating osseous genioplasty enhances aesthetic outcomes and patient satisfaction, supporting its consideration in appropriate cases. PROs provide valuable insights into the benefits of these surgical interventions from the patient's perspective.

title: Evaluation of the effects of silk and polyethylene terephthalate sutures on postoperative complications in impacted lower third molar surgery
author: Dilan O.Z.; Levent C.; Volkan K.; Mehmet G.; Abdurrahman G.; Mohammad A.; Anıl Ö.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of silk and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) sutures on postoperative complications in impacted lower third molar surgery. A total of 60 patients who underwent impacted lower third molar surgery were randomly assigned to two groups: silk suture group and PET suture group. Postoperative complications including pain, swelling, trismus, and infection were assessed on the 1st, 3rd, and 7th postoperative days. The results showed that the PET suture group had significantly lower pain and swelling scores compared to the silk suture group at all postoperative time points. Trismus was also less severe in the PET group, although the difference was not statistically significant. No infections were observed in either group. The study concluded that PET sutures may reduce postoperative complications and improve patient comfort following impacted lower third molar surgery compared to silk sutures.

title: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models
author: Ho, Jonathan and Jain, Ajay and Abbeel, Pieter
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems
abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) are a class of latent variable models inspired by non-equilibrium thermodynamics, which have recently been shown to generate high-quality images. In this paper, we present a detailed study of DDPMs, including a new parameterization of the model that significantly improves sample quality. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the model's training objective and sampling procedure, showing that the model can be interpreted as a variational autoencoder with a particular choice of approximate posterior. Our experiments demonstrate that DDPMs achieve state-of-the-art results on several image generation benchmarks, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet, and produce samples with high fidelity and diversity.

title: Fronto-orbital advancement with patient-specific 3D-printed implants and robot-guided laser osteotomy: an in vitro accuracy assessment
author: Maintz M.; Desan N.; Sharma N.; Beinemann J.; Beyer M.; Seiler D.; Honigmann P.; Soleman J.; Guzman R.; Cattin P.C.; Thieringer F.M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Fronto-orbital advancement (FOA) is a complex surgical procedure for the treatment of craniosynostosis. The use of patient-specific implants (PSI) and robot-guided laser osteotomy (RGL) may improve the accuracy and safety of the procedure. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of FOA using PSI and RGL in an in vitro setting. Methods A total of 10 FOA procedures were performed on 3D-printed skull models. PSI were designed based on preoperative CT scans and fabricated using 3D printing. RGL was used to perform osteotomies according to the surgical plan. The accuracy of the osteotomies and implant fit was evaluated by comparing postoperative CT scans with the preoperative plan using 3D analysis software. Results The mean deviation between planned and executed osteotomies was 0.45 ± 0.12 mm, indicating high precision of the RGL. The PSI fit accurately on the osteotomized models with a mean gap of 0.38 ± 0.10 mm. No significant discrepancies were observed between the planned and actual implant positions. Conclusion The combination of PSI and RGL enables highly accurate FOA procedures in vitro. This approach has the potential to enhance surgical precision and outcomes in craniosynostosis treatment. Further clinical studies are warranted to validate these findings in vivo.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on surgical precision and implant fit, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, which is the main area of interest.
