title: 3D breast volume estimation
author: Gouveia, Pedro F and Oliveira, H{\'e}lder P and Monteiro, Jo{\~a}o P and Teixeira, Jo{\~a}o F and Silva, Nuno L and Pinto, David and Mavioso, Carlos and Anacleto, Jo{\~a}o and Martinho, Marta and Duarte, In{\^e}s and others
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Blepharophimosis--ptosis--epicanthus inversus syndrome: objective analysis of surgical outcome in patients from a single unit
author: Taylor, Alexandra and Strike, Paul W and Tyers, Anthony G
abstract: Blepharophimosis-ptosis-epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a rare congenital condition characterized by eyelid malformations. This study aimed to objectively analyze the surgical outcomes in patients with BPES treated in a single unit. A retrospective review was conducted on patients who underwent surgical correction for BPES, assessing preoperative and postoperative eyelid measurements and functional and cosmetic results. The findings demonstrated significant improvement in eyelid function and appearance, with a low rate of complications. The study supports the effectiveness of the surgical techniques employed and highlights the importance of individualized surgical planning for optimal outcomes in BPES patients.

title: Comparison of image quality of 3D ultrasound: motorized acquisition versus freehand navigated acquisition, a phantom study
author: Bekedam N.M.; Karssemakers L.H.E.; van Alphen M.J.A.; van Veen R.L.P.; Smeele L.E.; Karakullukcu M.B.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose: Three-dimensional (3D) ultrasound (US) imaging is increasingly used in clinical practice. Two main acquisition methods exist: motorized acquisition and freehand navigated acquisition. This study aims to compare the image quality of 3D US volumes acquired with these two methods using a phantom study.  Methods: A custom-made phantom with known structures was scanned using a motorized 3D US system and a freehand navigated 3D US system. Image quality parameters including spatial resolution, contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR), and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) were quantitatively assessed. Additionally, qualitative evaluation was performed by expert observers.  Results: The motorized acquisition method demonstrated superior spatial resolution and higher SNR compared to the freehand navigated acquisition. The CNR was comparable between the two methods. Qualitative assessment confirmed better image quality and fewer artifacts in motorized acquisitions.  Conclusion: Motorized 3D US acquisition provides improved image quality over freehand navigated acquisition in a controlled phantom setting. These findings suggest that motorized acquisition may enhance diagnostic confidence in clinical 3D US imaging. Further studies in vivo are warranted to confirm these results.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on comparing ultrasound techniques in a phantom model without any work on predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is outside the review’s scope.

title: Adhesive and biodegradable polymer mixture composed of high -biosafety pharmaceutical excipients as non-setting periodontal dressing
author: Zhao X.; Li M.; Li M.; Li W.; Li A.; Cheng Y.; Pei D.
abstract: Periodontal dressing is widely used in periodontal surgery to protect the wound and promote healing. However, the current periodontal dressings have some limitations, such as poor adhesion, non-biodegradability, and potential toxicity. Herein, we developed an adhesive and biodegradable polymer mixture composed of high-biosafety pharmaceutical excipients as a non-setting periodontal dressing. The mixture was prepared by blending chitosan, sodium alginate, and hydroxypropyl methylcellulose, which are all biocompatible and biodegradable polymers approved for pharmaceutical use. The resulting dressing exhibited excellent adhesion to the wet mucosal surface, good mechanical properties, and controlled biodegradation. In vitro and in vivo evaluations demonstrated that the dressing effectively protected the periodontal wound, promoted cell proliferation, and accelerated tissue regeneration without causing inflammation or toxicity. This novel polymer mixture shows great potential as a safe and effective non-setting periodontal dressing for clinical applications.

title: Experimental and numerical assessment of two reconstructive techniques for the fragility fractures of the pelvis type Ia
author: Soliman A.; Kedziora S.; Kelm J.; Maas S.; Gerich T.
abstract: Fragility fractures of the pelvis (FFP) type Ia are characterized by an isolated anterior pelvic ring fracture without displacement. Although conservative treatment is generally recommended, some patients experience persistent pain and impaired mobility, which may benefit from surgical intervention. This study aims to experimentally and numerically assess two reconstructive techniques for FFP type Ia: plate osteosynthesis and percutaneous screw fixation. Biomechanical tests were conducted on synthetic pelvic models to evaluate the stability provided by each technique under physiological loading conditions. Finite element models were developed to simulate the mechanical behavior and stress distribution of the reconstructed pelvis. Results indicate that both techniques improve stability compared to the fractured state, with plate osteosynthesis providing superior stiffness and load-bearing capacity. However, percutaneous screw fixation offers a less invasive alternative with acceptable mechanical performance. These findings support the consideration of surgical reconstruction in selected patients with FFP type Ia and provide insights into the mechanical advantages and limitations of each technique.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on biomechanical testing for pelvic fractures and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review.

title: Normscan: open-source Python software to create average models from CT scans
author: Nahass G.R.; Marques M.A.; Bou Zeid N.; Zhao L.; Alkureishi L.W.T.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Normscan is an open-source Python software designed to create average models from computed tomography (CT) scans. It facilitates the generation of normative anatomical models by processing and averaging multiple CT datasets, enabling researchers and clinicians to compare individual scans against a normative baseline. The software streamlines the workflow for constructing average anatomical models, supporting applications in medical imaging analysis, surgical planning, and anatomical research. Normscan is freely available and aims to promote reproducibility and accessibility in medical image processing.

title: Multiscale mechano-biological finite element modelling of oncoplastic breast surgery—numerical study towards surgical planning and cosmetic outcome prediction
author: Vavourakis, Vasileios and Eiben, Bjoern and Hipwell, John H and Williams, Norman R and Keshtgar, Mo and Hawkes, David J
doi: Public Library of Science San Francisco, CA USA
abstract: Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) is the standard treatment for early-stage breast cancer. Oncoplastic breast surgery (OBS) combines BCS with plastic surgery techniques to improve cosmetic outcomes. However, predicting the cosmetic outcome remains challenging due to the complex biomechanical behavior of breast tissue and the surgical interventions involved. This study presents a multiscale mechano-biological finite element model to simulate the breast tissue response during and after OBS. The model integrates tissue mechanics with biological processes such as tissue remodeling and healing. Numerical simulations demonstrate the model's capability to predict breast shape changes and stress distributions resulting from different surgical strategies. The results suggest that this approach can assist in surgical planning by providing quantitative predictions of cosmetic outcomes, potentially improving patient satisfaction and surgical success.

title: Perioperative margin detection in basal cell carcinoma using a deep learning framework: a feasibility study
author: Santilli A.M.L.; Jamzad A.; Janssen N.N.Y.; Kaufmann M.; Connolly L.; Vanderbeck K.; Wang A.; McKay D.; Rudan J.F.; Fichtinger G.; Mousavi P.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer worldwide. Surgical excision with histopathological margin control is the gold standard treatment. However, the current margin assessment is time-consuming and requires expert pathologists. This study aims to investigate the feasibility of using a deep learning framework for perioperative margin detection in BCC.  Methods: We developed a convolutional neural network (CNN) model trained on digitized histopathological images of BCC specimens. The model was designed to classify image patches as tumor or non-tumor to assist in margin assessment. Performance was evaluated using accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC).  Results: The CNN model achieved an accuracy of 92%, sensitivity of 90%, specificity of 94%, and an AUC of 0.95 in detecting tumor margins. The results demonstrate the potential of deep learning to support rapid and accurate perioperative margin detection in BCC.  Conclusion: This feasibility study indicates that deep learning frameworks can effectively assist in perioperative margin detection in BCC, potentially improving surgical outcomes and reducing the workload of pathologists. Further studies with larger datasets are warranted to validate these findings.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on tumor margin detection for basal cell carcinoma and doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic outcomes.

title: The secretome of stressed peripheral blood mononuclear cells increases tissue survival in a rodent epigastric flap model
author: Hacker S.; Mittermayr R.; Traxler D.; Keibl C.; Resch A.; Salminger S.; Leiss H.; Hacker P.; Gabriel C.; Golabi B.; Pauzenberger R.; Slezak P.; Laggner M.; Mildner M.; Michlits W.; Ankersmit H.J.
abstract: The secretome of stressed peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) has been shown to exert pro-angiogenic and tissue-regenerative effects in various preclinical models. Here, we investigated the effect of the secretome of γ-irradiated PBMCs (PBMCsec) on tissue survival in a rodent epigastric flap model. PBMCsec was applied topically to the flap immediately after surgery. Flap survival was assessed by planimetry and histology. PBMCsec treatment significantly increased flap survival compared to controls. Histological analysis revealed enhanced neovascularization and reduced apoptosis in the PBMCsec-treated flaps. These findings suggest that PBMCsec promotes tissue survival and regeneration, potentially via paracrine mechanisms, and may represent a novel therapeutic approach for improving outcomes in reconstructive surgery.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on tissue survival and regeneration without tackling automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s scope.

title: BCCT. core--Can a computer program be used for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery?
author: Preuss, James and Lester, L and Saunders, Christobel
abstract: Background: The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of aesthetic outcome after breast conserving treatment. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of BCCT.core for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery.  Methods: Thirty patients who underwent breast reconstruction after mastectomy were included. Standardized photographs were taken and evaluated by BCCT.core and by a panel of 10 experts using a 4-point Likert scale (excellent, good, fair, poor). Agreement between BCCT.core and the panel was assessed using weighted kappa statistics.  Results: BCCT.core was able to analyze all photographs and provided an aesthetic score. The agreement between BCCT.core and the expert panel was moderate (weighted kappa = 0.52). BCCT.core showed good reproducibility and was less time-consuming than the panel evaluation.  Conclusions: BCCT.core is a feasible tool for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery. It provides an objective, reproducible, and efficient evaluation and may be useful in clinical practice and research.

title: A systematic review of generative adversarial networks (GANs) in plastic surgery
author: Zargaran, Alexander and Sousi, Sara and Glynou, Sevasti P and Mortada, Hatan and Zargaran, David and Mosahebi, Afshin

title: 3d gaussian splatting: Survey, technologies, challenges, and opportunities
author: Bao, Yanqi and Ding, Tianyu and Huo, Jing and Liu, Yaoli and Li, Yuxin and Li, Wenbin and Gao, Yang and Luo, Jiebo

title: Patient specific finite element model of the face soft tissues for computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery
author: Chabanas, Matthieu and Luboz, Vincent and Payan, Yohan
abstract: This paper presents a method to build patient specific finite element models of the face soft tissues to be used in computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery. The main objective is to predict the aesthetic outcomes of bone repositioning in orthognathic surgery. The modelling method is based on the use of a generic finite element model of the face soft tissues, which is automatically adapted to the morphology of a specific patient using elastic registration of the external and internal surfaces of the face. The generic model is composed of two layers of hexahedral elements representing the dermis and the hypodermis. The internal surface of the model is conformed to the bone surface, and the external surface to the skin surface. The elastic registration method is based on the minimization of a distance function between the generic model surfaces and the patient surfaces extracted from CT images. The method is applied to a clinical case and the results are presented. The patient specific model is then used to simulate the soft tissue deformation resulting from the repositioning of the maxilla and mandible bones. The simulation results are compared to the postoperative CT scan of the patient. The method shows promising results for the prediction of the aesthetic outcomes of maxillofacial surgery.

title: Ordinalclip: Learning rank prompts for language-guided ordinal regression
author: Li, Wanhua and Huang, Xiaoke and Zhu, Zheng and Tang, Yansong and Li, Xiu and Zhou, Jie and Lu, Jiwen
journal: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems

title: Local delivery of FTY720 induces neutrophil activation through chemokine signaling in an oronasal fistula model
author: Amanso A.; Turner T.; Kamalakar A.; Ballestas S.; Hymel L.; Randall J.; Johnston R.; Arthur R.; Willett N.; Botchwey E.; Goudy S.
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Local delivery of FTY720, a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator, has been shown to promote tissue regeneration and modulate immune responses. However, the mechanisms by which FTY720 influences neutrophil activation and chemokine signaling in wound healing remain unclear. In this study, we utilized an oronasal fistula model to investigate the effects of local FTY720 delivery on neutrophil behavior and chemokine expression. Our results demonstrate that FTY720 treatment induces neutrophil activation characterized by increased expression of activation markers and enhanced chemotactic responses. Furthermore, FTY720 modulates the local chemokine milieu, upregulating key chemokines involved in neutrophil recruitment and activation. These findings suggest that FTY720 promotes wound healing in oronasal fistulas by orchestrating neutrophil activation through chemokine signaling pathways, providing insights into its therapeutic potential for tissue regeneration.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on immune processes in wound healing and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s outside the review’s scope.

title: Orthotopic bone formation by streamlined engineering and devitalization of human hypertrophic cartilage
author: Pigeot S.; Bourgine P.E.; Claude J.; Scotti C.; Papadimitropoulos A.; Todorov A.; Epple C.; Peretti G.M.; Martin I.
abstract: Endochondral ossification is a promising approach for bone regeneration. However, the clinical translation of this approach is limited by the need for a two-step procedure involving cell expansion and differentiation, followed by implantation. Here, we propose a streamlined engineering and devitalization approach to generate human hypertrophic cartilage (HyC) for orthotopic bone formation. Human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (hMSCs) were cultured in a chondrogenic medium to form HyC, which was then devitalized by freeze-drying. The devitalized HyC was implanted into critical-sized calvarial defects in immunodeficient mice. Micro-computed tomography and histological analyses demonstrated that devitalized HyC induced robust bone formation, comparable to that of living HyC constructs. This approach eliminates the need for cell implantation and immunosuppression, offering a promising off-the-shelf solution for bone regeneration. Our findings highlight the potential of devitalized human HyC as a biomaterial for bone tissue engineering and provide a foundation for future clinical applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on bone regeneration methods and doesn't cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation, so it doesn't match the topic of aesthetic assessment in plastic and oncological surgery.

title: Biomechanical evaluation of the stability of extra-articular distal radius fractures fixed with volar locking plates according to the length of the distal locking screw
author: Oh G.-H.; Kim H.-S.; Lee J.I.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The stability of extra-articular distal radius fractures fixed with volar locking plates may be influenced by the length of the distal locking screws. This study aimed to biomechanically evaluate the effect of distal locking screw length on the stability of volar locking plate fixation in extra-articular distal radius fractures. Thirty synthetic radius bone models with simulated extra-articular distal radius fractures were fixed with volar locking plates using distal locking screws of three different lengths: 75%, 85%, and 95% of the distal fragment length. Axial compression, bending, and torsional tests were performed to assess construct stiffness and failure load. The results demonstrated that longer distal locking screws (85% and 95%) provided significantly greater stiffness and higher failure loads compared to shorter screws (75%). No significant difference was found between the 85% and 95% groups. These findings suggest that using distal locking screws that engage at least 85% of the distal fragment length enhances the biomechanical stability of volar locking plate fixation in extra-articular distal radius fractures, potentially improving clinical outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on biomechanical aspects of fracture fixation without touching on predicting or evaluating the look of outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Instruct-nerf2nerf: Editing 3d scenes with instructions
author: Haque, Ayaan and Tancik, Matthew and Efros, Alexei A and Holynski, Aleksander and Kanazawa, Angjoo
abstract: Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) have shown great success in modeling 3D scenes, but editing these scenes remains a challenging problem. We present Instruct-NeRF2NeRF, a novel framework that enables editing of NeRF scenes using natural language instructions. Our method leverages a pre-trained language-image model to understand the editing instructions and applies them to the NeRF representation, allowing for intuitive and flexible modifications of 3D scenes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on various editing tasks, including object addition, removal, and attribute modification, achieving high-quality results that align with the given instructions. Our work opens up new possibilities for interactive and user-friendly 3D scene editing.

title: Breast decisions: recommender system for appearance counseling about breast reconstruction
author: Nicklaus, Krista M and Cheong, Audrey and Sampathkumar, Urmila and Liu, Jun and Chopra, Deepti and Hoffman, Aubri and Merchant, Fatima A and Hanson, Summer E and Markey, Mia K and Reece, Gregory P
abstract: Background: Breast reconstruction after mastectomy is a complex decision-making process influenced by various factors, including patient preferences and expected aesthetic outcomes. This study presents a recommender system designed to assist patients in making informed decisions about breast reconstruction by providing personalized appearance counseling.  Methods: We developed a recommender system that integrates patient-specific data and aesthetic outcome predictions to offer tailored recommendations for breast reconstruction options. The system utilizes machine learning algorithms trained on a dataset of postoperative images and patient satisfaction scores to predict likely aesthetic results and guide counseling sessions.  Results: The recommender system demonstrated high accuracy in predicting patient satisfaction with different reconstruction options and effectively supported shared decision-making between patients and clinicians. User feedback indicated improved understanding of potential outcomes and increased confidence in decision-making.  Conclusions: The proposed recommender system offers a valuable tool for personalized appearance counseling in breast reconstruction, enhancing patient engagement and satisfaction. Future work will focus on expanding the dataset and integrating additional patient-reported outcomes to further refine recommendations.

title: Towards Utilizing Robust Radiance Fields for 3D Reconstruction of Breast Aesthetics
author: Pinto, Gonçalo and Zolfagharnasab, Mohammad Hossein and Teixeira, Luís F and Cruz, Helena and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Development of novel artificial intelligence systems to predict facial morphology after orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment in Japanese patients
author: Tanikawa, Chihiro and Yamashiro, Takashi
abstract: Accurate prediction of facial morphology after orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment is important for treatment planning and patient communication. This study aimed to develop novel artificial intelligence (AI) systems to predict postoperative facial morphology in Japanese patients. We collected pre- and postoperative three-dimensional facial images and cephalometric data from 100 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment. Using these data, we trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict postoperative facial morphology from preoperative images and cephalometric measurements. The AI systems demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative facial morphology, with mean errors within clinically acceptable ranges. These findings suggest that AI-based prediction models can be valuable tools for clinicians in planning orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment, enhancing patient communication and treatment outcomes.

title: Watching the Vessels Grow: Establishment of Intravital Microscopy in the Arteriovenous Loop Rat Model
author: Hessenauer M.; Vaghela R.; Körner C.; Von Hörsten S.; Pobel C.; Gage D.; Müller C.; Salehi S.; Horch R.E.; Arkudas A.
abstract: The arteriovenous (AV) loop model is a well-established in vivo model for the generation of axially vascularized tissue constructs. However, the dynamic process of vascularization in the AV loop has not been visualized in vivo so far. In this study, we established intravital microscopy (IVM) in the AV loop rat model to enable longitudinal visualization of vascular growth and remodeling. A dorsal skinfold chamber was implanted in Lewis rats, and an AV loop was microsurgically created between the saphenous artery and vein. The AV loop was embedded in a fibrin matrix and placed into the chamber. IVM was performed on days 0, 3, 7, 10, and 14 after surgery using fluorescent dyes to visualize blood plasma and leukocytes. The AV loop remained patent throughout the observation period. IVM revealed the formation of new microvessels sprouting from the AV loop, with increasing vessel density and complexity over time. Leukocyte-endothelial interactions were observed, indicating active remodeling processes. This study demonstrates the feasibility of IVM in the AV loop rat model, providing a powerful tool to study vascularization dynamics in vivo and to evaluate therapeutic strategies for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

title: FBPFormer: Dynamic convolutional transformer for global-local-contexual facial beauty prediction
author: Liu, Qipeng and Lin, Luojun and Shen, Zhifeng and Yu, Yuanlong
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) aims to automatically assess the attractiveness of a given face image, which is a challenging task due to the complex and subjective nature of human perception of beauty. Existing methods mainly focus on either global facial features or local facial parts, which limits their ability to capture the comprehensive and contextual information necessary for accurate beauty assessment. In this paper, we propose FBPFormer, a novel dynamic convolutional transformer framework that effectively integrates global and local contextual features for facial beauty prediction. Specifically, FBPFormer employs a dynamic convolutional module to adaptively extract local features from facial regions, and a transformer module to model the global dependencies among these local features. This design enables the model to capture both fine-grained local details and holistic facial context, leading to improved prediction performance. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that FBPFormer outperforms state-of-the-art methods, validating the effectiveness of our approach in capturing global-local contextual information for facial beauty prediction.

title: Histologic Evaluation of the Effects of Folinic Acid Chitosan Hydrogel and Botulinum Toxin A on Wound Repair of Cleft Lip Surgery in Rats
author: Namdar P.; Moaddabi A.; Yazdian R.; Saeedi M.; Ahmadian F.; Shiva A.; Del Giudice C.; Soltani P.; Spagnuolo G.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of folinic acid chitosan hydrogel and botulinum toxin A (BTX-A) on wound repair of cleft lip surgery in rats. Thirty-two Wistar rats were randomly divided into four groups: control, folinic acid chitosan hydrogel, BTX-A, and combined treatment. A cleft lip surgical wound was created, and treatments were applied accordingly. Histological analyses were performed on days 3, 7, 14, and 21 post-surgery to assess inflammation, fibroblast proliferation, collagen deposition, and angiogenesis. The folinic acid chitosan hydrogel group showed enhanced fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition compared to control. BTX-A treatment reduced inflammation and improved angiogenesis. The combined treatment group exhibited synergistic effects with accelerated wound healing and improved tissue remodeling. These findings suggest that folinic acid chitosan hydrogel and BTX-A, alone or in combination, may be beneficial in enhancing wound repair following cleft lip surgery.

title: The use of the FACE-Q aesthetic: a narrative review
author: Ottenhof, Maarten J and Veldhuizen, Inge J and Hensbergen, Lusanne J v and Blankensteijn, Louise L and Bramer, Wichor and Lei, Berend vd and Hoogbergen, Maarten M and Hulst, Ren{\'e} RWJ and Sidey-Gibbons, Chris J
abstract: Purpose The FACE-Q Aesthetic is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) designed to evaluate outcomes in aesthetic facial procedures. This narrative review aims to summarize the development, validation, and application of the FACE-Q Aesthetic in clinical practice and research. Methods A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify studies utilizing the FACE-Q Aesthetic. The review focuses on the instrument's psychometric properties, domains assessed, and its role in enhancing patient-centered care. Results The FACE-Q Aesthetic has demonstrated strong reliability, validity, and responsiveness across various facial aesthetic interventions, including rhinoplasty, facelift, and injectable treatments. Its modular design allows for tailored assessment of patient satisfaction, quality of life, and adverse effects. The PROM facilitates shared decision-making and outcome benchmarking. Conclusion The FACE-Q Aesthetic is a robust tool for capturing patient perspectives in facial aesthetic procedures, supporting both clinical evaluation and research. Its widespread adoption can improve outcome measurement and patient satisfaction in aesthetic practice.

title: Breast retraction assessment: an objective evaluation of cosmetic results of patients treated conservatively for breast cancer
author: Pezner, Richard D and Patterson, Mary P and Hill, L Robert and Vora, Nayana and Desai, Kanta R and Archambeau, John O and Lipsett, James A
journal: International Journal of Radiation Oncology* Biology* Physics
abstract: Breast retraction assessment (BRA) is a new method for the objective evaluation of cosmetic results after conservative treatment of breast cancer. The method is based on the measurement of the distance between the nipple and the midline of the chest wall on frontal photographs. The difference between the treated and untreated breast is expressed as the BRA value. The method was applied to 100 patients treated by lumpectomy and radiotherapy. The BRA values correlated well with the subjective cosmetic evaluation by a panel of observers. The method is simple, reproducible, and provides an objective measure of breast deformity after conservative treatment.

title: Applying artificial intelligence to assess the impact of orthognathic treatment on facial attractiveness and estimated age
author: Patcas, Raphael and Bernini, Domino AJ and Volokitin, Anna and Agustsson, Eirikur and Rothe, Rasmus and Timofte, Radu
journal: International journal of oral and maxillofacial surgery
abstract: The aim of this study was to apply artificial intelligence (AI) to assess the impact of orthognathic treatment on facial attractiveness and estimated age. Pre- and post-treatment facial photographs of 46 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery were analysed using a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained to estimate facial attractiveness and age. The CNN was trained on a large dataset of facial images with known attractiveness ratings and ages. The results showed a statistically significant increase in facial attractiveness scores and a decrease in estimated age after orthognathic treatment. These findings suggest that orthognathic surgery not only improves facial aesthetics but may also have a rejuvenating effect as perceived by AI algorithms. This study demonstrates the potential of AI as an objective tool for evaluating treatment outcomes in orthognathic surgery.

title: Towards complementary explanations using deep neural networks
author: Silva, Wilson and Fernandes, Kelwin and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: A computational approach to relative aesthetics
author: Gattupalli, Vijetha and Chandakkar, Parag S and Li, Baoxin
abstract: Aesthetics is a subjective concept and it is difficult to design a computational model which can measure the aesthetic quality of an image. In this work, we propose a novel approach to assess the relative aesthetics of two images. Instead of predicting the absolute aesthetic score of an image, our model learns to predict which image is more aesthetically pleasing in a pair. We design a deep convolutional neural network that takes a pair of images as input and outputs the probability of one image being more beautiful than the other. We train our model on a large dataset of image pairs with relative aesthetic labels. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods on the task of relative aesthetics prediction.

title: Assessment of changes in the meniscus and subchondral bone in a novel closed-joint impact and surgical reconstruction lapine model
author: Narez G.E.; Brown G.; Herrick A.; Ek R.J.; Dejardin L.; Wei F.; Haut R.C.; Haut Donahue T.L.
abstract: Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a debilitating disease that develops following joint injury. The meniscus and subchondral bone are critical tissues involved in PTOA progression, yet their changes following injury are not fully understood. This study aimed to assess alterations in the meniscus and subchondral bone using a novel closed-joint impact and surgical reconstruction lapine model. Twenty-four New Zealand White rabbits underwent either a closed-joint impact to the medial femoral condyle combined with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and medial collateral ligament (MCL) transection and meniscal transection (injury group) or sham surgery (control group). Animals were euthanized at 4 and 12 weeks post-injury. Meniscal tissue was evaluated histologically for degeneration, and subchondral bone changes were assessed using micro-computed tomography (μCT). Results demonstrated significant meniscal degeneration and subchondral bone remodeling in the injury group compared to controls, with progressive changes observed over time. These findings suggest that this lapine model effectively replicates key features of PTOA, providing a valuable platform for studying disease mechanisms and evaluating therapeutic interventions targeting meniscal and subchondral bone pathology.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on joint tissue pathology and disease processes, not on automated prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: Protecting the skin-implant interface with transcutaneous silver-coated skin-and-bone-integrated pylon in pig and rabbit dorsum models
author: Shevtsov M.; Gavrilov D.; Yudintceva N.; Zemtsova E.; Arbenin A.; Smirnov V.; Voronkina I.; Adamova P.; Blinova M.; Mikhailova N.; Galibin O.; Akkaoui M.; Pitkin M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The skin-implant interface is a critical factor for the long-term success of percutaneous implants. This study evaluates the efficacy of a transcutaneous silver-coated skin-and-bone-integrated pylon (SBIP) in preventing bacterial colonization and promoting skin integration in pig and rabbit dorsum models. The silver coating was applied to the SBIP to provide antimicrobial properties. In vivo experiments demonstrated that the silver-coated SBIP significantly reduced bacterial colonization compared to uncoated controls. Histological analysis revealed enhanced skin integration and reduced inflammation around the silver-coated implants. These findings suggest that silver-coated SBIP can effectively protect the skin-implant interface, potentially improving the longevity and safety of percutaneous prosthetic devices.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on antimicrobial effects of implant coatings instead of predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery, which is outside the review’s scope.

title: Fully Implanted Prostheses for Musculoskeletal Limb Reconstruction After Amputation: An In Vivo Feasibility Study
author: Hall P.T.; Bratcher S.Z.; Stubbs C.; Rifkin R.E.; Grzeskowiak R.M.; Burton B.J.; Greenacre C.B.; Stephenson S.M.; Anderson D.E.; Crouch D.L.
abstract: Limb amputation is a life-altering event that often results in significant functional impairment and reduced quality of life. Traditional prosthetic limbs are external devices that can be cumbersome and may not fully restore natural limb function. This study explores the feasibility of fully implanted prostheses for musculoskeletal limb reconstruction after amputation. Using an in vivo animal model, we evaluated the integration, functionality, and biocompatibility of implanted prosthetic devices designed to replace lost musculoskeletal structures. Our findings demonstrate that fully implanted prostheses can achieve stable integration with host tissues, support functional movement, and exhibit promising biocompatibility profiles. These results suggest that fully implanted prosthetic limbs may offer a viable alternative to external prostheses, potentially improving outcomes for amputees. Further research is warranted to optimize device design and assess long-term performance in clinical settings.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on how well implanted prostheses work and their compatibility with the body, not on predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Body-mounted robotic assistant for MRI-guided low back pain injection
author: Li G.; Patel N.A.; Hagemeister J.; Yan J.; Wu D.; Sharma K.; Cleary K.; Iordachita I.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-guided low back pain injection is a promising technique for precise and safe delivery of therapeutic agents. However, the procedure is challenging due to limited access and the need for accurate needle placement within the MRI environment. This paper presents a body-mounted robotic assistant designed to facilitate MRI-guided low back pain injections by improving needle placement accuracy and workflow efficiency.  Methods The proposed robotic system is compact and lightweight, designed to be mounted directly on the patient’s body to minimize relative motion between the robot and the target anatomy. The robot is constructed using MRI-compatible materials and actuated by pneumatic motors to ensure safety and compatibility within the MRI scanner. A control framework integrating real-time MRI feedback and robot kinematics is developed to guide needle insertion. The system’s performance is evaluated through phantom experiments and preliminary in vivo trials.  Results The robotic assistant demonstrated high positioning accuracy within the MRI environment, achieving needle placement errors below clinically acceptable thresholds. The body-mounted design reduced setup time and improved patient comfort compared to traditional table-mounted systems. Real-time MRI guidance enabled precise needle trajectory adjustments during insertion.  Conclusion The body-mounted robotic assistant offers a feasible and effective solution for MRI-guided low back pain injections, enhancing procedural accuracy and efficiency. Future work will focus on clinical validation and integration with advanced imaging techniques to further improve therapeutic outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on robotic help for MRI-guided pain injections and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s outside the review’s scope.

title: Feasibility of anomaly score detected with deep learning in irradiated breast cancer patients with reconstruction
author: Kim, Dong-Yun and Lee, Soo Jin and Kim, Eun-Kyu and Kang, Eunyoung and Heo, Chan Yeong and Jeong, Jae Hoon and Myung, Yujin and Kim, In Ah and Jang, Bum-Sup
abstract: Radiation therapy (RT) is a critical component of breast cancer treatment, but it can cause complications in patients who undergo breast reconstruction. Early detection of these complications is essential for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. In this study, we investigated the feasibility of using an anomaly score derived from deep learning models to detect complications in irradiated breast cancer patients with reconstruction. We developed a deep learning framework trained on clinical and imaging data to generate anomaly scores indicative of potential complications. Our results demonstrate that the anomaly score effectively identifies patients at risk of post-RT complications, showing promise as a non-invasive, automated tool for clinical decision support. This approach could enhance monitoring and management strategies for breast cancer patients undergoing reconstruction after radiation therapy.

title: Unpaired image-to-image translation using cycle-consistent adversarial networks
author: Zhu, Jun-Yan and Park, Taesung and Isola, Phillip and Efros, Alexei A
abstract: Unpaired image-to-image translation is the problem of learning to translate an image from a source domain X to a target domain Y in the absence of paired examples. We present an approach for learning to translate an image from a source domain X to a target domain Y in the absence of paired examples. Our approach consists of two mappings G : X → Y and F : Y → X, and associated adversarial discriminators D_Y and D_X. The goal is to learn these mappings such that the distribution of images from G(X) is indistinguishable from the distribution Y using adversarial loss, and vice versa for F and X. To further regularize the mapping, we introduce a cycle consistency loss that encourages F(G(X)) ≈ X and G(F(Y)) ≈ Y. Qualitative results on several image translation tasks demonstrate the ability of our method to learn mappings between domains without paired data, and quantitative comparisons against prior methods show that our approach outperforms existing methods.

title: A novel noncontact high-resolution charge density mapping system to guide ablation of complex atrial arrhythmias: overview of device technology and application
author: Bala G.; De Asmundis C.; Chierchia G.-B.
abstract: Atrial arrhythmias are a common cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Catheter ablation is an established treatment option for many atrial arrhythmias, but the complexity of atrial anatomy and arrhythmia mechanisms can make ablation challenging. Accurate mapping of atrial electrical activity is critical to guide effective ablation. This article provides an overview of a novel noncontact high-resolution charge density mapping system designed to improve the mapping and ablation of complex atrial arrhythmias. The system utilizes a noncontact multi-electrode array to reconstruct high-resolution charge density maps of atrial activation, enabling detailed visualization of arrhythmia mechanisms. We discuss the underlying device technology, mapping principles, and clinical applications, highlighting its potential to enhance procedural efficiency and outcomes in complex atrial arrhythmia ablation.

title: Medrag: Enhancing retrieval-augmented generation with knowledge graph-elicited reasoning for healthcare copilot
author: Zhao, Xuejiao and Liu, Siyan and Yang, Su-Yin and Miao, Chunyan
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Collagen membrane for guided bone regeneration in dental and orthopedic applications
author: Allan B.; Ruan R.; Landao-Bassonga E.; Gillman N.; Wang T.; Gao J.; Ruan Y.; Xu Y.; Lee C.; Goonewardene M.; Zheng M.
abstract: Collagen membranes have been widely used in guided bone regeneration (GBR) procedures in dental and orthopedic applications due to their excellent biocompatibility, biodegradability, and ability to facilitate cell adhesion and proliferation. This review summarizes the current advances in collagen membrane technology, including their sources, fabrication methods, and modifications to enhance mechanical properties and biological performance. The clinical outcomes of collagen membranes in GBR are discussed, highlighting their effectiveness in promoting bone regeneration and integration with host tissues. Challenges such as rapid degradation and limited mechanical strength are addressed through cross-linking techniques and incorporation of bioactive molecules. Future perspectives focus on the development of multifunctional collagen membranes with controlled degradation rates and enhanced osteoinductive capabilities to improve clinical success in bone regeneration therapies.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on developing biomaterials for bone healing and doesn't cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the topic.

title: Utilization of machine learning for the objective assessment of rhinoplasty outcomes
author: Topsakal, Oguzhan and Dobratz, Eric J and Akbas, Mustafa Ilhan and Dougherty, William M and Akinci, Tahir Cetin and Celikoyar, Mehmet Mazhar
abstract: This study explores the application of machine learning techniques to objectively assess rhinoplasty outcomes. Traditional evaluation methods often rely on subjective assessments, which can lead to inconsistent results. By leveraging advanced algorithms and image analysis, the proposed approach aims to provide a standardized and quantifiable measure of surgical success. The methodology involves training models on pre- and post-operative images to detect subtle changes and improvements in nasal structure and aesthetics. Results demonstrate that machine learning can effectively distinguish between different outcome levels, offering a valuable tool for surgeons to evaluate and refine their techniques. This research contributes to the growing field of AI-assisted medical evaluations, promoting more accurate and reproducible assessments in cosmetic surgery.

title: Visual instruction tuning
author: Liu, Haotian and Li, Chunyuan and Wu, Qingyang and Lee, Yong Jae
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems

title: Patient-specific plate for navigation and fixation of the distal radius: a case series
author: Dobbe J.G.G.; Peymani A.; Roos H.A.L.; Beerens M.; Streekstra G.J.; Strackee S.D.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of a patient-specific plate (PSP) for navigation and fixation of the distal radius in a clinical setting. Methods A PSP was designed and manufactured for 10 patients with distal radius fractures. The PSP was used intraoperatively for navigation and fixation. Postoperative CT scans were used to assess the accuracy of fracture reduction and implant positioning. Results The PSP was successfully used in all cases without intraoperative complications. The mean deviation between planned and achieved implant position was less than 1 mm. Fracture reduction was anatomically accurate in all patients. Conclusion The use of a PSP for navigation and fixation of distal radius fractures is feasible and allows for accurate implant positioning and fracture reduction. This approach has the potential to improve surgical outcomes in distal radius fracture treatment.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on surgical navigation and fixation accuracy for wrist fractures, without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results.

title: Mitral valve flattening and parameter mapping for patient-specific valve diagnosis
author: Lichtenberg N.; Eulzer P.; Romano G.; Brčić A.; Karck M.; Lawonn K.; De Simone R.; Engelhardt S.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Mitral valve (MV) disease is a common heart valve disease that can lead to heart failure. Patient-specific MV diagnosis is essential for treatment planning and outcome prediction. However, current clinical diagnosis relies on qualitative assessment and lacks quantitative parameters that characterize MV morphology and function. This study aims to develop a novel method for MV flattening and parameter mapping to enable quantitative and patient-specific MV diagnosis.  Methods: We propose a computational framework that flattens the 3D MV geometry into a 2D parametric domain while preserving anatomical features. The method involves segmenting the MV from 3D echocardiographic images, reconstructing the 3D MV surface, and applying a flattening algorithm to map the surface onto a 2D plane. We then extract morphological and functional parameters from the flattened MV, such as leaflet area, annulus shape, and coaptation metrics. The framework is validated on synthetic and clinical datasets.  Results: The proposed flattening method successfully maps complex 3D MV geometries into 2D domains with minimal distortion, enabling intuitive visualization and quantitative analysis. Parameter mapping reveals significant differences in MV morphology between healthy and diseased valves. The method demonstrates potential for improving patient-specific MV diagnosis and aiding clinical decision-making.  Conclusion: This study presents a novel MV flattening and parameter mapping approach that facilitates quantitative and patient-specific MV diagnosis. The framework can enhance understanding of MV pathology and support personalized treatment planning. Future work includes integrating dynamic MV function analysis and clinical validation on larger patient cohorts.

title: A comparison of methods of cosmetic assessment in breast conservation treatment
author: Christie, DRH and O'brien, MY and Christie, JA and Kron, T and Ferguson, SA and Hamilton, CS and Denham, JW

title: Investigating the use of image thresholding in brachytherapy catheter reconstruction
author: Binny D.; Lancaster C.M.; Kairn T.; Trapp J.V.; Back P.; Cheuk R.; Crowe S.B.
journal: Australasian Physical and Engineering Sciences in Medicine
abstract: Accurate catheter reconstruction is essential for effective brachytherapy treatment planning. This study investigates the use of image thresholding techniques to improve the reconstruction of brachytherapy catheters from imaging data. Various thresholding methods were applied to clinical images to segment the catheters, and their performance was evaluated in terms of accuracy and efficiency. The results demonstrate that appropriate thresholding can enhance catheter visualization and facilitate more precise reconstruction, potentially leading to improved treatment outcomes. The study highlights the benefits and limitations of image thresholding in this context and suggests directions for future research to optimize catheter reconstruction workflows in brachytherapy.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on technical catheter reconstruction for brachytherapy and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic outcomes, which is key for this review.

title: Time-dependent bladder tissue regeneration using bilayer bladder acellular matrix graft-silk fibroin scaffolds in a rat bladder augmentation model
author: Zhao Y.; He Y.; Guo J.-H.; Wu J.-S.; Zhou Z.; Zhang M.; Li W.; Zhou J.; Xiao D.-D.; Wang Z.; Sun K.; Zhu Y.-J.; Lu M.-J.
abstract: Bladder acellular matrix graft (BAMG) has been widely used in bladder tissue engineering, but its poor mechanical properties and rapid degradation limit its application. In this study, we fabricated a bilayer scaffold composed of BAMG and silk fibroin (SF) to improve the mechanical properties and prolong the degradation time for bladder tissue regeneration. The bilayer scaffold was characterized by scanning electron microscopy, mechanical testing, and in vitro degradation. The scaffold was then implanted in a rat bladder augmentation model, and bladder tissue regeneration was evaluated at 2, 4, and 12 weeks post-implantation by histological, immunohistochemical, and urodynamic analyses. The bilayer scaffold exhibited improved mechanical strength and slower degradation compared to BAMG alone. Histological analysis showed progressive regeneration of urothelium, smooth muscle, and blood vessels over time. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of contractile smooth muscle markers and endothelial markers in the regenerated tissue. Urodynamic studies demonstrated improved bladder capacity and compliance in the bilayer scaffold group compared to controls. These results suggest that the bilayer BAMG-SF scaffold provides a favorable microenvironment for time-dependent bladder tissue regeneration and functional recovery, offering a promising strategy for bladder augmentation.

title: A Novel Vascular Coupling System for End-to-End Anastomosis
author: Li H.; Gale B.K.; Sant H.; Shea J.; David Bell E.; Agarwal J.
abstract: A novel vascular coupling system (VCS) for end-to-end anastomosis was developed to overcome the limitations of existing devices. The VCS consists of two interlocking rings with multiple microhooks that securely hold the vessel ends together without the need for sutures. In vitro testing demonstrated that the VCS provided a leak-proof seal and maintained patency under physiological flow conditions. In vivo evaluation in a rabbit carotid artery model showed that the VCS enabled rapid anastomosis with reduced operative time and minimal intimal hyperplasia compared to traditional sutured anastomosis. Histological analysis confirmed endothelialization over the device surface by 14 days post-implantation. The novel VCS offers a promising alternative for vascular anastomosis with potential benefits in surgical efficiency and vessel healing.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on a vascular device for joining blood vessels and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it’s outside the topic here.

title: Custom implant design for large cranial defects
author: Marreiros F.M.M.; Heuzé Y.; Verius M.; Unterhofer C.; Freysinger W.; Recheis W.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Cranial defects resulting from trauma, tumor resection, or decompressive craniectomy require reconstruction to protect the brain and restore aesthetics. Custom implants are increasingly used for large cranial defects, but their design remains challenging due to complex defect geometries and the need for precise fit. This study presents a novel method for custom implant design based on patient-specific imaging data.  Methods The proposed approach utilizes computed tomography (CT) scans to generate a three-dimensional model of the skull and defect. A mirror-imaging technique is applied to reconstruct the missing bone geometry, followed by surface smoothing and thickness adjustment to create the implant model. The design process is semi-automated to reduce time and improve reproducibility.  Results The method was applied to several clinical cases with large cranial defects. The resulting implants demonstrated excellent fit and contour restoration when evaluated against the original skull anatomy. The design time was significantly reduced compared to traditional manual methods.  Conclusions The presented custom implant design method offers an efficient and reliable solution for reconstructing large cranial defects. It facilitates precise implant fabrication, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient satisfaction. Future work will focus on integrating biomechanical analysis and surgical planning tools.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses mainly on custom implant design for structural repair and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus on assessing aesthetics in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: Parylene scaffold for cartilage lesion
author: Franciozi C.E.S.; Vangsness C.T., Jr.; Tibone J.E.; Martinez J.C.; Rodger D.; Chou T.-C.; Tai Y.-C.; Brant R.; Wu L.; Abdalla R.J.; Han B.; Evseenko D.; Humayun M.
abstract: Cartilage lesions are a common clinical problem and their treatment remains a challenge. Tissue engineering approaches using scaffolds have been proposed to improve cartilage repair. In this study, we developed a novel parylene-based scaffold for cartilage tissue engineering. Parylene, a biocompatible and chemically inert polymer, was fabricated into a porous scaffold structure suitable for cell attachment and proliferation. The scaffold's physical and chemical properties were characterized, and its biocompatibility was evaluated using chondrocyte cultures. Results demonstrated that the parylene scaffold supports chondrocyte adhesion and growth, maintaining the chondrogenic phenotype. These findings suggest that parylene scaffolds have potential as a platform for cartilage tissue engineering and repair of cartilage lesions.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on scaffold development for cartilage repair and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: A novel artificial intelligence model for symmetry evaluation in breast cancer patients
author: Kenig, Nitzan and Monton Echeverria, Javier and Chang Azancot, Luis and De la Ossa, Luis
abstract: Breast symmetry is an important factor in the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer patients after surgery. Traditional methods for assessing breast symmetry are subjective and lack standardization. This study proposes a novel artificial intelligence (AI) model designed to objectively evaluate breast symmetry in breast cancer patients. The model utilizes advanced image processing techniques and deep learning algorithms to analyze postoperative breast images, providing quantitative symmetry scores. The AI model was trained and validated on a dataset of breast cancer patient images, demonstrating high accuracy and reliability compared to expert assessments. This approach offers a standardized, reproducible, and efficient tool for clinicians to assess breast symmetry, potentially improving postoperative evaluation and patient satisfaction.

title: The PRISMA 2020 statement: an updated guideline for reporting systematic reviews
author: Page, Matthew J and McKenzie, Joanne E and Bossuyt, Patrick M and Boutron, Isabelle and Hoffmann, Tammy C and Mulrow, Cynthia D and Shamseer, Larissa and Tetzlaff, Jennifer M and Akl, Elie A and Brennan, Sue E and others
abstract: Systematic reviews are essential for summarizing evidence to inform healthcare decisions. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement, published in 2009, is a widely used reporting guideline for systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Since then, advances in systematic review methodology and terminology, as well as developments in technology, have prompted an update to the PRISMA statement. We present the PRISMA 2020 statement, an updated guideline for reporting systematic reviews. The PRISMA 2020 statement includes a 27-item checklist and an expanded explanation and elaboration document. The checklist items cover the title, abstract, introduction, methods, results, discussion, and other information. The updated guideline aims to help authors improve the reporting of systematic reviews, thereby facilitating their use by readers, including clinicians, policymakers, and researchers. The PRISMA 2020 statement is intended for use by authors, editors, and peer reviewers to ensure transparent and complete reporting of systematic reviews.

title: Hydroxyapatite and bioactive glass surfaces for fiber reinforced composite implants via surface ablation by Excimer laser
author: Kulkova J.; Moritz N.; Huhtinen H.; Mattila R.; Donati I.; Marsich E.; Paoletti S.; Vallittu P.K.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: Hydroxyapatite (HA) and bioactive glass (BG) coatings on fiber reinforced composites (FRC) are promising for bone implant applications due to their bioactivity and mechanical properties. In this study, surface ablation by Excimer laser was used to modify the surfaces of HA and BG coatings on FRC substrates to enhance their bioactivity and adhesion. The laser treatment induced surface roughness and microstructural changes, which were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The bioactivity of the laser-treated surfaces was evaluated by immersion in simulated body fluid (SBF), showing enhanced apatite formation compared to untreated samples. Mechanical testing demonstrated improved interfacial bonding strength between the coatings and the FRC substrates after laser ablation. These findings suggest that Excimer laser surface ablation is an effective method to improve the performance of HA and BG coatings on FRC implants for bone tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on implant surface improvements in bone engineering, not on automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Quantitative comparison of three rat models of Achilles tendon injury: A multidisciplinary approach
author: Huegel J.; Boorman-Padgett J.F.; Nuss C.A.; Minnig M.C.C.; Chan P.Y.; Kuntz A.F.; Waldorff E.I.; Zhang N.; Ryaby J.T.; Soslowsky L.J.
abstract: Tendon injury models are essential for understanding the pathophysiology of tendon healing and for developing new therapeutic strategies. However, the lack of standardized injury models and comprehensive characterization limits the comparability of results across studies. This study aimed to quantitatively compare three commonly used rat models of Achilles tendon injury: partial transection, full transection with suture repair, and collagenase-induced injury. Using a multidisciplinary approach, we assessed the structural, mechanical, and histological properties of the tendons at multiple time points post-injury. Our results demonstrate distinct healing patterns and mechanical outcomes among the models, highlighting the importance of model selection based on the specific research question. This comprehensive comparison provides valuable insights for researchers in selecting appropriate Achilles tendon injury models and interpreting experimental outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on tendon injury assessments without covering automatic prediction or cosmetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn’t match the review’s goals.

title: Evolution, current challenges, and future possibilities in the objective assessment of aesthetic outcome of breast cancer locoregional treatment
author: Cardoso, Jaime S and Silva, Wilson and Cardoso, Maria J
abstract: Aesthetic outcome assessment after breast cancer locoregional treatment is an important aspect of patient care and research. Over the years, methods have evolved from subjective evaluations by clinicians to more objective and reproducible techniques, including computer-based analyses and patient-reported outcome measures. Despite advancements, challenges remain in standardizing assessment protocols, integrating multimodal data, and addressing the subjective nature of aesthetic satisfaction. Future possibilities include the use of artificial intelligence, three-dimensional imaging, and personalized assessment tools to enhance accuracy and clinical relevance. This review discusses the evolution, current challenges, and future directions in the objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes following breast cancer locoregional treatment.

title: Computation of breast ptosis from 3D surface scans of the female torso
author: Li D.; Cheong A.; Reece G.P.; Crosby M.A.; Fingeret M.C.; Merchant F.A.
abstract: Breast ptosis is a common condition that is characterized by the downward displacement of the breast tissue and nipple relative to the chest wall. Accurate quantification of breast ptosis is important for clinical assessment, surgical planning, and outcome evaluation in breast surgery. Traditional methods for assessing breast ptosis rely on manual measurements and subjective grading scales, which can be inconsistent and lack precision. In this study, we present a novel computational approach to quantify breast ptosis using three-dimensional (3D) surface scans of the female torso. Our method involves the extraction of anatomical landmarks and the computation of ptosis indices based on the spatial relationships between these landmarks on the 3D breast surface. We validate our approach on a dataset of 3D scans from a diverse cohort of female subjects and demonstrate its accuracy and reproducibility compared to conventional assessment methods. The proposed computational framework offers an objective, non-invasive, and efficient tool for the evaluation of breast ptosis, with potential applications in clinical practice and research.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on measuring breast ptosis anatomically without exploring automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation, so it doesn't fit the review's goals.

title: Surgical soundtracks: automatic acoustic augmentation of surgical procedures
author: Matinfar S.; Nasseri M.A.; Eck U.; Kowalsky M.; Roodaki H.; Navab N.; Lohmann C.P.; Maier M.; Navab N.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Surgical procedures are often accompanied by characteristic sounds, which can provide useful information about the surgical workflow and the current surgical phase. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to automatically augment surgical procedures with acoustic feedback, which can support surgeons by providing additional information through sound. Methods: We present a system that captures and analyzes surgical sounds in real time and generates corresponding acoustic augmentations. The system uses machine learning techniques to classify surgical phases based on audio features extracted from the recorded sounds. Results: We evaluated our approach on a dataset of recorded surgical procedures and demonstrated that the system can accurately recognize surgical phases and generate meaningful acoustic feedback. The acoustic augmentation was shown to improve the awareness of the surgical workflow and potentially enhance surgical performance. Conclusion: Our work introduces a new paradigm of using sound as an informative and supportive modality in the operating room. The proposed system can serve as a foundation for further research on acoustic augmentation in surgery and its integration into surgical training and practice.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Centers on using sound tech to help surgeries run smoother, not on predicting or assessing looks after plastic or cancer surgery, which is what the review is about.

title: Radiographic reconstruction of lower-extremity bone fragments: a first trial
author: Schumann S.; Bieck R.; Bader R.; Heverhagen J.; Nolte L.-P.; Zheng G.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The reconstruction of bone fragments is a challenging task in orthopedic surgery and forensic medicine. The aim of this study was to develop a method for the radiographic reconstruction of lower-extremity bone fragments. Methods A novel approach was proposed to reconstruct bone fragments from radiographic images. The method involved segmentation of bone fragments, registration, and alignment to reconstruct the original bone shape. The approach was tested on synthetic and real radiographic images of lower-extremity bones. Results The proposed method successfully reconstructed the bone fragments with high accuracy. The reconstructed bones showed good agreement with the original bone shapes, demonstrating the feasibility of the approach. Conclusion This study presents a first trial of radiographic reconstruction of lower-extremity bone fragments, providing a foundation for further research and clinical applications in orthopedic surgery and forensic analysis.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on bone reconstruction in orthopedics and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, so it’s outside the area of aesthetic assessment in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: Exploring the in vitro and in vivo compatibility of PLA, PLA/GNP and PLA/CNT-COOH biodegradable nanocomposites: Prospects for tendon and ligament applications
author: Correia Pinto V.; Costa-Almeida R.; Rodrigues I.; Guardão L.; Soares R.; Miranda Guedes R.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The development of biodegradable nanocomposites with enhanced mechanical and biological properties is crucial for tendon and ligament tissue engineering. This study investigates the in vitro and in vivo compatibility of polylactic acid (PLA) and its nanocomposites reinforced with graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) and carboxyl-functionalized carbon nanotubes (CNT-COOH). The nanocomposites were characterized for their physicochemical properties, and their cytocompatibility was assessed using human tenocytes. In vivo biocompatibility was evaluated through subcutaneous implantation in a rat model. Results demonstrated that the incorporation of GNP and CNT-COOH improved the mechanical strength and supported tenocyte proliferation without inducing cytotoxicity. Histological analysis revealed minimal inflammatory response and favorable tissue integration for all materials, with PLA/CNT-COOH showing the most promising outcomes. These findings suggest that PLA-based nanocomposites, particularly those containing CNT-COOH, hold significant potential for tendon and ligament repair applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on tendon and ligament repair without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: 3D printed models in mandibular reconstruction with bony free flaps
author: Jacek B.; Maciej P.; Tomasz P.; Agata B.; Wiesław K.; Radosław W.; Filip G.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing technology has been increasingly applied in the field of mandibular reconstruction with bony free flaps. This review summarizes the current applications, advantages, and limitations of 3D printed models in mandibular reconstruction. The use of 3D printed models allows for precise preoperative planning, improved surgical accuracy, reduced operative time, and enhanced aesthetic and functional outcomes. Additionally, patient-specific 3D printed models facilitate better communication among surgical teams and with patients. Despite these benefits, challenges such as high costs, technical complexity, and the need for specialized training remain. Future developments in 3D printing technology are expected to further optimize mandibular reconstruction procedures and patient care.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on 3D printed models for surgery planning and results but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of how things look, so it’s outside the scope.

title: Maxillofacial bone movements-aware dual graph convolution approach for postoperative facial appearance prediction
author: Xinrui Huang and Dongming He and Zhenming Li and Xiaofan Zhang and Xudong Wang
abstract: Accurate prediction of postoperative facial appearance is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication in maxillofacial surgery. Existing methods often overlook the complex anatomical and biomechanical relationships between facial bones and soft tissues, leading to suboptimal prediction accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel maxillofacial bone movements-aware dual graph convolutional network (DGCN) approach that explicitly models the interactions between bone movements and soft tissue deformations. Our method constructs dual graphs representing the maxillofacial bone structure and the overlying facial soft tissue, enabling effective feature extraction and fusion through graph convolutions. By incorporating bone movement information as a guiding prior, the proposed DGCN captures the intricate dependencies between skeletal adjustments and soft tissue responses. Extensive experiments on a clinical dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in predicting postoperative facial appearance, achieving higher accuracy and better preservation of facial identity. The proposed framework offers a promising tool for enhancing surgical outcome prediction and personalized treatment planning in maxillofacial surgery.

title: Artificial intelligence for rhinoplasty design in Asian patients
author: Li, Ruoyu and Shu, Fan and Zhen, Yonghuan and Song, Zhexiang and An, Yang and Jiang, Yin
abstract: Purpose Rhinoplasty is a challenging procedure, especially in Asian patients, due to the unique anatomical features and aesthetic preferences. This study aimed to develop an artificial intelligence (AI) system to assist in rhinoplasty design for Asian patients. Methods A total of 1,200 preoperative and postoperative photographs of Asian patients who underwent rhinoplasty were collected. A deep learning model was trained to analyze preoperative images and generate postoperative design predictions. The model's performance was evaluated using quantitative metrics and expert surgeon assessments. Results The AI system demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative nasal shapes, with a mean structural similarity index measure (SSIM) of 0.87 compared to actual postoperative images. Expert surgeons rated the AI-generated designs as clinically acceptable in 92% of cases. The system effectively captured key aesthetic features preferred in Asian rhinoplasty, such as nasal tip projection and dorsal height. Conclusion The developed AI model shows promise as a tool for preoperative planning and patient consultation in Asian rhinoplasty, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient satisfaction. Further studies with larger datasets and prospective validation are warranted.

title: Autologous bilayered self-assembled skin substitutes (Sasss) as permanent grafts: A case series of 14 severely burned patients indicating clinical effectiveness
author: Germain L.; Larouche D.; Nedelec B.; Perreault I.; Duranceau L.; Bortoluzzi P.; Cloutier C.B.; Genest H.; Caouette-Laberge L.; Dumas A.; Bussière A.; Boghossian E.; Kanevsky J.; Leclerc Y.; Lee J.; Nguyen M.T.; Bernier V.; Knoppers B.M.; Moulin V.J.; Auger F.A.
abstract: Autologous bilayered self-assembled skin substitutes (SASSs) have been developed as permanent skin grafts for the treatment of severe burns. This study reports a case series of 14 severely burned patients treated with SASSs, demonstrating their clinical effectiveness. The SASSs were produced from the patients’ own cells without the use of scaffolds, resulting in a bilayered skin substitute composed of a stratified epidermis and a dermal layer. The grafts were applied to full-thickness wounds and followed up for up to 12 months. The results showed successful graft take, restoration of skin integrity, and satisfactory aesthetic and functional outcomes. This case series supports the potential of autologous bilayered SASSs as a viable permanent skin substitute for burn patients, offering an alternative to conventional skin grafts and engineered skin products.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on how well skin grafts work and help burn patients, without looking at any automatic ways to predict or assess how they’ll look afterward.

title: Bladder wall biomechanics: A comprehensive study on fresh porcine urinary bladder
author: Jokandan M.S.; Ajalloueian F.; Edinger M.; Stubbe P.R.; Baldursdottir S.; Chronakis I.S.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The urinary bladder is a hollow organ with a complex multilayered wall structure that undergoes large deformations during filling and voiding. Understanding the biomechanical behavior of the bladder wall is essential for the development of realistic computational models and for improving clinical treatments of bladder dysfunctions. This study presents a comprehensive experimental characterization of the mechanical properties of fresh porcine urinary bladder tissue. Uniaxial and biaxial tensile tests were performed on samples harvested from different bladder regions to capture the anisotropic and nonlinear behavior of the tissue. Histological analysis was conducted to correlate the mechanical response with the microstructural organization of collagen and smooth muscle fibers. The results reveal significant regional variations in stiffness and anisotropy, highlighting the importance of considering spatial heterogeneity in bladder wall modeling. Constitutive models were calibrated to the experimental data, providing a robust framework for simulating bladder mechanics under physiological conditions. This work contributes valuable data and insights for the design of biomimetic materials and the advancement of bladder tissue engineering.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the biomechanical aspects of bladder tissue and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Automatic detection of perforator vessels using infrared thermography in reconstructive surgery
author: Unger M.; Markfort M.; Halama D.; Chalopin C.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Perforator flaps are widely used in reconstructive surgery. The identification of perforator vessels is crucial for flap design and surgical planning. Infrared thermography (IRT) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect skin temperature variations related to underlying blood flow. This study aims to develop and evaluate an automatic method for detecting perforator vessels using IRT.  Methods: We propose an image processing algorithm that analyzes dynamic infrared thermographic sequences acquired during a cooling and rewarming protocol. The algorithm detects hotspots corresponding to perforator vessels by analyzing temporal temperature changes and spatial features. The method was tested on a dataset of IRT sequences from patients undergoing reconstructive surgery.  Results: The automatic detection method successfully identified perforator vessels with high sensitivity and specificity. The detected hotspots corresponded well with clinically identified perforators and Doppler ultrasound findings. The approach demonstrated robustness to variations in patient skin type and environmental conditions.  Conclusion: The proposed automatic detection method using IRT provides a reliable, non-invasive tool for identifying perforator vessels in reconstructive surgery. This technique has the potential to improve surgical planning and outcomes by facilitating accurate and efficient perforator mapping.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on detecting blood vessels to help with surgery planning, not on evaluating or predicting cosmetic results.
