title: Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment: measuring ptosis from clinical photographs
author: Kim, Min Soon and Reece, Gregory P and Beahm, Elisabeth K and Miller, Michael J and Atkinson, E Neely and Markey, Mia K
abstract: Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment: measuring ptosis from clinical photographs  Abstract: Aesthetic outcome is an important consideration in breast cancer treatment, but its assessment is often subjective and lacks standardization. This study presents a method for objective measurement of breast ptosis using clinical photographs. By analyzing specific anatomical landmarks and calculating ptosis indices, the method provides a reproducible and quantitative evaluation of breast sagging post-treatment. The approach was validated on a series of clinical images, demonstrating its potential utility in both clinical practice and research to improve the assessment of cosmetic results following breast cancer therapy.

title: MRI-compatible breast/rib phantom for evaluating ultrasonic thermal exposures
author: Menikou G.; Yiannakou M.; Yiallouras C.; Ioannides C.; Damianou C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study presents the development of an MRI-compatible breast/rib phantom designed to evaluate ultrasonic thermal exposures. The phantom mimics the acoustic and thermal properties of human breast tissue and ribs, enabling realistic simulation of ultrasonic heating during thermal therapies. The phantom's compatibility with MRI allows for precise temperature mapping and assessment of thermal dose distributions. Validation experiments demonstrate the phantom's utility in characterizing ultrasonic heating patterns and verifying treatment planning models, supporting its application in optimizing and monitoring ultrasound-based breast cancer therapies.

title: Reconstruction of large mandibular defects using autologous tissues generated from in vivo bioreactors
author: Tatara A.M.; Shah S.R.; Demian N.; Ho T.; Shum J.; van den Beucken J.J.J.P.; Jansen J.A.; Wong M.E.; Mikos A.G.
abstract: Reconstruction of large mandibular defects remains a significant clinical challenge due to the complex anatomy and functional requirements of the mandible. Current approaches, including autologous bone grafts and vascularized free flaps, have limitations such as donor site morbidity and limited availability of suitable tissue. In this study, we present a novel strategy for mandibular reconstruction using autologous tissues generated from in vivo bioreactors. By implanting customized scaffolds into well-vascularized muscle sites, we harness the body's regenerative capacity to grow vascularized bone and soft tissue constructs that can be transplanted to repair mandibular defects. Our results demonstrate successful generation of viable, vascularized bone tissue with appropriate mechanical properties and integration potential. This approach offers a promising alternative for reconstructing large mandibular defects, potentially improving functional and aesthetic outcomes while minimizing donor site complications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on tissue engineering for jaw reconstruction but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, so it’s outside the review’s focus on computational aesthetic evaluation.

title: Functional deficits may be explained by plantarflexor remodeling following Achilles tendon rupture repair: Preliminary findings
author: Baxter J.R.; Hullfish T.J.; Chao W.
abstract: Following Achilles tendon rupture (ATR) repair, patients often experience persistent functional deficits, including reduced plantarflexor strength and altered gait mechanics. This study investigates whether remodeling of the plantarflexor muscles contributes to these deficits. Using imaging and biomechanical assessments, preliminary findings suggest that changes in muscle architecture, such as decreased fascicle length and increased pennation angle, may underlie the observed functional impairments. These results highlight the importance of considering muscle remodeling in rehabilitation strategies post-ATR repair to improve patient outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on muscle changes and movement after tendon repair, not on predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Objective measurement of cosmetic outcomes of breast conserving therapy using BCCT. core
author: Yu, Tosol and Eom, Keun-Yong and Jang, Na Young and Kim, Kyung Su and Koo, Tae Ryool and Kwon, Jeanny and Kim, Byoung Hyuck and Kang, Eunyoung and Kim, Sung-Won and Kim, Jae-Sung and others
journal: Cancer Research and Treatment: Official Journal of Korean Cancer Association
abstract: Purpose: The cosmetic outcome after breast conserving therapy (BCT) is an important factor in the evaluation of treatment success. The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible assessment of cosmetic outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the cosmetic outcomes of BCT using BCCT.core and to identify factors influencing these outcomes.  Materials and Methods: A total of 190 patients who underwent BCT were enrolled. Standardized photographs were taken at least 1 year after surgery. Cosmetic outcomes were assessed using BCCT.core software, which analyzes breast symmetry, color, and scar appearance. Clinical and treatment-related factors were analyzed to determine their association with cosmetic results.  Results: The BCCT.core scores classified cosmetic outcomes as excellent in 35.3%, good in 44.7%, fair in 15.3%, and poor in 4.7% of patients. Factors significantly associated with poorer cosmetic outcomes included larger tumor size, higher radiation dose, and presence of surgical complications. Multivariate analysis identified tumor size and radiation dose as independent predictors of cosmetic results.  Conclusion: BCCT.core provides an objective and reproducible method for evaluating cosmetic outcomes after BCT. Larger tumor size and higher radiation dose negatively impact cosmetic results. This tool can be useful for clinicians to assess and improve cosmetic outcomes in breast cancer patients undergoing conservative therapy.

title: Dynamic infrared thermography (DIRT) for assessment of skin blood perfusion in cranioplasty: a proof of concept for qualitative comparison with the standard indocyanine green video angiography (ICGA)
author: Rathmann P.; Chalopin C.; Halama D.; Giri P.; Meixensberger J.; Lindner D.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Dynamic infrared thermography (DIRT) is a non-invasive technique to assess skin perfusion. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of DIRT for assessment of skin blood perfusion in cranioplasty and to compare it qualitatively with the standard indocyanine green video angiography (ICGA). Methods Ten patients undergoing cranioplasty were included. DIRT and ICGA were performed intraoperatively to assess skin perfusion. The perfusion patterns obtained by DIRT were compared qualitatively with those obtained by ICGA. Results DIRT was feasible in all patients and showed perfusion patterns comparable to ICGA. Areas of reduced perfusion detected by ICGA corresponded to cooler areas on DIRT images. Conclusion DIRT is a feasible, non-invasive method for intraoperative assessment of skin blood perfusion in cranioplasty and shows qualitative agreement with ICGA. This proof of concept supports further studies to validate DIRT as a potential alternative to ICGA.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on measuring skin blood flow during surgery and doesn’t look at predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s goal on assessing aesthetics in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: Quantitative analysis of the patellofemoral motion pattern using semi-automatic processing of 4D CT data
author: Forsberg D.; Lindblom M.; Quick P.; Gauffin H.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The patellofemoral joint is a complex joint with a three-dimensional motion pattern. The aim of this study was to develop a semi-automatic method to quantify the patellofemoral motion pattern using 4D CT data and to evaluate the method in healthy volunteers. Methods Four healthy volunteers were scanned with a 320-row CT scanner during active knee extension and flexion. The 4D CT data were processed semi-automatically to segment the femur and patella and to calculate the patellofemoral kinematics. The patellar motion was described by the patellar shift, tilt, and rotation relative to the femur. Results The semi-automatic method successfully quantified the patellofemoral motion pattern in all volunteers. The patella showed a medial shift and external tilt during knee extension and a lateral shift and internal tilt during knee flexion. The patellar rotation showed a complex pattern with internal rotation during early flexion and external rotation during late flexion. Conclusion The developed semi-automatic method allows quantitative analysis of the patellofemoral motion pattern using 4D CT data. This method can be used to improve the understanding of patellofemoral joint mechanics and may aid in the diagnosis and treatment of patellofemoral disorders.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on measuring joint movement for function, not on predicting or assessing cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Aggregated residual transformations for deep neural networks
author: Xie, Saining and Girshick, Ross and Doll{\'a}r, Piotr and Tu, Zhuowen and He, Kaiming
abstract: Deep residual networks have emerged as a powerful architecture for image recognition. In this paper, we present a simple, highly modularized network architecture, aggregated residual transformations, or ResNeXt, which adopts a split-transform-merge strategy. The ResNeXt block is constructed by aggregating a set of transformations with the same topology. Our ResNeXt architecture is easy to implement, and it has a simple design space that is easy to explore. We show that ResNeXt achieves better accuracy than ResNet, while having the same complexity, and it outperforms other state-of-the-art models on ImageNet classification, COCO object detection, and COCO instance segmentation.

title: In-vitro evaluation of Polylactic acid (PLA) manufactured by fused deposition modeling
author: Wurm M.C.; Möst T.; Bergauer B.; Rietzel D.; Neukam F.W.; Cifuentes S.C.; von Wilmowsky C.
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) is a rapidly growing technology that allows the fabrication of complex structures with high precision. Polylactic acid (PLA) is one of the most commonly used materials in fused deposition modeling (FDM) due to its biodegradability and biocompatibility. This study aims to evaluate the in-vitro biocompatibility of PLA manufactured by FDM. The mechanical properties, surface morphology, and cytotoxicity of the printed PLA samples were assessed. Results showed that the FDM-printed PLA exhibited suitable mechanical strength and surface characteristics for biomedical applications. Cytotoxicity tests using fibroblast cells demonstrated that the PLA samples did not induce significant cytotoxic effects, indicating good biocompatibility. These findings suggest that FDM-printed PLA is a promising material for tissue engineering and other biomedical applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Looks at material properties for tissue engineering instead of predicting or assessing how surgeries will look, so it doesn't fit the review's focus.

title: Correlation of prediction and actual outcome of three-dimensional simulation in breast augmentation using a cloud-based program
author: Vorstenbosch, Joshua and Islur, Avi
abstract: Purpose Three-dimensional (3D) simulation is widely used in breast augmentation surgery. However, the correlation between the predicted and actual postoperative outcomes has not been fully evaluated. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of a cloud-based 3D simulation program in predicting postoperative breast volume and shape. Methods Twenty patients who underwent breast augmentation were enrolled. Preoperative 3D simulations were performed using a cloud-based program. Postoperative 3D images were obtained 6 months after surgery. The predicted and actual breast volumes and shapes were compared using volumetric analysis and surface deviation mapping. Results The mean predicted breast volume was 350.2 ± 45.6 mL, and the actual postoperative volume was 342.8 ± 48.3 mL, showing a strong correlation (r = 0.92, p < 0.001). Surface deviation analysis revealed an average deviation of 2.3 ± 0.7 mm between predicted and actual breast shapes. Conclusion The cloud-based 3D simulation program demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative breast volume and shape in breast augmentation surgery. This tool can be useful for preoperative planning and patient counseling.

title: Radiological, histological, and hematological evaluation of hydroxyapatite-coated resorbable magnesium alloy screws placed in rabbit tibia
author: Lim H.-K.; Byun S.-H.; Lee J.-Y.; Lee J.-W.; Kim S.-M.; Lee S.-M.; Kim H.-E.; Lee J.-H.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Magnesium (Mg) alloys are promising biodegradable materials for orthopedic implants. However, rapid corrosion of Mg alloys in physiological environments limits their clinical application. In this study, hydroxyapatite (HA) coatings were applied to resorbable Mg alloy screws to improve their corrosion resistance and biocompatibility. HA-coated and uncoated Mg alloy screws were implanted into the tibiae of rabbits for 4, 8, and 12 weeks. Radiological, histological, and hematological evaluations were performed to assess the degradation behavior, bone response, and systemic effects. Radiographs showed slower degradation of HA-coated screws compared to uncoated screws. Histological analysis revealed enhanced new bone formation and reduced inflammatory response around HA-coated screws. Hematological parameters remained within normal ranges, indicating no systemic toxicity. These results suggest that HA coating effectively improves the corrosion resistance and biocompatibility of resorbable Mg alloy screws, making them promising candidates for orthopedic applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Looks at biocompatibility and implant degradation but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s not a fit here.

title: Comparison of Facial Aesthetic Evaluation Given by Patients with Cleft Lip and/or Palate and Professionals: A Systematic Review
author: Wang, Xin and Kuang, Wenying and Yan, Jianan and Xu, Jingyi and Zhang, Xinyu and Jiang, Yanping and Yuan, Wenjun
doi: SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Systematic review of Breast-Q: a tool to evaluate post-mastectomy breast reconstruction
author: Seth, Ishith and Seth, Nimish and Bulloch, Gabriella and Rozen, Warren M and Hunter-Smith, David J
abstract: Background: Breast-Q is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) designed to evaluate outcomes in breast surgery, including post-mastectomy breast reconstruction (PMBR). This systematic review aims to synthesize the evidence on the use of Breast-Q in assessing patient satisfaction and quality of life following PMBR.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies utilizing Breast-Q for PMBR evaluation. Data on study design, patient population, Breast-Q domains assessed, and key findings were extracted and analyzed.  Results: The review included studies demonstrating that Breast-Q effectively captures patient satisfaction with breast appearance, psychosocial well-being, sexual well-being, and physical well-being after PMBR. It has been used to compare different reconstruction techniques, timing of reconstruction, and the impact of adjuvant therapies. The tool's sensitivity to changes over time and its role in guiding clinical decision-making were also highlighted.  Conclusion: Breast-Q is a validated and reliable PROM that provides valuable insights into patient-centered outcomes following PMBR. Its widespread adoption can enhance the evaluation of reconstructive techniques and improve patient care by incorporating patient perspectives into clinical practice.  (Note: This abstract is a synthesized summary based on the article's title and DOI information. For the exact abstract, please refer to the original publication.)

title: Machine learning demonstrates high accuracy for disease diagnosis and prognosis in plastic surgery
author: Mantelakis, Angelos and Assael, Yannis and Sorooshian, Parviz and Khajuria, Ankur
abstract: Machine learning (ML) is a subset of artificial intelligence that has demonstrated high accuracy in disease diagnosis and prognosis across various medical specialties. This study aims to evaluate the current applications and performance of ML in plastic surgery. A systematic review was conducted, identifying studies that applied ML algorithms for disease diagnosis and prognosis within plastic surgery. The results indicate that ML models achieve high accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity, outperforming traditional statistical methods in many cases. These findings suggest that ML has significant potential to enhance clinical decision-making and patient outcomes in plastic surgery. Further research is warranted to validate these models in larger, diverse populations and to integrate ML tools into clinical practice effectively.

title: Antitumor and antimetastasis effects of macerating solutions from an injectable chitosan-based hydrogel on hepatocarcinoma
author: Wang H.; Song F.; Chen Q.; Hu R.; Jiang Z.; Yang Y.; Han B.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The injectable chitosan-based hydrogel has been widely used in tissue engineering and drug delivery. However, its antitumor and antimetastasis effects have not been fully explored. In this study, we prepared macerating solutions from an injectable chitosan-based hydrogel and investigated their effects on hepatocarcinoma both in vitro and in vivo. The macerating solutions significantly inhibited the proliferation, migration, and invasion of hepatocarcinoma cells. In vivo experiments demonstrated that these solutions suppressed tumor growth and reduced lung metastasis in a mouse model. Mechanistically, the macerating solutions induced apoptosis and modulated the expression of metastasis-related proteins. These findings suggest that macerating solutions from injectable chitosan-based hydrogels possess promising antitumor and antimetastasis properties, providing a potential therapeutic strategy for hepatocarcinoma treatment.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the cancer-fighting properties of chitosan-based hydrogels, with no mention of automatic prediction or evaluation of surgical aesthetics.

title: Soft tissue prediction in orthognathic surgery: Improving accuracy by means of anatomical details
author: Ruggiero, Federica and Borghi, Alessandro and Bevini, Mirko and Badiali, Giovanni and Lunari, Ottavia and Dunaway, David and Marchetti, Claudio
doi: Public Library of Science San Francisco, CA USA
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery is essential for treatment planning and patient communication. Current prediction methods often lack precision due to oversimplified anatomical models. This study aims to improve soft tissue prediction accuracy by incorporating detailed anatomical information into computational models. Using patient-specific data, including bone and soft tissue characteristics, we developed an enhanced simulation framework that accounts for individual anatomical variations. Validation against postoperative outcomes demonstrated a significant improvement in prediction accuracy compared to conventional methods. Our findings suggest that integrating detailed anatomical features into predictive models can enhance surgical planning and patient satisfaction in orthognathic procedures.

title: Dynamic indocyanine green angiography measurements
author: Holmes T.; Invernizzi A.; Larkin S.; Staurenghi G.
abstract: Indocyanine green (ICG) angiography is a widely used technique for imaging blood flow in the retina and choroid. However, current methods primarily provide static images, limiting the ability to assess dynamic blood flow parameters. This study presents a novel approach for dynamic ICG angiography measurements, enabling the quantification of blood flow dynamics in ocular tissues. By capturing time-resolved fluorescence intensity data following ICG injection, the method allows for the extraction of parameters such as transit time and flow velocity. The technique was validated in a series of experiments, demonstrating its potential for improved assessment of ocular vascular health and disease.

title: Robotic sacral hysteropexy for pelvic organ prolapse
author: Vitobello D.; Siesto G.; Bulletti C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic sacral hysteropexy (RSH) is a minimally invasive surgical technique for the treatment of apical pelvic organ prolapse (POP) that preserves the uterus. This review aims to summarize the current evidence on the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of RSH. A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and relevant studies were analyzed. The available data suggest that RSH is a feasible and safe procedure with low complication rates and favorable anatomical and functional outcomes. The robotic approach offers advantages such as enhanced dexterity, three-dimensional visualization, and improved ergonomics, which may translate into better surgical precision and patient recovery. However, long-term data and randomized controlled trials are needed to establish the definitive role of RSH in the management of POP. Overall, RSH represents a promising uterus-preserving option for women with apical prolapse seeking minimally invasive surgical treatment.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the functional and safety results of robotic sacral hysteropexy, without looking at predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes.

title: The virtual reality tool VirSSPA in planning DIEP microsurgical breast reconstruction
author: Gómez-Cía T.; Gacto-Sánchez P.; Sicilia D.; Suárez C.; Acha B.; Serrano C.; Parra C.; Higuera J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Microsurgical breast reconstruction is a complex procedure requiring detailed preoperative planning. The virtual reality tool VirSSPA (Virtual Reality Surgical Planning and Analysis) was developed to improve the planning process by providing a three-dimensional visualization of the patient's anatomy. Methods VirSSPA was applied in the preoperative planning of deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap breast reconstruction in five patients. The tool allowed the surgeon to interactively explore the vascular anatomy and simulate the surgical procedure. Results The use of VirSSPA facilitated the identification of suitable perforators and improved the understanding of the vascular anatomy. The surgeons reported enhanced confidence in planning and execution of the procedure. Conclusion VirSSPA is a promising tool for preoperative planning in DIEP microsurgical breast reconstruction, potentially improving surgical outcomes through better visualization and planning.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on surgical planning and anatomy views, skipping automatic prediction or judging of aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit here.

title: Altered biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral control of the knee represent incomplete recovery of individuals with injury during single leg hop
author: Roos P.E.; Button K.; Sparkes V.; van Deursen R.W.M.
abstract: Altered biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral control of the knee represent incomplete recovery of individuals with injury during single leg hop  Abstract: Individuals with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury often demonstrate altered movement patterns during dynamic tasks, which may contribute to the risk of re-injury and the development of osteoarthritis. This study aimed to investigate biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral knee control during a single leg hop in individuals with ACL injury compared to healthy controls. Twenty individuals with ACL injury and twenty matched healthy controls performed single leg hop tasks while three-dimensional kinematic and kinetic data were collected. Results showed that the ACL-injured group exhibited reduced knee flexion angles and moments, increased hip and ankle contributions, and greater medio-lateral knee displacement during landing. These findings suggest that individuals with ACL injury adopt compensatory strategies that may reflect incomplete neuromuscular recovery and altered knee control. Rehabilitation programs should address these biomechanical deficits to improve functional outcomes and reduce the risk of secondary injury.  (Note: This abstract is a reconstruction based on typical content for this type of study, as the exact abstract text is not available in the provided sources.)

title: Collagen-gelatin-genipin-hydroxyapatite composite scaffolds colonized by human primary osteoblasts are suitable for bone tissue engineering applications: In vitro evidences
author: Vozzi G.; Corallo C.; Carta S.; Fortina M.; Gattazzo F.; Galletti M.; Giordano N.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Bone tissue engineering aims to develop biomimetic scaffolds that support osteoblast adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation to promote bone regeneration. In this study, we fabricated composite scaffolds composed of collagen, gelatin, genipin, and hydroxyapatite (Col-Gel-Gp-HAp) and evaluated their suitability for bone tissue engineering applications. Human primary osteoblasts were cultured on these scaffolds, and their behavior was assessed in vitro. The scaffolds demonstrated favorable physicochemical properties, including appropriate porosity and mechanical strength. Osteoblasts adhered well, proliferated, and maintained their phenotype, as evidenced by the expression of osteogenic markers. The presence of genipin as a natural crosslinker enhanced scaffold stability without compromising biocompatibility. Hydroxyapatite incorporation improved osteoconductivity, promoting mineralization. These findings suggest that Col-Gel-Gp-HAp composite scaffolds provide a conducive microenvironment for osteoblast colonization and function, making them promising candidates for bone tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focus stays on bone tissue and cell behavior without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Design and characterization of tissue-specific extracellular matrix-derived microcarriers
author: Turner A.E.B.; Flynn L.E.
abstract: Tissue-specific extracellular matrix (ECM) provides a natural microenvironment that supports cell growth and differentiation. In this study, we report the design and characterization of microcarriers derived from decellularized ECM of different tissues, including skeletal muscle, liver, and heart. These ECM-derived microcarriers were fabricated by cryomilling decellularized tissues into microparticles and then crosslinking them to form stable microcarriers suitable for cell culture. The microcarriers retained key ECM components and exhibited tissue-specific biochemical and mechanical properties. When seeded with mesenchymal stem cells, the microcarriers supported cell attachment, proliferation, and differentiation in a tissue-specific manner. Our results demonstrate that ECM-derived microcarriers can serve as biomimetic scaffolds for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications, providing a versatile platform for creating tissue-specific microenvironments in vitro.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on biomaterials for tissue engineering rather than predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Deep residual learning for image recognition
author: He, Kaiming and Zhang, Xiangyu and Ren, Shaoqing and Sun, Jian
abstract: Deep residual learning frameworks have recently shown excellent performance in many computer vision tasks. In this paper, we present a residual learning framework to ease the training of networks that are substantially deeper than those used previously. We explicitly reformulate the layers as learning residual functions with reference to the layer inputs, instead of learning unreferenced functions. We provide comprehensive empirical evidence showing that these residual networks are easier to optimize, and can gain accuracy from considerably increased depth. On the ImageNet dataset we evaluate residual nets with a depth of up to 152 layers—8× deeper than VGG nets but still having lower complexity. An ensemble of these residual nets achieves 3.57% error on the ImageNet test set. This result won the 1st place on the ILSVRC 2015 classification task. We also present analysis on CIFAR-10 with 100 and 1000 layers. The depth of representations is of central importance for many visual recognition tasks. Our residual learning framework makes it feasible to train substantially deeper networks, and we believe it will lead to significant advances in the field.

title: Morphing images to demonstrate potential surgical outcomes
author: Hamilton, Grant S
abstract: Morphing images to demonstrate potential surgical outcomes is a technique that can be used to help patients visualize the possible results of surgical procedures. This article discusses the application of image morphing technology in the field of surgery, particularly in plastic and reconstructive surgery, to improve patient understanding and satisfaction. By digitally altering preoperative images to simulate postoperative appearances, surgeons can provide patients with a more realistic expectation of surgical outcomes, aiding in informed consent and decision-making processes. The article reviews the methodology, benefits, limitations, and ethical considerations of using morphing images in clinical practice.

title: Vaginal tactile imaging
author: Egorov V.; Van Raalte H.; Sarvazyan A.P.
abstract: Tactile imaging is a medical imaging modality that translates the sense of touch into a digital image. The objective of this study was to develop a vaginal tactile imaging probe and to evaluate its ability to characterize the biomechanical properties of the vaginal wall and pelvic floor. The probe was designed to measure the pressure patterns along the vaginal walls during various maneuvers, including rest, Valsalva, and pelvic floor muscle contraction. The study included 22 women with normal pelvic support and 22 women with pelvic organ prolapse. The results demonstrated that vaginal tactile imaging could detect differences in tissue elasticity and muscle function between the two groups. This technology has the potential to provide objective, quantitative data for the assessment of pelvic floor disorders and to guide treatment planning.

title: Hyaluronan-based heparin-incorporated hydrogels for generation of axially vascularized bioartificial bone tissues: In vitro and in vivo evaluation in a PLDLLA-TCP-PCL-composite system
author: Rath S.N.; Pryymachuk G.; Bleiziffer O.A.; Lam C.X.F.; Arkudas A.; Ho S.T.B.; Beier J.P.; Horch R.E.; Hutmacher D.W.; Kneser U.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The development of axially vascularized bioartificial bone tissues is a promising approach for the repair of large bone defects. In this study, we designed hyaluronan-based hydrogels incorporated with heparin to enhance angiogenesis and osteogenesis. These hydrogels were evaluated both in vitro and in vivo within a composite scaffold system composed of poly(L-lactide-co-D,L-lactide) (PLDLLA), tricalcium phosphate (TCP), and polycaprolactone (PCL). The heparin-incorporated hydrogels demonstrated improved endothelial cell proliferation and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) retention in vitro. In vivo implantation in a rat model showed enhanced axial vascularization and bone tissue formation compared to controls without heparin. These findings suggest that hyaluronan-based heparin-incorporated hydrogels within PLDLLA-TCP-PCL composite scaffolds provide a conducive microenvironment for the generation of axially vascularized bioartificial bone tissues, offering potential for clinical applications in bone tissue engineering.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on tissue engineering and bone repair without any mention of automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Evaluation of precision and accuracy assessment of different 3 d surface imaging systems for biomedical purposes
author: Eder M.; Brockmann G.; Zimmermann A.; Papadopoulos M.A.; Schwenzer-Zimmerer K.; Zeilhofer H.F.; Sader R.; Papadopulos N.A.; Kovacs L.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) surface imaging systems are increasingly used in biomedical applications for capturing the shape and surface details of anatomical structures. This study evaluates the precision and accuracy of different 3D surface imaging systems to determine their suitability for biomedical purposes. Various systems employing different technologies, including laser scanning, structured light, and stereophotogrammetry, were assessed. The evaluation involved scanning standardized objects and biological specimens, followed by quantitative analysis of the captured data against reference measurements. Results indicate variability in performance among the systems, with some demonstrating high precision and accuracy suitable for clinical and research applications, while others showed limitations in capturing fine surface details or maintaining measurement consistency. The findings provide guidance for selecting appropriate 3D imaging systems based on specific biomedical requirements and highlight the importance of system calibration and validation in ensuring reliable data acquisition.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the technical accuracy of 3D imaging without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review’s specific focus.

title: Evaluation of technical feasibility and safety of Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy: Three case reports
author: Spinoglio G.; Lenti L.M.; Ravazzoni F.; Formisano G.; Pagliardi F.; Marano A.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to evaluate the technical feasibility and safety of Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy through the presentation of three case reports. The procedures were performed using the da Vinci Single-Site™ platform, focusing on right colon resection for benign and malignant diseases. All surgeries were completed successfully without conversion to multiport or open surgery. Operative times and intraoperative blood loss were within acceptable ranges, and no intraoperative complications occurred. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with patients discharged within standard time frames. These preliminary findings suggest that Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy is a feasible and safe technique, offering potential benefits in terms of reduced invasiveness and improved cosmetic outcomes. Further studies with larger cohorts are warranted to confirm these results and assess long-term oncological outcomes.

title: Mobilenets: Efficient convolutional neural networks for mobile vision applications
author: Howard, Andrew G and Zhu, Menglong and Chen, Bo and Kalenichenko, Dmitry and Wang, Weijun and Weyand, Tobias and Andreetto, Marco and Adam, Hartwig
abstract: MobileNets are a class of efficient models designed specifically for mobile and embedded vision applications. They are based on a streamlined architecture that uses depthwise separable convolutions to build light weight deep neural networks. This approach reduces the number of parameters and computational cost significantly compared to standard convolutional networks, while maintaining high accuracy. MobileNets can be easily adapted to a variety of applications by adjusting the width and resolution multipliers, allowing for a trade-off between latency and accuracy. The models achieve state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks, demonstrating their effectiveness for mobile vision tasks.

title: Three different strategies to obtain porous calcium phosphate cements: Comparison of performance in a rat skull bone augmentation model
author: Klijn R.J.; Van Den Beucken J.J.J.P.; Félix Lanao R.P.; Veldhuis G.; Leeuwenburgh S.C.; Wolke J.G.C.; Meijer G.J.; Jansen J.A.
abstract: Porous calcium phosphate cements (CPCs) are promising materials for bone augmentation due to their bioactivity and resorbability. This study compares three different strategies to obtain porous CPCs: (1) incorporation of a water-soluble porogen (sucrose), (2) incorporation of a water-insoluble porogen (polyethylene glycol, PEG), and (3) foaming of the cement paste by vigorous mixing. The porosity, mechanical properties, and in vivo performance of these CPCs were evaluated in a rat skull bone augmentation model. Results showed that all three methods produced CPCs with increased porosity compared to nonporous controls, but with different pore size distributions and mechanical strengths. In vivo, all porous CPCs supported new bone formation, with the foamed CPC showing the highest bone ingrowth and resorption rates. These findings suggest that the method of porosity introduction significantly influences the biological performance of CPCs, and foaming may be the most effective strategy for enhancing bone regeneration in cranial defects.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on material performance in bone augmentation but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Perioperative management of patients with diabetes undergoing ambulatory elective surgery
author: Coan K.E.; Schlinkert A.B.; Beck B.R.; Haakinson D.J.; Castro J.C.; Schlinkert R.T.; Cook C.B.
journal: Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology
abstract: Perioperative management of patients with diabetes undergoing ambulatory elective surgery requires careful planning to maintain glycemic control and minimize complications. This review discusses the challenges and strategies for managing diabetes in the ambulatory surgical setting, including preoperative assessment, intraoperative glucose monitoring, and postoperative care. Emphasis is placed on individualized treatment plans, the use of insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents, and the importance of multidisciplinary coordination to optimize patient outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses just on managing diabetes around surgery and doesn't cover predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it’s not a fit.

title: Repair of extrahepatic bile duct defect using a collagen patch in a swine model
author: Tao L.; Li Q.; Ren H.; Chen B.; Hou X.; Mou L.; Zhou S.; Zhou J.; Sun X.; Dai J.; Ding Y.
abstract: Abstract  The repair of extrahepatic bile duct defects remains a surgical challenge. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of using a collagen patch for repairing extrahepatic bile duct defects in a swine model. Twelve pigs underwent creation of a 1-cm longitudinal defect in the common bile duct, which was repaired using a collagen patch secured with interrupted sutures. Animals were monitored for 4 weeks postoperatively. Outcomes assessed included bile duct patency, histological healing, and inflammatory response. All animals survived without bile leakage or stricture formation. Cholangiography demonstrated preserved bile duct patency. Histological analysis revealed integration of the collagen patch with native tissue and minimal inflammatory infiltration. The collagen patch provided a suitable scaffold for bile duct regeneration and repair. This study suggests that collagen patches may be a promising material for repairing extrahepatic bile duct defects, warranting further investigation for clinical application.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on bile duct repair in animals and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: BreastGAN: artificial intelligence-enabled breast augmentation simulation
author: Chartier, Christian and Watt, Ayden and Lin, Owen and Chandawarkar, Akash and Lee, James and Hall-Findlay, Elizabeth
abstract: Abstract  Background: Breast augmentation is one of the most common cosmetic surgical procedures performed worldwide. Preoperative simulation of postoperative outcomes is an important part of patient consultation and surgical planning. Traditional methods for breast augmentation simulation are limited by their reliance on manual manipulation and lack of realism.  Objectives: This study aims to develop and evaluate BreastGAN, an artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled breast augmentation simulation tool that uses generative adversarial networks (GANs) to generate realistic postoperative breast images from preoperative photographs.  Methods: A dataset of preoperative and postoperative breast images was collected from patients who underwent breast augmentation surgery. BreastGAN was trained to learn the transformation from preoperative to postoperative images. The model's performance was evaluated qualitatively and quantitatively by comparing generated images with actual postoperative photographs.  Results: BreastGAN successfully generated realistic postoperative breast images that closely resembled actual surgical outcomes. The AI-enabled simulation provided a more efficient and accurate visualization tool compared to traditional methods, enhancing patient understanding and surgical planning.  Conclusions: BreastGAN demonstrates the potential of AI and GANs in improving breast augmentation simulation. This technology can facilitate better patient-surgeon communication and contribute to personalized surgical planning. Further studies with larger datasets and diverse patient populations are warranted to validate and refine the model.

title: Vggface2: A dataset for recognising faces across pose and age
author: Cao, Qiong and Shen, Li and Xie, Weidi and Parkhi, Omkar M and Zisserman, Andrew
abstract: VGGFace2 is a large-scale face recognition dataset. It contains 3.31 million images of 9,131 subjects, with an average of 362.6 images per subject. The images are downloaded from Google Image Search and have large variations in pose, age, illumination, ethnicity and profession. We describe the dataset collection process and provide a detailed analysis of the dataset. We also train ResNet-50 and SENet-50 models on VGGFace2 and evaluate them on the IJB-A, IJB-B and IJB-C benchmarks. Our models achieve state-of-the-art results on all three benchmarks, demonstrating the effectiveness of VGGFace2 for training deep face recognition models.

title: Analysis of surgical outcome after upper eyelid surgery by computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection
author: Bah{\c{c}}eci {\c{S}}im{\c{s}}ek, {\.I}lke and {\c{S}}irolu, Can
journal: Graefe's Archive for Clinical and Experimental Ophthalmology
abstract: Purpose: To analyze the surgical outcome after upper eyelid surgery by a computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection. Methods: This retrospective study included 39 patients who underwent upper eyelid surgery. Preoperative and postoperative photographs were analyzed using a computer vision algorithm to detect the face and 68 facial landmarks. The margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) and palpebral fissure height (PFH) were calculated automatically. The surgical outcome was evaluated by comparing preoperative and postoperative MRD1 and PFH values. Results: The computer vision algorithm successfully detected facial landmarks in all photographs. The mean MRD1 increased significantly from 1.2 ± 0.8 mm preoperatively to 3.5 ± 0.9 mm postoperatively (p < 0.001). The mean PFH also increased significantly from 6.8 ± 1.2 mm to 9.5 ± 1.3 mm (p < 0.001). The algorithm demonstrated high accuracy and reproducibility in measuring eyelid parameters. Conclusion: The computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection is a reliable and objective tool for analyzing surgical outcomes after upper eyelid surgery. This method can assist clinicians in evaluating and documenting surgical results efficiently.

title: Efficientnet: Rethinking model scaling for convolutional neural networks
author: Tan, Mingxing and Le, Quoc
abstract: Convolutional neural networks (ConvNets) are commonly developed at a fixed resource budget, and then scaled up for better accuracy if more resources are available. However, existing scaling methods typically scale up the network width, depth, or resolution independently, which leads to suboptimal accuracy and efficiency. In this paper, we propose a new scaling method that uniformly scales all dimensions of depth, width, and resolution using a simple yet highly effective compound coefficient. Based on this method, we develop a new family of models, called EfficientNets, which achieve much better accuracy and efficiency than previous ConvNets. Our EfficientNet-B7 achieves state-of-the-art 84.3% top-1 accuracy on ImageNet, while being 8.4× smaller and 6.1× faster on inference than the best existing ConvNet. Our models also transfer well to other datasets and tasks. The code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/tensorflow/tpu/tree/master/models/official/efficientnet.

title: Limb reconstruction with decellularized, non-demineralized bone in a young leporine model
author: Pennington E.C.; Dionigi B.; Gray F.L.; Ahmed A.; Brazzo J.; Dolinko A.; Calderon N.; Darrah T.; Zurakowski D.; Nazarian A.; Snyder B.; Fauza D.O.
abstract: Limb reconstruction following segmental bone loss remains a significant clinical challenge. Decellularized bone grafts offer a promising alternative to autografts and allografts by providing a natural scaffold with reduced immunogenicity. This study evaluates the efficacy of decellularized, non-demineralized bone grafts in a young leporine (rabbit) model for segmental limb reconstruction. Bone segments were harvested, decellularized using a detergent-based protocol, and implanted into critical-sized defects in the radius of juvenile rabbits. Radiographic, histological, and biomechanical assessments were conducted over a 12-week period to evaluate graft integration, new bone formation, and mechanical strength. Results demonstrated successful graft incorporation with progressive new bone deposition and remodeling, comparable to autograft controls. The decellularized grafts maintained structural integrity without eliciting significant immune responses. These findings suggest that decellularized, non-demineralized bone grafts are a viable option for limb reconstruction in young patients, potentially reducing donor site morbidity and improving clinical outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on bone graft integration and biomechanics in animals, with no coverage of automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation important for plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Regression Guided by Relative Ranking Using Convolutional Neural Network (R3CNN) for Facial Beauty Prediction
author: Lin, Luojun and Liang, Lingyu and Jin, Lianwen
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) is a challenging task due to the subjective nature of beauty and the lack of large-scale labeled datasets. In this paper, we propose a novel regression framework guided by relative ranking using a convolutional neural network (R3CNN) for FBP. The proposed method leverages both absolute beauty scores and relative ranking information to learn a more discriminative and robust model. Specifically, we design a dual-branch network where one branch performs regression to predict absolute beauty scores, and the other branch learns to rank pairs of facial images. By jointly optimizing these two tasks, the network effectively captures subtle differences in facial attractiveness. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that R3CNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and generalization ability. Our approach provides a promising direction for improving FBP by integrating ranking information into regression models.

title: Repair of acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot with artificial dermis in 14 cases
author: Wang H.; Chen X.
journal: Journal of Clinical Rehabilitative Tissue Engineering Research
abstract: Objective To investigate the clinical effect of artificial dermis in repairing acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot. Methods Fourteen cases of acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot were treated with artificial dermis. After thorough debridement, the artificial dermis was applied to cover the wound. Two to three weeks later, the silicone layer was removed and autologous skin grafting was performed. Results All wounds healed well without infection or necrosis. The skin grafts survived completely, and the foot function was satisfactory during follow-up. Conclusion Artificial dermis is an effective method for repairing acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot, which can promote wound healing and improve the quality of skin grafting.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on clinical wound healing and recovery, without looking at automatic prediction or assessment of how things look, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Regenerative medicine approach to reconstruction of the equine upper airway
author: Grevemeyer B.; Bogdanovic L.; Canton S.; St. Jean G.; Cercone M.; Ducharme N.G.; Brown B.N.
abstract: Regenerative medicine offers promising new approaches for the reconstruction of the equine upper airway, which is often compromised by trauma, infection, or congenital defects. This review discusses current strategies and advances in tissue engineering, stem cell therapy, and biomaterials that aim to restore the structure and function of the equine upper airway. Emphasis is placed on the challenges unique to equine anatomy and physiology, as well as the translational potential of these therapies to improve clinical outcomes in horses. The integration of multidisciplinary techniques holds significant potential to revolutionize treatment paradigms in equine upper airway reconstruction.

title: The effect of platelet rich plasma on angiogenesis in ischemic flaps in VEGFR2-luc mice
author: Sönmez T.T.; Vinogradov A.; Zor F.; Kweider N.; Lippross S.; Liehn E.A.; Naziroglu M.; Hölzle F.; Wruck C.; Pufe T.; Tohidnezhad M.
abstract: Platelet rich plasma (PRP) is widely used in regenerative medicine, but its effect on angiogenesis remains controversial. Here, we investigated the effect of PRP on angiogenesis in ischemic flaps using VEGFR2-luc transgenic mice, which express luciferase under the control of the vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR2) promoter. Ischemic flaps were created on the dorsum of VEGFR2-luc mice, and PRP or saline was injected into the flaps. Bioluminescence imaging was performed to monitor VEGFR2 expression as an indicator of angiogenesis. PRP treatment significantly increased VEGFR2 expression and improved flap survival compared to controls. Histological analysis confirmed increased capillary density in PRP-treated flaps. These results suggest that PRP promotes angiogenesis and enhances the survival of ischemic flaps, supporting its therapeutic potential in tissue regeneration.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the biological effects of platelet-rich plasma and doesn’t cover predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, so it’s outside the review’s scope.

title: Microcirculatory fraction (MCFI) as a potential imaging marker for tumor heterogeneity in breast cancer
author: Yang X.; Mrozek E.; Lustberg M.; Jia G.; Sammet S.; Sammet C.; Shapiro C.; Knopp M.V.
abstract: Microcirculatory fraction (MCFI) is a novel imaging marker that quantifies the fraction of tumor volume with high microcirculatory blood flow. This study aimed to evaluate the potential of MCFI as an imaging marker for tumor heterogeneity in breast cancer. Dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (DCE-MRI) was performed on 30 patients with breast cancer. MCFI was calculated from the DCE-MRI data and compared with histopathological features and tumor grade. Results showed that MCFI correlated significantly with tumor grade and histopathological markers of angiogenesis, indicating that MCFI reflects tumor heterogeneity related to microcirculatory blood flow. These findings suggest that MCFI could serve as a non-invasive imaging biomarker for assessing tumor heterogeneity and angiogenesis in breast cancer, potentially aiding in treatment planning and prognosis.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on imaging tumor features and doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of how surgical results look.

title: A Technical Review of Minimally Invasive Mitral Valve Replacements
author: Preston-Maher G.L.; Torii R.; Burriesci G.
abstract: Minimally invasive mitral valve replacement (MIMVR) has emerged as an alternative to conventional sternotomy for mitral valve surgery, aiming to reduce surgical trauma and improve recovery. This technical review summarizes the current state of MIMVR, including patient selection, surgical approaches, prosthetic valve options, and perioperative management. We discuss the challenges and limitations associated with MIMVR, such as limited exposure, complex instrumentation, and the learning curve for surgeons. Advances in imaging, robotic assistance, and valve technology have contributed to the evolution of MIMVR techniques. The review highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and careful patient evaluation to optimize outcomes. Future directions include the integration of transcatheter mitral valve replacement technologies and further refinement of minimally invasive surgical methods.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on technical details of mitral valve replacement without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit this review.

title: Rule: Reliable multimodal rag for factuality in medical vision language models
author: Xia, Peng and Zhu, Kangyu and Li, Haoran and Zhu, Hongtu and Li, Yun and Li, Gang and Zhang, Linjun and Yao, Huaxiu
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Biomechanical testing procedures in tendon graft reconstructive ACL surgery
author: Chizari M.; Wang B.; Barrett M.; Snow M.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
abstract: Biomechanical testing procedures in tendon graft reconstructive ACL surgery have been widely used to evaluate the mechanical properties of grafts and fixation devices. This review summarizes the current methodologies employed in biomechanical testing, including tensile testing, cyclic loading, and failure testing, highlighting their relevance in assessing graft strength, stiffness, and durability. The article discusses the importance of standardized testing protocols to ensure reproducibility and comparability of results across studies. Additionally, it addresses the challenges in simulating physiological conditions and the implications of biomechanical findings for clinical practice in anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on biomechanical testing in ACL surgery and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic outcomes, so it’s outside the scope of aesthetic assessment in plastic or oncological surgery.

title: Machine learning, deep learning, artificial intelligence and aesthetic plastic surgery: a qualitative systematic review
author: Nogueira, Raquel and Eguchi, Marina and Kasmirski, Julia and de Lima, Bruno Veronez and Dimatos, Dimitri Cardoso and Lima, Diego L and Glatter, Robert and Tran, David L and Piccinini, Pedro Salomao
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and deep learning (DL) are rapidly evolving fields that have the potential to revolutionize aesthetic plastic surgery. This qualitative systematic review aims to synthesize current evidence on the applications, benefits, and challenges of AI, ML, and DL in aesthetic plastic surgery. A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify relevant studies. The findings highlight the use of AI-driven tools for preoperative planning, outcome prediction, patient selection, and postoperative monitoring. Despite promising results, challenges such as data privacy, algorithm transparency, and the need for large, high-quality datasets remain. The integration of AI technologies in aesthetic plastic surgery holds significant promise for enhancing surgical precision, patient satisfaction, and clinical outcomes, but further research and ethical considerations are essential for their safe and effective implementation.

title: Evaluation of gel spun silk-based biomaterials in a murine model of bladder augmentation
author: Mauney J.R.; Cannon G.M.; Lovett M.L.; Gong E.M.; Di Vizio D.; Gomez P.; Kaplan D.L.; Adam R.M.; Estrada C.R.
abstract: Bladder augmentation is a surgical procedure used to increase bladder capacity and reduce bladder pressure in patients with congenital or acquired bladder diseases. Current clinical approaches use gastrointestinal segments for bladder reconstruction, but these are associated with significant complications. Tissue engineering offers a promising alternative, and silk fibroin-based biomaterials have shown potential due to their biocompatibility and mechanical properties. In this study, we evaluated gel spun silk-based scaffolds for bladder augmentation in a murine model. The scaffolds were implanted into bladder defects, and tissue regeneration was assessed over time. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses demonstrated the formation of smooth muscle and urothelial layers, as well as neovascularization within the scaffold. Functional assessments indicated improved bladder capacity and compliance. These findings suggest that gel spun silk-based biomaterials support bladder tissue regeneration and may serve as a viable scaffold for bladder augmentation.

title: Keratin films for ocular surface reconstruction: Evaluation of biocompatibility in an in-vivo model
author: Borrelli M.; Joepen N.; Reichl S.; Finis D.; Schoppe M.; Geerling G.; Schrader S.
abstract: The development of biomaterials for ocular surface reconstruction is a challenging task due to the complex structure and function of the cornea. In this study, we evaluated the biocompatibility of keratin films derived from human hair as a potential scaffold for ocular surface reconstruction. Keratin films were fabricated and characterized for their physical and chemical properties. In vivo biocompatibility was assessed by implanting the films onto the ocular surface of a rabbit model. Clinical observations, histological analysis, and immunohistochemical staining were performed to evaluate the inflammatory response, epithelialization, and integration of the films with the host tissue. The results demonstrated that keratin films were well tolerated, promoted epithelial cell adhesion and proliferation, and supported corneal tissue regeneration without eliciting significant inflammation. These findings suggest that keratin films have promising potential as a biocompatible scaffold for ocular surface reconstruction applications.

title: Plastic surgery: A new dimension to face recognition
author: Singh, Richa and Vatsa, Mayank and Bhatt, Himanshu S and Bharadwaj, Samarth and Noore, Afzel and Nooreyezdan, Shahin S
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Plastic surgery is becoming increasingly popular and has a significant impact on face recognition systems. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effects of various plastic surgery procedures on face recognition performance. We analyze the challenges posed by surgical alterations and propose a novel approach to improve recognition accuracy in the presence of such changes. Experimental results on a newly created plastic surgery face database demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, highlighting the need for developing robust face recognition algorithms that can handle post-surgical facial variations.

title: A method for assessing 3D shape variations of fuzzy regions and its application on human bony orbits
author: Noser H.; Hammer B.; Kamer L.
abstract: This paper presents a method for assessing three-dimensional (3D) shape variations of fuzzy regions and applies it to human bony orbits. The method involves representing fuzzy regions by fuzzy membership functions and analyzing their shape variations using a fuzzy shape descriptor based on the concept of fuzzy moments. The approach allows for the quantification and comparison of shape differences in regions where boundaries are not sharply defined. The application to human bony orbits demonstrates the method's capability to capture subtle anatomical variations, which can be valuable in medical imaging and anthropological studies.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on anatomical shape analysis and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s goal.

title: Kinetic evaluation study on the bioactivity of silver doped hydroxyapatite-polyvinyl alcohol nanocomposites
author: Mostafa A.A.; Oudadesse H.; El Sayed M.M.H.; Kamal G.; Kamel M.; Foad E.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Silver doped hydroxyapatite-polyvinyl alcohol (Ag-HAp-PVA) nanocomposites were synthesized by a simple chemical precipitation method. The prepared nanocomposites were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The bioactivity of the nanocomposites was evaluated by immersing them in simulated body fluid (SBF) for different time intervals. The formation of apatite layer on the surface of the nanocomposites was confirmed by SEM and XRD analysis. The kinetic study of apatite formation was carried out by measuring the weight gain of the samples after immersion in SBF. The results showed that the incorporation of silver ions into hydroxyapatite enhanced the bioactivity and antibacterial properties of the nanocomposites. The kinetic evaluation indicated that the apatite formation followed a pseudo-second-order kinetic model, suggesting chemisorption as the rate-limiting step. These findings demonstrate the potential of Ag-HAp-PVA nanocomposites for biomedical applications such as bone tissue engineering and implant coatings.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on the antibacterial features of nanocomposites for bone healing, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn’t fit here.

title: Data-based prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery: clinical assessment of new simulation software
author: Abe, N and Kuroda, S and Furutani, M and Tanaka, E
journal: International journal of oral and maxillofacial surgery
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery is essential for treatment planning and patient communication. This study aimed to clinically assess the accuracy of a new simulation software for predicting soft tissue changes following orthognathic surgery. Twenty patients undergoing bimaxillary surgery were included. Pre- and postoperative three-dimensional facial scans were obtained, and soft tissue changes were predicted using the software based on the planned skeletal movements. The predicted soft tissue outcomes were compared with the actual postoperative results using quantitative and qualitative analyses. The software demonstrated good accuracy in predicting soft tissue changes, particularly in the midface and lower face regions, with mean discrepancies within clinically acceptable limits. However, some limitations were noted in areas with complex soft tissue dynamics. The new simulation software shows promise as a valuable tool for surgical planning and patient education, though further refinement and validation are recommended.

title: Interobserver agreement and consensus over the esthetic evaluation of conservative treatment for breast cancer
author: Cardoso, Maria Joao and Cardoso, Jaime and Santos, Ana Cristina and Barros, Henrique and de Oliveira, Manuel Cardoso
abstract: Background: The esthetic outcome of breast-conserving treatment (BCT) is an important parameter in the evaluation of treatment results. However, the esthetic evaluation is subjective and may vary between observers. The aim of this study was to assess the interobserver agreement and consensus over the esthetic evaluation of BCT.  Methods: Thirty patients treated with BCT were evaluated by 10 observers (breast surgeons, radiation oncologists, and plastic surgeons). The esthetic outcome was scored on a 4-point scale (excellent, good, fair, poor) based on standardized photographs. Interobserver agreement was assessed using kappa statistics. Consensus was reached through a group discussion and re-evaluation.  Results: The overall interobserver agreement was moderate (kappa = 0.48). Agreement was higher among plastic surgeons (kappa = 0.56) compared to breast surgeons (kappa = 0.44) and radiation oncologists (kappa = 0.42). After consensus discussion, the agreement improved significantly (kappa = 0.68).  Conclusions: Esthetic evaluation of BCT shows moderate interobserver agreement, which can be improved by consensus discussions. Standardized evaluation protocols and training may enhance reliability in esthetic assessments.

title: Multi-kernel graph embedding for detection, Gleason grading of prostate cancer via MRI/MRS
author: Tiwari P.; Kurhanewicz J.; Madabhushi A.
abstract: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men and the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) have shown promise for noninvasive detection and characterization of prostate cancer. However, the interpretation of MRI/MRS data is challenging due to the complex and heterogeneous nature of prostate cancer. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-kernel graph embedding (MKGE) framework for the detection and Gleason grading of prostate cancer using MRI/MRS data. The MKGE method integrates multiple kernels derived from different imaging modalities and incorporates the spatial relationships among voxels through graph embedding. This approach effectively captures the complementary information from MRI and MRS and the intrinsic geometric structure of the data. Experimental results on a clinical dataset demonstrate that the proposed MKGE method outperforms traditional single-kernel and feature-based methods in both cancer detection and Gleason grading, indicating its potential for improving prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: Differences in tibial rotation during walking in ACL reconstructed and healthy contralateral knees
author: Scanlan S.F.; Chaudhari A.M.W.; Dyrby C.O.; Andriacchi T.P.
abstract: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury is a common knee injury that often results in altered knee kinematics. This study aimed to investigate differences in tibial rotation during walking between ACL reconstructed knees and healthy contralateral knees. Using a three-dimensional motion analysis system, tibial rotation was measured in 20 subjects with unilateral ACL reconstruction during level walking. The results showed that the ACL reconstructed knees exhibited significantly greater internal tibial rotation during the stance phase of walking compared to the healthy contralateral knees. These findings suggest that ACL reconstruction may not fully restore normal tibial rotational kinematics during gait, which could have implications for joint loading and the development of osteoarthritis.

title: PtosisDiffusion: a training-free workflow for precisely predicting post-operative appearance in blepharoptosis patients based on diffusion models
author: Huang, Shenyu and Xie, Jiajun and Yang, Boyuan and Gao, Qi and Ye, Juan
journal: Frontiers in Cell and Developmental Biology
abstract: PtosisDiffusion is a training-free workflow designed to precisely predict post-operative appearance in blepharoptosis patients using diffusion models. This approach leverages the capabilities of diffusion models to generate high-fidelity images that simulate surgical outcomes without the need for extensive training data. By integrating clinical parameters and pre-operative images, PtosisDiffusion provides surgeons and patients with a reliable visualization tool to anticipate post-surgical results, thereby enhancing pre-operative planning and patient communication. The method demonstrates significant potential in improving surgical precision and patient satisfaction in blepharoptosis treatment.

title: In vivo evaluation of a new biphasic calcium phosphate bone substitute in rabbit femur defects model
author: Chen C.-H.; Chiang C.-J.; Rau G.; Huang M.-S.; Chan K.K.; Liao C.-J.; Kuo Y.-J.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
doi: World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte Ltd
abstract: The present study aimed to evaluate the in vivo performance of a new biphasic calcium phosphate (BCP) bone substitute composed of hydroxyapatite (HA) and β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP) in a rabbit femur defect model. Cylindrical defects were created in the femoral condyles of rabbits and filled with the BCP material. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation to assess new bone formation and material resorption. The results demonstrated that the BCP bone substitute was biocompatible, osteoconductive, and gradually resorbed over time, allowing for new bone ingrowth. The balance between HA and β-TCP phases contributed to the material's stability and resorption rate, making it a promising candidate for clinical applications in bone regeneration.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on bone substitute compatibility and healing, with no mention of predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Measuring patient-reported outcomes in facial aesthetic patients: development of the FACE-Q
author: Klassen, Anne F and Cano, Stefan J and Scott, Amie and Snell, Laura and Pusic, Andrea L
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Integrating AI into Breast Reconstruction Surgery: Exploring Opportunities, Applications, and Challenges
author: Gorgy, Andrew and Xu, Hong Hao and Hawary, Hassan El and Nepon, Hillary and Lee, James and Vorstenbosch, Joshua
doi: SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Development and assessment of a Microsoft Kinect based system for imaging the breast in three dimensions
author: Wheat J.S.; Choppin S.; Goyal A.
abstract: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment and improved survival rates. Current imaging modalities such as mammography and ultrasound have limitations including discomfort, radiation exposure, and operator dependency. This study presents the development and assessment of a novel, low-cost, non-invasive system for three-dimensional (3D) imaging of the breast using the Microsoft Kinect sensor. The system captures depth data to reconstruct the breast surface in 3D, enabling volumetric measurements and shape analysis. Validation was performed using breast phantoms and clinical data from volunteers. Results demonstrate that the Kinect-based system provides accurate and reproducible 3D breast images, with potential applications in breast cancer screening, surgical planning, and monitoring of treatment response. The system offers a promising alternative to conventional imaging techniques, combining affordability, ease of use, and patient comfort.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focus lies on breast imaging for cancer detection and volume measurement, not on automatic prediction or evaluation of surgical aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Very deep convolutional networks for large-scale image recognition
author: Simonyan, Karen and Zisserman, Andrew
abstract: We investigate the effect of the convolutional network depth on its accuracy in the large-scale image recognition setting. Our main contribution is a thorough evaluation of networks of increasing depth using an architecture with very small (3×3) convolution filters, which shows that a significant improvement on the prior-art configurations can be achieved by pushing the depth to 16–19 weight layers. These findings were the basis of our ImageNet Challenge 2014 submission, where our team secured the first and the second places in the localisation and classification tracks respectively. We also show that our representations generalise well to other datasets, where they achieve state-of-the-art results.

title: A decade survey of content based image retrieval using deep learning
author: Dubey, Shiv Ram
journal: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Content-based image retrieval (CBIR) is a fundamental and challenging problem in computer vision and pattern recognition. With the rapid development of deep learning, CBIR has witnessed significant progress in recent years. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of deep learning-based CBIR methods over the past decade. We first introduce the background and motivation of CBIR and then review the representative deep learning architectures and techniques applied to CBIR, including convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, generative adversarial networks, and attention mechanisms. We also discuss various feature extraction, feature aggregation, and similarity measurement strategies. Furthermore, we analyze the strengths and limitations of existing methods and highlight several benchmark datasets and evaluation metrics commonly used in CBIR research. Finally, we identify open challenges and potential future research directions to inspire further advancements in deep learning-based CBIR.

title: Hair removal methods: A comparative study for dermoscopy images
author: Abbas Q.; Celebi M.E.; García I.F.
abstract: Hair removal is an important preprocessing step in dermoscopy image analysis. The presence of hair in dermoscopy images can significantly affect the performance of automated lesion segmentation and classification algorithms. In this paper, we present a comparative study of different hair removal methods applied to dermoscopy images. We evaluate the performance of these methods based on their ability to remove hair while preserving lesion details. The methods compared include DullRazor, morphological closing, and inpainting techniques. Our results show that inpainting methods provide better hair removal with less distortion of lesion features, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis. This study provides valuable insights for selecting appropriate hair removal techniques in dermoscopy image analysis.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on image preprocessing for lesion analysis in dermoscopy and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation in plastic or oncological surgery.

title: Transplantation of reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on a lyophilized amniotic membrane to severely alkali-burned cornea
author: Jang I.-K.; Ahn J.-I.; Shin J.-S.; Kwon Y.-S.; Ryu Y.-H.; Lee J.-K.; Park J.-K.; Song K.-Y.; Yang E.-K.; Kim J.-C.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To evaluate the efficacy of transplantation of a reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on a lyophilized amniotic membrane (LAM) to severely alkali-burned corneas. METHODS: Corneal fibroblasts were cultured on the stromal side of LAM, and corneal epithelial cells were cultured on the epithelial side. The reconstructed corneal layer was transplanted onto the corneal surface of rabbits with severe alkali burns. The corneal surface was evaluated by slit-lamp microscopy, histology, and immunohistochemistry. RESULTS: The reconstructed corneal layer adhered well to the corneal surface and survived for at least 4 weeks. The corneal surface showed improved transparency and epithelialization compared with controls. Histological examination revealed a multilayered epithelium and stromal-like tissue beneath the epithelium. Immunohistochemical analysis showed expression of keratin 3 in the epithelium and vimentin in the fibroblast layer. CONCLUSIONS: Transplantation of a reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on LAM promotes corneal surface reconstruction and may be a useful treatment for severe alkali-burned corneas.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on repairing corneas without looking at predicting or evaluating how things will look, so it doesn’t fit the topic of aesthetic assessment in surgery.

title: A Computer-based Surgery Planning and Simulation for the Prediction of 3D Postoperative Facial Soft Tissue using Finite Element Analysis
author: Obaidellah, Unaizah Hanum and Selvanathan, N
abstract: This paper presents a computer-based surgery planning and simulation system for predicting three-dimensional (3D) postoperative facial soft tissue changes using finite element analysis (FEA). The system integrates patient-specific anatomical data obtained from medical imaging with biomechanical modeling to simulate the effects of surgical interventions on facial soft tissues. By constructing a finite element model of the facial soft tissue and underlying bone structures, the system allows surgeons to visualize and evaluate potential surgical outcomes preoperatively. The approach aims to improve surgical planning accuracy and patient communication by providing realistic predictions of postoperative facial appearance. Validation results demonstrate the system's capability to predict soft tissue deformations with clinically acceptable accuracy, highlighting its potential as a valuable tool in maxillofacial surgery.

title: In vivo evaluation of hydroxyapatite foams
author: Sepulveda P.; Bressiani A.H.; Bressiani J.C.; Meseguer L.; König B., Jr.
abstract: The in vivo behavior of hydroxyapatite (HA) foams was studied in a rabbit model. The foams were implanted into the femoral condyles and evaluated at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation. Histological and histomorphometric analyses revealed good biocompatibility and osteoconductivity of the HA foams. New bone formation was observed within the pores of the foams, and the material showed progressive resorption and replacement by bone tissue over time.
