The results suggest that HA foams have potential as bone graft substitutes for the repair of bone defects.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the biocompatibility and bone healing of hydroxyapatite foams, without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Telemetry system for monitoring anterior cruciate ligament graft forces in vivo
author: McKee E.L.; Lindsey D.P.; Hull M.L.; Howell S.M.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: A telemetry system for monitoring anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) graft forces in vivo was developed and tested. The system consists of a force transducer integrated into the graft, a miniature transmitter, and an external receiver. The force transducer is a strain gauge-based device designed to measure tensile forces within the graft. The transmitter sends the force data wirelessly to the receiver, allowing real-time monitoring of graft forces during various activities. Calibration and in vitro testing demonstrated the system's accuracy and reliability. Preliminary in vivo experiments in animal models showed the feasibility of continuous graft force monitoring, providing valuable data for understanding graft biomechanics and improving surgical techniques. This telemetry system represents a significant advancement in orthopedic research and clinical practice by enabling direct measurement of ACL graft forces in living subjects.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on biomechanical monitoring of ACL graft forces and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Deep Learning-Based Facial and Skeletal Transformations for Surgical Planning
author: Bao, J and Zhang, X and Xiang, S and Liu, H and Cheng, M and Yang, Y and Huang, X and Xiang, W and Cui, W and Lai, HC and others
doi: SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Measurement of adverse cosmesis in breast cancer: A deep learning approach
author: Saha, Ashirbani and Levine, Mark and Kong, Isaac and Parvez, Elena and Whelan, Timothy
abstract: This study proposes a novel deep learning-based approach for the objective measurement of adverse cosmesis in breast cancer patients following treatment. Traditional assessment methods rely heavily on subjective evaluations, which can lead to inconsistent and unreliable results. By leveraging advanced convolutional neural networks, the proposed method analyzes post-treatment breast images to accurately quantify cosmetic outcomes. The model was trained and validated on a comprehensive dataset, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing techniques. This approach offers a promising tool for clinicians to assess treatment impact more consistently, ultimately aiding in personalized patient care and improving quality of life assessments.

title: Aesthetics in breast conserving therapy: do objectively measured results match patients’ evaluations?
author: Heil, Joerg and Dahlkamp, Julia and Golatta, Michael and Rom, Joachim and Domschke, Christoph and Rauch, Geraldine and Cardoso, Maria Joao and Sohn, Christof
abstract: Background: The aim of this study was to compare patients’ subjective evaluations of aesthetic results after breast-conserving therapy (BCT) with objective measurements.  Methods: A total of 100 patients who underwent BCT were included. Patients rated their aesthetic outcome using a visual analog scale (VAS). Objective measurements were performed using a computer-based system analyzing breast symmetry, volume, and nipple position. Correlations between subjective and objective assessments were analyzed.  Results: The mean patient VAS score was 7.2 (range 2–10). Objective measurements showed varying degrees of asymmetry. There was a moderate correlation between patient evaluations and objective symmetry measurements (r = 0.45, p < 0.01). However, some patients with significant asymmetry rated their results highly, indicating a discrepancy between subjective satisfaction and objective findings.  Conclusions: While objective measurements provide valuable information on aesthetic outcomes after BCT, they do not fully capture patients’ subjective satisfaction. Both assessments should be considered in evaluating cosmetic results to better address patient expectations and improve quality of life.

title: Metacarpophalangeal collateral ligament reconstruction using small intestinal submucosa in an equine model
author: Bertone A.L.; Goin S.; Kamei S.J.; Mattoon J.S.; Litsky A.S.; Weisbrode S.E.; Clarke R.B.; Plouhar P.L.; Kaeding C.C.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The collateral ligaments of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint are important stabilizers of the joint and are frequently injured in horses. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the use of small intestinal submucosa (SIS) as a scaffold for collateral ligament reconstruction in an equine model. Six adult horses underwent unilateral reconstruction of the MCP collateral ligament using SIS. Clinical, ultrasonographic, and histologic evaluations were performed over a 12-week period. All horses tolerated the procedure well, and no complications were observed. Ultrasonographic examination showed progressive integration of the SIS graft with surrounding tissues. Histologic analysis revealed cellular infiltration, neovascularization, and collagen deposition within the graft, indicating remodeling and ligamentization. These findings suggest that SIS is a promising biomaterial for collateral ligament reconstruction in horses, providing a scaffold that supports tissue regeneration and functional recovery. Further studies are warranted to assess long-term outcomes and biomechanical properties of the reconstructed ligaments.

title: Realm: Rag-driven enhancement of multimodal electronic health records analysis via large language models
author: Zhu, Yinghao and Ren, Changyu and Xie, Shiyun and Liu, Shukai and Ji, Hangyuan and Wang, Zixiang and Sun, Tao and He, Long and Li, Zhoujun and Zhu, Xi and others
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Hair removal using the long-pulsed ruby laser in children
author: Morley S.; Gault D.
journal: Journal of Clinical Laser Medicine and Surgery
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hair removal in children is a common cosmetic concern. The long-pulsed ruby laser has been used effectively for hair removal in adults, but its safety and efficacy in children have not been well studied. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of the long-pulsed ruby laser for hair removal in children. METHODS: Twenty children aged 7 to 15 years with unwanted hair were treated with the long-pulsed ruby laser. Treatments were performed at 4- to 6-week intervals for a total of three to six sessions. Hair reduction was assessed by clinical examination and patient satisfaction. RESULTS: Significant hair reduction was observed in all patients, with minimal side effects. Transient erythema and mild discomfort were the most common adverse effects. No scarring or pigmentary changes were noted. CONCLUSION: The long-pulsed ruby laser is a safe and effective method for hair removal in children. It offers a promising option for pediatric patients seeking long-term hair reduction.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on how well and safely laser hair removal works, without looking at predicting or evaluating how it affects appearance, which is what's needed here.

title: Five-year clinical investigation of one conventional composite and three microfilled resins in anterior teeth
author: Crumpler D.C.; Heymann H.O.; Shugars D.A.; Bayne S.C.; Leinfelder K.F.
abstract: The clinical performance of one conventional composite resin (Concise) and three microfilled resins (Silux Plus, Durafill, and Heliomolar) was evaluated in anterior teeth over a five-year period. A total of 120 restorations were placed in 30 patients and assessed at baseline and after 1, 2, 3, and 5 years using modified USPHS criteria. The results showed that all materials exhibited good clinical performance with no significant differences in retention rates. However, microfilled resins demonstrated superior surface texture and color match compared to the conventional composite. Marginal adaptation and anatomic form were maintained satisfactorily in all materials. The study concluded that microfilled resins are suitable for anterior restorations, offering esthetic advantages without compromising clinical durability over five years.

title: An artificial intelligence tool for image simulation in rhinoplasty
author: Chinski, Hernan and Lerch, Ricardo and Tournour, Dami{\'a}n and Chinski, Luis and Caruso, Diego
abstract: Background Rhinoplasty is one of the most challenging procedures in plastic surgery. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) tools in image simulation can help surgeons and patients to better understand the expected surgical outcomes. This study aimed to develop and evaluate an AI-based tool for image simulation in rhinoplasty.  Methods A convolutional neural network (CNN) was trained on a dataset of preoperative and postoperative rhinoplasty images to learn the transformation patterns. The model was then used to generate simulated postoperative images from new preoperative photographs. The quality and realism of the simulated images were assessed by a panel of experienced plastic surgeons.  Results The AI tool successfully generated realistic postoperative images that closely resembled actual surgical outcomes. The surgeons rated the simulations as highly accurate and useful for preoperative planning and patient counseling.  Conclusion The developed AI-based image simulation tool shows promise as an aid in rhinoplasty, enhancing communication between surgeons and patients and potentially improving surgical planning and satisfaction. Further studies with larger datasets are warranted to refine the model and validate its clinical utility.

title: Anchor-Net: Distance-Based Self-Supervised Learning Model for Facial Beauty Prediction
author: Bae, Jiho and Buu, Seok-Jun and Lee, Suwon
abstract: This paper proposes a novel self-supervised learning model, Anchor-Net, for facial beauty prediction. Unlike traditional supervised methods that rely heavily on labeled data, Anchor-Net leverages a distance-based approach to learn discriminative facial features without explicit beauty annotations. The model employs anchor points in the feature space to capture intrinsic beauty-related characteristics, enabling effective representation learning. Experimental results on benchmark facial beauty datasets demonstrate that Anchor-Net achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art supervised methods, highlighting its potential for applications where labeled data is scarce or unavailable.

title: Prefabricated tracheal prosthesis with partial biodegradable materials: A surgical and tissue engineering evaluation in vivo
author: Acocella F.; Brizzola S.; Valtolina C.; Scanziani E.; Marchesi F.; Mantero S.; Garreau H.; Vert M.
journal: Journal of Biomaterials Science, Polymer Edition
abstract: The present study aimed to evaluate the in vivo performance of a prefabricated tracheal prosthesis composed of partial biodegradable materials. The prosthesis was designed to combine mechanical support with tissue engineering principles to promote regeneration of tracheal tissue. In a surgical model, the prosthesis was implanted and assessed for biocompatibility, integration with host tissue, and functional outcomes over a defined period. Histological and mechanical analyses demonstrated that the biodegradable components facilitated gradual tissue ingrowth and remodeling, while maintaining airway patency. The results suggest that this hybrid approach holds promise for tracheal reconstruction, offering a balance between structural integrity and biological integration. Further studies are warranted to optimize material composition and long-term outcomes.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on the functional and tissue engineering aspects of tracheal prostheses and doesn't cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Biodegradable material for bladder reconstruction
author: Agishi T.; Nakazono M.; Kiraly R.J.; Picha G.; Nosé Y.
abstract: Biodegradable materials have been investigated as scaffolds for bladder reconstruction to provide a temporary matrix that supports tissue regeneration and then degrades, eliminating the need for surgical removal. This study evaluates the use of a biodegradable polymer, poly(glycolic acid) (PGA), as a scaffold for bladder tissue engineering. PGA scaffolds were seeded with bladder smooth muscle cells and implanted in a rat model. Histological and functional assessments demonstrated that the PGA scaffold supported smooth muscle regeneration and urothelial coverage, with progressive scaffold degradation over time. These findings suggest that biodegradable PGA scaffolds may be a promising approach for bladder reconstruction, offering a potential alternative to traditional non-degradable materials.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses solely on tissue regeneration with biodegradable scaffolds and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation, so it’s outside the review’s scope.

title: Deep edge detection methods for the automatic calculation of the breast contour
author: Freitas, Nuno and Silva, Daniel and Mavioso, Carlos and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: Accurate breast contour detection is a crucial step in breast cancer diagnosis and treatment planning. Traditional edge detection methods often struggle with the complex and variable nature of breast images. This study proposes deep learning-based edge detection methods to automatically calculate the breast contour from medical images. We evaluate several deep edge detection architectures and compare their performance with classical methods. Our results demonstrate that deep learning approaches significantly improve the accuracy and robustness of breast contour detection, facilitating better clinical decision-making and personalized treatment strategies.

title: A novel incremental simulation of facial changes following orthognathic surgery using FEM with realistic lip sliding effect
author: Kim, Daeseung and Kuang, Tianshu and Rodrigues, Yriu L and Gateno, Jaime and Shen, Steve GF and Wang, Xudong and Stein, Kirhyn and Deng, Hannah H and Liebschner, Michael AK and Xia, James J
abstract: Orthognathic surgery is a common procedure to correct dentofacial deformities, which results in significant changes in facial appearance. Predicting postoperative facial changes is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication. This paper presents a novel incremental simulation method based on the finite element method (FEM) to predict facial soft tissue changes following orthognathic surgery, incorporating a realistic lip sliding effect. The proposed method models the lip sliding phenomenon by introducing a frictional contact algorithm between the upper and lower lips, which allows for more accurate simulation of lip movements and deformations. The incremental approach updates the simulation step-by-step, capturing the gradual changes in facial tissues during surgery. Experimental results on clinical cases demonstrate that the proposed method achieves improved accuracy in predicting postoperative facial appearance, especially in the lip region, compared to existing methods. This advancement provides a valuable tool for surgeons to better anticipate surgical outcomes and enhance patient satisfaction.

title: A fully automatic postoperative appearance prediction system for blepharoptosis surgery with image-based deep learning
author: Sun, Yiming and Huang, Xingru and Zhang, Qianni and Lee, Sang Yeul and Wang, Yaqi and Jin, Kai and Lou, Lixia and Ye, Juan
abstract: Purpose: To develop a fully automatic postoperative appearance prediction system for blepharoptosis surgery using image-based deep learning. Design: Retrospective case series. Participants: A total of 970 preoperative and postoperative facial images from 485 patients who underwent blepharoptosis surgery. Methods: A deep learning model was trained to predict postoperative appearance from preoperative images. The model was developed using a convolutional neural network architecture and was trained on paired preoperative and postoperative images. Main Outcome Measures: The accuracy of the predicted postoperative appearance was evaluated using quantitative metrics and qualitative assessments by ophthalmologists. Results: The deep learning model successfully generated postoperative appearance predictions that closely resembled actual postoperative images. Quantitative analysis showed high similarity scores between predicted and actual postoperative images. Qualitative assessments by ophthalmologists confirmed the clinical relevance and accuracy of the predictions. Conclusions: The developed deep learning-based system can automatically predict postoperative appearance after blepharoptosis surgery with high accuracy, potentially aiding surgical planning and patient counseling.

title: Assessment of viability and proliferation of in vivo silicone‐primed lymphocytes after in vitro re‐exposure to silicone
author: Ciapetti G.; Granchi D.; Stea S.; Cenni E.; Schiavon P.; Giuliani R.; Pizzoferrato A.
abstract: The viability and proliferation of lymphocytes obtained from silicone‐primed and control rats were assessed after in vitro re‐exposure to silicone. Lymphocytes were isolated from the lymph nodes of rats that had been implanted with silicone gel or sham operated. The cells were cultured in the presence or absence of silicone gel for 3 days. Cell viability was determined by trypan blue exclusion and proliferation was measured by [3H]thymidine incorporation. The results showed that lymphocytes from silicone‐primed rats had a significantly higher proliferation rate upon re‐exposure to silicone in vitro compared to controls, while cell viability remained unaffected. These findings suggest that silicone implantation primes lymphocytes to respond to silicone antigens, which may have implications for understanding silicone-related immune responses.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on immune reactions to silicone instead of predicting or assessing surgical appearance, so it doesn't fit the topic.

title: Clinical evaluations of OSTEON® as a new alloplastic material in sinus bone grafting and its effect on bone healing
author: Kim Y.-K.; Yun P.-Y.; Lim S.-C.; Kim S.-G.; Lee H.-J.; Ong J.L.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the clinical efficacy of OSTEON® as a new alloplastic material in sinus bone grafting and its effect on bone healing. Twenty patients requiring sinus bone grafting were enrolled and divided into two groups: the OSTEON® group and the control group using Bio-Oss®. Clinical and radiographic evaluations were performed at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were conducted on bone biopsy specimens obtained during implant placement. The results showed that OSTEON® demonstrated comparable clinical performance to Bio-Oss® in terms of graft volume maintenance and implant stability. Histological analysis revealed new bone formation with good integration of OSTEON® particles, indicating its osteoconductive properties. The study concluded that OSTEON® is a promising alloplastic material for sinus bone grafting, promoting effective bone healing and providing a suitable environment for implant placement.

title: Breast compliance: a new method for evaluation of cosmetic outcome after conservative treatment of early breast cancer
author: Tsouskas, LI and Fentiman, IS
abstract: Breast compliance, defined as the ratio of breast volume to breast projection, was evaluated as a new method for assessing cosmetic outcome after conservative treatment of early breast cancer. In a prospective study, 50 patients underwent breast-conserving surgery followed by radiotherapy. Breast volume and projection were measured using a three-dimensional laser scanner before treatment and at 6 and 12 months post-treatment. The breast compliance index was calculated and correlated with subjective cosmetic assessments by patients and clinicians. Results showed a significant decrease in breast compliance on the treated side compared to the untreated side, correlating with poorer cosmetic outcomes. Breast compliance measurement provides an objective, reproducible, and sensitive method for evaluating cosmetic results after breast-conserving therapy and may aid in treatment planning and patient counseling.

title: Evaluation of cosmetic outcomes in breast reconstruction patients undergoing radiotherapy using an anomaly generative adversarial network model
author: Lee, Choong-Won and Shin, Kyung Hwan and Chang, Ji Hyun and Jang, Bum-Sup
abstract: Breast reconstruction patients undergoing radiotherapy often experience changes in cosmetic outcomes, which are challenging to evaluate objectively. This study proposes an anomaly generative adversarial network (AnoGAN) model to assess cosmetic outcomes in these patients. The model was trained on pre- and post-radiotherapy images to detect anomalies indicative of cosmetic changes. Our results demonstrate that the AnoGAN model effectively identifies subtle cosmetic alterations, providing a quantitative and objective tool for evaluating breast reconstruction outcomes post-radiotherapy. This approach has the potential to enhance clinical decision-making and patient counseling by offering precise assessments of cosmetic results.

title: Polydimethylsiloxane versus Polytetrafluoroethylene for Vocal Fold Medialization: Histologic Evaluation in a Rabbit Model
author: Caballero M.; Bernal-Sprekelsen M.; Calvo C.; Farrè X.; Quintó L.; Alòs L.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The purpose of this study was to compare the histologic tissue response to polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) when used for vocal fold medialization in a rabbit model. Twelve rabbits underwent unilateral vocal fold medialization with either PDMS or PTFE implants. After 12 weeks, the larynges were harvested and processed for histologic evaluation. The tissue response was assessed by examining inflammation, fibrosis, and foreign body reaction. Both materials were well tolerated, with minimal inflammatory response and no evidence of implant extrusion or migration. PDMS showed a slightly higher degree of fibrosis compared to PTFE, but this difference was not statistically significant. The findings suggest that both PDMS and PTFE are biocompatible materials suitable for vocal fold medialization, with comparable histologic outcomes in this animal model.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Looks at tissue responses in animals without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn’t match what’s needed.

title: Hippocrate: A safe robot arm for medical applications with force feedback
author: Pierrot F.; Dombre E.; Dégoulange E.; Urbain L.; Caron P.; Boudet S.; Gariépy J.; Mégnien J.-L.
abstract: This paper presents Hippocrate, a robot arm designed for medical applications that incorporates force feedback to ensure safety during operation. The system is developed to assist medical practitioners by providing precise and controlled movements while maintaining a high level of safety through real-time force sensing and feedback mechanisms. The design considerations, control strategies, and experimental results demonstrating the robot's performance and safety features are discussed in detail. Hippocrate aims to enhance the capabilities of medical robots by combining dexterity with reliable force feedback to prevent accidental harm to patients.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on robotic safety and force feedback in general medical use, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Simulation and artificial intelligence in rhinoplasty: a systematic review
author: Eldaly, Abdullah S and Avila, Francisco R and Torres-Guzman, Ricardo A and Maita, Karla and Garcia, John P and Palmieri Serrano, Luiza and Forte, Antonio J
abstract: Purpose Simulation and artificial intelligence (AI) are increasingly used in plastic surgery, including rhinoplasty. This systematic review aims to summarize the current applications of simulation and AI in rhinoplasty and evaluate their impact on surgical planning, education, and outcomes. Methods A systematic literature search was conducted in PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases up to June 2022. Studies reporting on simulation or AI applications in rhinoplasty were included. Data on study design, technology used, application, and outcomes were extracted and analyzed. Results Twenty-three studies met inclusion criteria. Simulation methods included three-dimensional (3D) imaging, virtual surgical planning, and augmented reality. AI applications involved machine learning algorithms for outcome prediction and automated anatomical analysis. Simulation improved preoperative planning accuracy and patient communication. AI showed promise in predicting surgical outcomes and complications but requires further validation. Conclusions Simulation and AI technologies are emerging tools in rhinoplasty, enhancing surgical planning, education, and potentially improving outcomes. However, current evidence is limited, and further research is needed to establish standardized protocols and validate AI models for clinical use.

title: Neocartilage formation in vitro and in vivo using cells cultured on synthetic biodegradable polymers
author: Freed L.E.; Marquis J.C.; Nohria A.; Emmanual J.; Mikos A.G.; Langer R.
abstract: Neocartilage formation was studied in vitro and in vivo using cells cultured on synthetic biodegradable polymers. Chondrocytes isolated from rabbit articular cartilage were seeded onto porous biodegradable polymer scaffolds composed of poly(L-lactic acid) and poly(glycolic acid) and cultured in vitro for up to 4 weeks. The constructs were then implanted subcutaneously in nude mice for up to 8 weeks. Histological and biochemical analyses demonstrated that the chondrocytes maintained their phenotype and produced cartilaginous extracellular matrix both in vitro and in vivo. The results suggest that synthetic biodegradable polymers can serve as suitable scaffolds for cartilage tissue engineering.

title: Subjective rating of cosmetic treatment with botulinum toxin type A: do existing measures demonstrate interobserver validity?
author: Conkling, Nicole and Bishawi, Muath and Phillips, Brett T and Bui, Duc T and Khan, Sami U and Dagum, Alexander B
abstract: Background: Botulinum toxin type A (BTX-A) is widely used for cosmetic treatment of facial rhytides. Subjective rating scales are commonly used to assess treatment outcomes, but their interobserver validity has not been well established. This study aimed to evaluate the interobserver validity of existing subjective rating measures for cosmetic BTX-A treatment.  Methods: A panel of experienced clinicians independently rated standardized photographs of patients before and after BTX-A treatment using commonly used subjective rating scales. Interobserver agreement was assessed using statistical measures including intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs).  Results: The study found variable interobserver agreement across different rating scales, with some measures demonstrating moderate to good reliability, while others showed poor agreement. Factors influencing variability included scale design and rater experience.  Conclusions: Existing subjective rating scales for cosmetic BTX-A treatment show inconsistent interobserver validity. There is a need for standardized, validated measures to reliably assess treatment outcomes in clinical and research settings.

title: Deep learning-based facial appearance simulation driven by surgically planned craniomaxillofacial bony movement
author: Fang, Xi and Kim, Daeseung and Xu, Xuanang and Kuang, Tianshu and Deng, Hannah H and Barber, Joshua C and Lampen, Nathan and Gateno, Jaime and Liebschner, Michael AK and Xia, James J and others
abstract: Accurate prediction of facial appearance changes after craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery is essential for surgical planning and patient communication. Traditional biomechanical models require complex parameter tuning and are computationally expensive. In this paper, we propose a deep learning-based framework to simulate facial appearance changes driven by surgically planned bony movements. Our method leverages a conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) that takes preoperative facial images and 3D bony movement parameters as inputs and generates postoperative facial appearance images. We train and validate our model on a dataset of CMF surgical cases with paired pre- and postoperative images and corresponding bony movement data. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach can produce realistic and accurate facial appearance simulations, significantly reducing computation time compared to biomechanical models. This work offers a promising tool for enhancing surgical planning and patient education in CMF surgery.

title: Tribological evaluation of oxidized zirconium using an articular cartilage counterface: A novel material for potential use in hemiarthroplasty
author: Patel A.M.; Spector M.
abstract: The tribological behavior of oxidized zirconium (OxZr) was evaluated using an articular cartilage counterface in a pin-on-plate configuration. The OxZr was compared to cobalt-chromium (CoCr) alloy and titanium alloy (Ti6Al4V) under conditions simulating hemiarthroplasty. The results showed that OxZr exhibited significantly lower friction and wear against cartilage compared to CoCr and Ti6Al4V. The reduced wear and friction are attributed to the hard, smooth, and chemically stable oxide layer on the OxZr surface. These findings suggest that OxZr is a promising material for hemiarthroplasty applications due to its superior tribological performance with articular cartilage.

title: In vitro and in vivo biocompatibility evaluation of a polyalkylimide hydrogel for soft tissue augmentation
author: Ramires P.A.; Miccoli M.A.; Panzarini E.; Dini L.; Protopapa C.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The biocompatibility of a polyalkylimide hydrogel (PAI) was evaluated in vitro and in vivo to assess its potential use as a soft tissue filler. In vitro cytotoxicity tests using L929 fibroblasts showed no significant cytotoxic effects. In vivo biocompatibility was assessed by subcutaneous implantation in rats, with histological analysis performed at 1, 4, and 12 weeks post-implantation. The results demonstrated minimal inflammatory response and good tissue integration without fibrous capsule formation. These findings suggest that PAI hydrogel is a promising candidate for soft tissue augmentation applications.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on hydrogel biocompatibility and tissue integration, without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results.

title: Moiré photography as a means of topographical mapping of the human face
author: Madden M.C.; Karlan M.S.
abstract: Moiré photography is a technique which can be used to obtain a topographical map of the human face. The method is based on the interference of two superimposed patterns, one of which is the image of the object and the other a reference grating. The resulting moiré fringes correspond to lines of equal height on the surface of the object. The technique is non-invasive, rapid, and can be used to detect small changes in facial topography. Applications include clinical assessment of facial deformities and monitoring of treatment progress.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on facial mapping and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which is key for this review on aesthetic assessment in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: The recharge of esthetic dental restorative materials with fluoride in vitro - Two years' results
author: Preston A.J.; Agalamanyi E.A.; Higham S.M.; Mair L.H.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the fluoride recharge capacity of esthetic dental restorative materials after two years of aging in vitro. Four materials were tested: a resin-modified glass ionomer cement (Vitremer), a polyacid-modified composite resin (Dyract AP), a fluoride-containing composite resin (Tetric Ceram), and a conventional composite resin (Z100). Specimens were stored in artificial saliva for two years and then subjected to a fluoride recharge treatment with a 1.23% acidulated phosphate fluoride gel. Fluoride release was measured before and after recharge using an ion-selective electrode. Results showed that Vitremer had the highest fluoride release and recharge capacity, followed by Dyract AP and Tetric Ceram, while Z100 showed negligible fluoride release and recharge. The study concluded that resin-modified glass ionomer cements and polyacid-modified composite resins can maintain fluoride release over extended periods and can be recharged with topical fluoride applications, which may contribute to their cariostatic effect in clinical use.

title: Effect of filler porosity on the abrasion resistance of nanoporous silica gel/polymer composites
author: Luo J.; Lannutti J.J.; Seghi R.R.
abstract: The effect of filler porosity on the abrasion resistance of nanoporous silica gel/polymer composites was investigated. Nanoporous silica gels with different porosities were incorporated into polymer matrices, and their abrasion resistance was evaluated. The results showed that the porosity of the filler significantly influenced the wear behavior of the composites. Higher porosity fillers led to increased abrasion resistance due to enhanced energy dissipation and improved filler-matrix interfacial bonding. These findings suggest that controlling filler porosity is a viable strategy to optimize the wear performance of polymer composites.

title: A machine learning framework for automated diagnosis and computer-assisted planning in plastic and reconstructive surgery
author: Knoops, Paul and Papaioannou, Athanasios and Borghi, Alessandro and Breakey, William and Wilson, Alexander and Jeelani, Noor and Zafeiriou, Stefanos and Steinbacher, Derek and Padwa, Bonnie and Dunaway, David and Schievano, Silvia
abstract: Machine learning (ML) has the potential to transform plastic and reconstructive surgery by enabling automated diagnosis and computer-assisted planning. However, the development of ML frameworks tailored to the unique challenges of this field remains limited. Here, we present a comprehensive ML framework designed for automated diagnosis and surgical planning in plastic and reconstructive surgery. Our approach integrates multimodal clinical data, including imaging and patient demographics, to train predictive models that assist in diagnosis and optimize surgical outcomes. We demonstrate the framework's efficacy through case studies involving complex reconstructive procedures, highlighting improvements in diagnostic accuracy and planning efficiency. This work lays the foundation for integrating ML into clinical workflows, ultimately enhancing patient care in plastic and reconstructive surgery.

title: Fluoroscopy-based 3-D reconstruction of femoral bone cement: A new approach for revision total hip replacement
author: De La Fuente M.; Ohnsorge J.A.K.; Schkornmodau E.; Jetzki S.; Wirtz D.C.; Radermacher K.
abstract: This paper presents a new approach for three-dimensional (3-D) reconstruction of femoral bone cement using fluoroscopic images. The method aims to assist in revision total hip replacement surgeries by providing accurate 3-D models of the cement mantle within the femur. The approach involves acquiring multiple fluoroscopic images from different angles, followed by image processing techniques to segment the bone cement and reconstruct its 3-D geometry. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and accuracy of the method, suggesting its potential utility in preoperative planning and intraoperative guidance during revision hip arthroplasty.

title: A fuzzy logic based-method for prognostic decision making in breast and prostate cancers
author: Seker H.; Odetayo M.O.; Petrovic D.; Naguib R.N.G.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine
abstract: This paper presents a fuzzy logic-based method for prognostic decision making in breast and prostate cancers. The approach integrates clinical and pathological data to model the uncertainty and imprecision inherent in medical diagnosis and prognosis. By employing fuzzy sets and fuzzy inference systems, the method provides a flexible and interpretable framework for predicting patient outcomes, aiding clinicians in treatment planning. The proposed system is validated using real patient data, demonstrating improved accuracy and robustness compared to traditional statistical methods. This work highlights the potential of fuzzy logic techniques in enhancing decision support systems in oncology.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses on predicting cancer outcomes instead of evaluating aesthetic results in surgery, so it doesn’t match this review’s topic.

title: A biomechanical and histological evaluation of a bioresorbable lumbar interbody fusion cage
author: Hojo Y.; Kotani Y.; Ito M.; Abumi K.; Kadosawa T.; Shikinami Y.; Minami A.
abstract: The development of bioresorbable implants for spinal fusion has the potential to eliminate the long-term complications associated with permanent metallic implants. This study evaluates the biomechanical and histological performance of a bioresorbable lumbar interbody fusion cage made from poly(L-lactide-co-D,L-lactide) (PLDLLA) in a sheep model. Twelve sheep underwent anterior lumbar interbody fusion at L2-L3 with implantation of the bioresorbable cage filled with autologous bone graft. Biomechanical testing was performed at 3 and 6 months postoperatively to assess fusion stability, and histological analysis was conducted to evaluate new bone formation and implant resorption. Results demonstrated progressive implant degradation accompanied by new bone formation within and around the cage, leading to increased fusion stability over time. The bioresorbable cage provided sufficient initial mechanical support and was gradually replaced by bone, indicating its potential as a viable alternative to metallic cages for lumbar interbody fusion.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focuses only on biomechanical and tissue analysis of spinal implants, without covering automatic prediction or cosmetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Anatomically and Clinically Informed Deep Generative Model for Breast Surgery Outcome Prediction
author: Santos, Joana and Montenegro, Helena and Bonci, Eduard and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: Accurate prediction of breast surgery outcomes is crucial for surgical planning and patient counseling. We propose an anatomically and clinically informed deep generative model that integrates preoperative imaging and clinical data to predict postoperative breast appearance. Our model leverages a variational autoencoder framework conditioned on anatomical landmarks and patient-specific clinical variables to generate realistic postoperative breast images. We validate our approach on a dataset of breast surgery cases, demonstrating improved prediction accuracy and visual fidelity compared to baseline methods. This work highlights the potential of combining anatomical knowledge and clinical information within deep generative models to enhance personalized surgical outcome prediction.

title: A regression model for predicting shape deformation after breast conserving surgery
author: Zolfagharnasab, Hooshiar and Bessa, S{\'\i}lvia and Oliveira, Sara P and Faria, Pedro and Teixeira, Jo{\~a}o F and Cardoso, Jaime S and Oliveira, H{\'e}lder P
abstract: Breast conserving surgery (BCS) is a common treatment for breast cancer, but it often results in shape deformation of the breast, which can affect patient satisfaction and quality of life. This study proposes a regression model to predict the extent of breast shape deformation after BCS using preoperative imaging and clinical data. The model incorporates variables such as tumor size, location, breast volume, and surgical parameters to estimate postoperative breast shape changes. The predictive accuracy of the model was evaluated using a dataset of patients who underwent BCS, demonstrating its potential utility in surgical planning and patient counseling. The results suggest that the regression model can serve as a valuable tool for anticipating cosmetic outcomes and guiding surgical decisions to minimize breast deformity.

title: Histological and compositional evaluations of three types of calcium phosphate cements when implanted in subcutaneous tissue immediately after mixing
author: Miyamoto Y.; Ishikawa K.; Takechi M.; Taketomo T.; Yuasa T.; Nagayama M.; Suzuki K.
abstract: The histological and compositional evaluations of three types of calcium phosphate cements (CPCs) were performed after implantation in subcutaneous tissue of rats immediately after mixing. The three types of CPCs were: (1) a mixture of tetracalcium phosphate and dicalcium phosphate anhydrous (TTCP-DCPA), (2) a mixture of α-tricalcium phosphate and dicalcium phosphate anhydrous (α-TCP-DCPA), and (3) a mixture of α-tricalcium phosphate and calcium carbonate (α-TCP-CaCO3). The CPCs were implanted subcutaneously in rats for 1, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days. Histological examination showed that all CPCs were biocompatible and induced minimal inflammatory reactions. The TTCP-DCPA and α-TCP-DCPA cements gradually transformed into hydroxyapatite (HA) in vivo, as confirmed by X-ray diffraction and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy analyses. The α-TCP-CaCO3 cement showed a different transformation pattern, with the formation of a carbonated apatite phase. These results suggest that the composition of CPCs influences their in vivo behavior and transformation, which is important for their clinical applications in bone repair.
reason_for_full-text_screening: Focus lies only on biocompatibility and material changes in bone repair, with no mention of automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.
